description: When you are visiting Union Square, walk up to the Dewey Monument, it's The Goddess of Victory Statue holding the laurels and trident. Take a deep breath, and now look all around you, make a nice big 360, what you are seeing is Microcosm on a Macro scale.  You are in the Heart of San Francisco. Union Square is only 2.6 acres but this  this one-block plaza and surrounding areas are one of the largest collections of department stores, upscale boutiques, gift shops, art galleries, beauty salons and not to  mention Hotels, in the United States.  Union Square is like the love child of NY's Civic Center and Herald Square with Granny Broadway and Grandpa Nomad. This area has a very cosmopolitan but laid back vibe, and during the holiday season, everything everything is lit up, the Ice Skating rink comes in, and the Christmas Tree towers over guests buzzing around the plaza. You'll find anything and everything you need for your shopping desires, and within close proximity is Chinatown, with a great connection to the cable cars. This is a great place to come and spend a week or month or two.
author: Eddie S.

description:
I'd been Union Square Park countless times cause hubby and I had always stayed at the hotels in this area. We walked here after our lunch nearby, seriously can this few blocks get even more crowded and busier? There were people everywhere, so many tourists speaking all kinds of languages. I was glad they had a few deli stores around this Square, they even had decent selections of beer and wine, I could always use a glass of wine to keep a day going! 

Parents and sister took photos of this park, a lot of people were just sitting around and relaxing, it was a bit hot for me at the moment. I remember they had a dance event last time I was here, I think they have different events all the time, so it's a fun place for local activities I suppose. 

A MUST see when you are in San Francisco Bay Area. Walk around, do some shopping and pick a restaurant to eat and drink nearby later!
author: Mimi L.

description:
It's nice that there's a large open space in the middle of this otherwise dense and busy area full of shops and hotels, but otherwise there's not much to it besides a vast concrete expanse that can host temporary pavilions for special events and an ice rink during the holidays.

Besides this, there's a decent amount of benches and steps at which to sit. The area is also fairly well-patrolled so you won't usually be accosted by random hecklers. All in all, a logical space at which to take a break and reorient yourself before heading on to your next destination.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I was on Maiden Lane when I decided to go to Union Square. I stopped by on Wednesday, July 11th around 2:45pm.

I used to come here all the time on my lunch break and just sit and people watch. Sometimes, I'd grab a coffee at the cafe and sit outside while enjoying the sun. This time, I just walked around a bit as it had been a while since I last visited. I walk by it all the time as it's close to work, but I never really go inside the square anymore. Right now, there's a lot of construction due to the the underground thing they are building, so it's not as pretty. Still, I guess as a tourist, it's a nice place to check out.

Can't wait until they finish all the construction so Union Square is back to normal. Forgot how much I like hanging out here.
author: Elena N.

description: Union Square park is a nice little center to all the crazy shopping areas around in downtown SF.  It's a great place to people watch.  There can be events that are held there.  For example, I've been there when the NBA had something going on and the big Christmas tree is there during the holiday season.  It's not a tourist trap as it is just an area for people to really hang out in some ways.  Stop by and see if there is anything going on when around.  If not, just take a break from all the shopping and chill while the feet recover.
author: Simon N.

description:
I love this place.  The layout of the park is so peaceful/tranquil even though it sits in the middle of busy-ness' like Macy's, Saks, Apple Store, Westin-St. Francis Hotel, etc.  

The center of the park is subtly surrounded by walls and walkways creating a protective barrier.  This keeps the heavy foot traffic on the sideways of the surrounding streets.  You can sit and enjoy the sights and sounds of The City and not feel crowded-in.

Standing in the center, you can take breath-taking photos of all the businesses (or a panoramic photo).  You can also go to those businesses upstairs viewing areas and take photos of Union Square Park. 

Grab a cup of coffee or your favorite drink and maybe food, sit down, and enjoy.  There are food & drink spots IN the park.

Only drawback, I did not see any grass areas and not much greenery.  However, it did not take away from the beauty and peace of this park. 

If you haven't been to Union Square Park, it's a must-visit-see spot in The City (SF).
author: Randy L.

description:
Union Square Park is definitely a tourist destination, but not your typical "tourist trap" vibe (at least on the Sunday morning we went) as it was very spacious and lively without the claustrophobia Pier 39 seems to emit.

They have all of your typical stores on the outskirt of the tiny park, like Macy's, Victoria Secret, Apple, Zara etc. 

I've heard (and now can vouche for) there isn't much to do here if you're just sight seeing without an actual destination or purpose in mind, so our goal was to just find the "Hearts in SF" and grab some Boudin's inside the Macy, since we missed the chance to do so at the Wharf. (Their food is better here in my opinion)

NOTE:
We easily found the 3 hearts on the outskirt/corners of the park, but the bottom right heart was missing. Maybe due to construction?  We stumbled across another heart at Pier 39, and found that the blogs mentioning multiple other hearts' locations weren't reliable/outdated (Yes, I did a lot of research for these hearts haha)
author: Christine H.

description:
I don't think there's a time I've looked at Union Square and not thought of that scene in Francis Ford Coppola's "The Conversation",

"He'd kill us if he had the chance."

Blood chilling.

It starred Harrison Ford in one of his first on-screen speaking roles and Ford, wanting a pair of expensive shoes from luxury San Francisco retailer Wilkes Bashford, was told he could keep the shoes if they were in the shot.

Cleverly, Ford had them shoot his scene with him quickly stepping down the stairs of the Embarcadero Center. You see the shoes before you see his face and they do inform you about the character. 

Now, the park has far less charm than in the movie, the inviting wood benches and boxwood around the interior of the park that once gave it an intimate feel, gone. 

Now it's wide open to discourage homeless from lying around but it also discourages everyone from wanting to linger. 

You walk quickly through the concrete park as a necessity, not a pleasure, hitting the half price tickets booth or underneath, the Union Square garage.

After Christmas when the ice skating rink and Christmas "tree" (an ugly cone that's charming only at night with lights twinkling) it transforms back to its drab, depressing, concrete form.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
We were on a tour bus and our tour guide brought us here.

It was nice to sit on the grass and take it all in. Tourists and locals make their way to Union Square Park. There are plenty of shops, restaurants, hotels, jazz and blues clubs, cafes, and so much more here. You will see cable cars head up Powell Street and flower stands in the corners. We enjoyed window shopping and walking around. I love the artwork done on their iconic hearts, it changes every year. It showcases local artists and these hearts raise money for the San Francisco General Hospital. Very cool!
author: Kimberly J.

description: Really basic park located in the center of a bustling area.  I would say that this is a great place to stop by and take pictures with the decorated heart installations but besides this, that is all.  I didn't linger around with my toddler because there was this guy yelling at people on the streets.  I didn't feel particularly safe or at the very least, let my toddler run around.  I wouldn't say that this is a standard park since there wasn't that much space for kids to run around since there were a lot of stairs.  This isn't the conventional park that parents think of.  There is no playground.  Just benches.
author: Grace W.

description:
Union Square today is considered a high-end shopping district in the heart of San Francisco. Yet, if you delve deeper into "the square" you'll discover a rich history dating to 1850. The land was immediately set aside to be a community park & gathering spot by San Francisco's first mayor, John Geary. The official park's name came in honor of the pro-union army & navy rallies held in the square during the American Civil War - hence the "Union" in the square. The 85-foot tower in the center of the park was dedicated to Admiral Dewey, a popular guy with all millennials;). Yet, many overlook the 9-foot statue of the Goddess Nike at the pinnacle... the Greek Goddess of Victory! Look up! 

Union Square Park is easy to find as it covers over 2-acres in the busiest part of the city. You have not been to San Francisco unless you stroll or sit in the square. Art shows are regularly shown on the weekends. And recently, the heart sculptures from the Hearts in San Francisco public art installation have been placed in each of the four corners of the square. Each year, the sculptures are auctioned off to benefit the San Francisco General Hospital Foundation and new sculptures painted by talented artists are installed in their place. It is said that Tony Bennet's song "I Left My Heart in San Francisco" inspired this wonderful event. Photo ops galore! 

Today, Union Square Park remains as the "heart" of San Francisco, serving as the spot of public concerts and events, art shows, impromptu protests, local events, the winter ice rink, and the annual (love) Christmas tree and Menorah lighting. Iconic landmarks include: Sir Francis Drake Hotel, The Macy's building, and the Grand Hyatt hotel. Other retail giants anchor around the mostly concrete park like Tiffany & Co., Louis Vuitton, Neiman Marcus, Saks 5th Ave, Williams Sonoma, and ironically a giant Nike store! 

Lastly, I can't emphasize the importance of relaxing on a busy day. So if in downtown San Francisco and you're too busy shopping, too busy being busy, just head on over to Union Square Park... maybe you can't breathe-in nature like Golden Gate Park, however "the square" offers you a place to sit even for a few minutes and collect yourself. To hear the trolley's "ring-a-ding". To admire the Greek Goddess Nike. Hey, It's not a bad place to be. You just might be in the mood of singing... "I left my heart in San Francisco..." in Falsetto!
author: Eric R.

description:
Used this park as a meeting point. It is one of the biggest tourist spots you will find in the city. If you don't like being bantered with people trying to upsell you on tours around the city or Alcatraz, stay away from here. Pretty much every corner has people trying to profit off of these tourists by handing out fliers, trying to bother you when you're simply trying to walk by.
Other than that, people come from all over to see the heart statues. They're pretty cool and have different images painted onto them. 
The surrounding area is pretty nice as well, they have plenty of designer shops and places to eat. Overall it's a cool spot, I just think it can get too overwhelming with the huge crowds and difficulty trying to get into the city.
author: Jermaine C.

description: Pretty amazing place especially during Christmas time there's an ice rink, high end stores and a 2 level Apple store surrounding the park. Heck I even saw Governor Ed Brown walking around. Pretty neat place. It's a must see while visiting San Francisco, California.
author: Roxy L.

description: Union Square Park is a unique city square / district. There's tons of stores (Apple, Macy's, Nike, Saks Fifth Avenue, Tiffany's etc) restaurants, clubs and hotels. There are more high end stores than low end. It's definitely more for shopping. If you go during Christmas time, there's a huge tree and a skating rink. Rentals are extra. It's also nice to come at night, since the Christmas and palm trees are lit up.
author: Vincent H.

description: I wanted to come to this CA Historical Landmark for the iconic hearts. I found two. The other two corners didn't have hearts. It may be due to the construction going on. At the center of the park, there is the Dewey Monument. The park is a busy area with many things to do nearby, such as shopping.
author: Helen H.

description: Literally a square surrounded by high end shopping and tour bus drop off/pick up. You can walk around and drop a few bills or just people watch. It's relatively safe and clean. The only annoying part is the people who work for the tour companies harassing you to use their services. Reminds me of Times Square in NYC but more ritzy. Nicest part is the heart sculpture (a reference to Tony Bennett's famous song). You can also stop in one of the little coffee shops and just people watch. ENJOY!
author: Pasquale R.

description:
Alrighty, Union Square is where you're going to find all the good looking babes and gents shopping. Oh wait - tourists as well. Lols.

Union Square is the epicenter of high end shops, department stores, and the largest Victoria Secret I've seen in my life!

Oh and let's not forget the Apple store. It was interesting to see this particular Apple store because it reminded me of all the crazies that waited in line for Apple's next greatest thing. It's a powerhouse I tell ya.

Oh and there's restaurants! Affordable ones! Lol, there's the Cheesecake Factory in the same building where Macy's is. And of course Starbucks.... which is everywhere.

Want to know some fun facts?

- Did you know that the Union Square Apple Store glass is actually the same glass they use on their iPhones? 
- Did you know that all the Department and high end stores cannot be found anywhere else besides Union Square? Yup. You've heard that right. You'll only find it in Union Square. Why? "Equal Opportunity duuuuuuuude." You have to give the small boutiques a chance. Lols. Lols. Lols.
- There's a rumor that Michael Jackson has shopped on all the stores in Union Square. Truth is? He didn't. So don't think "Michael" St. Is named after him lol.

Anywho, I didnt go shopping. I just can't imagine waiting in the crazy lines. 

But that's not to say I won't shop in the future! :)
author: Shannen R.

description:
They have a cute heart sculpture that ppl like to take photos of. Definitely a cool place to just grab a latte and hang out and just chill especially if the weather is great.

It's a huge open space, great for children to run around.
author: Wendi J.

description: This is a review of the Pokémon Go play in Union Square Park in San Francisco,CA. It's a war zone up in here! A churning caldron of battle! There are five gyms and countless poke-stops here. Lures run 24/7. There are also raids going on continuously. If you want to catch hoards of pokemon, come here. The large amount of gyms and stops will also keep your avatar running around and you will crack eggs and earn lots of buddy candy.  Do you like gym battles?  Then this is a great place to play. But you won't hold a gym for long. Its war without end!  If you are in one of the hotels that ring Union Square you can reach the action from your room. I suspect hotel guests are what is really fueling this maelstrom. Because the park can be totally empty at 5:00 am yet the war is going full tilt. Highly recommend!
author: Jerry M.

description:
Beautiful place for hanging out and shopping with lots of stores, cafes and restaurants. Very convenient location. Love it here. 
"I have always been rather better treated in San Francisco than I actually deserved."~Mark Twain
author: Maksim C.

description: Not necessarily the excitement you might desire unless you have shopaholic tendencies. My friend and I did enjoy seeing the tall buildings and ate at Burger Bar to catch a good view. I was hoping for cuter hearts, but saw some pretty basic ones while we were there this past weekend. I did like the display of cool street art.
author: Casey W.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE Union Square Park! It's a beautiful place in a beautiful city! I don't live in San Francisco but thanks to my job, I frequent it quite often. When I have the opportunity, I come and enjoy Union Square Park. It's beautifully decorated for the holidays...a real sight to see! But even when it's not the holidays you'll enjoy the space.
author: Nancy M.

description: You can't visit San Francisco without stopping by Union Square! There are many celebrated department stores to visit and many delicious restaurants to choose from nearby. We visited the square at night to enjoy the end of summer weekend. Enjoy your visit!
author: Vincent Artemio E.

description:
If there is a central point in San Francisco, particularly as a tourist, Union Square is certainly in the running.  Union Square Plaza Park is surrounded by the hustle and bustle of Downtown San Francisco, encircled by Hotels, High End Shopping, Cable Cars and lots of energy.  You feel like you're in the middle of a major city, because you are.  This place has come a long way from its roots - originally this was where pro-Union citizens came to rally during the Civil War.  

I remember my first time standing in the middle of Union Square Plaza Park and being rather in awe of my setting.  This was my first trip to San Francisco.  In fact, my first time to California.  We landed a few hours earlier and were staying at a nearby hotel.  We were walking to drinks (Starlight Room) and dinner (Scala's) at the Sir Francis Drake - not a bad first few hours in SF, huh?  We walked through Union Square Plaza Park just before dusk on an April evening.  There were tourists and locals, and my thought was "Gee, this is really nice."  You're looking at all these amazing building around you and the voices you hear are from across the world.  I didn't know it the very first moment, but within a few hours I started thinking "Maybe I'll live in SF one day..."

Living here now, I don't always have quite the same magical feeling, but this is still a beautiful place.  I enjoy passing through on the way to work in the morning when I'm working from the FiDi - it is sort of peaceful despite the downtown workday frenzy.  It's also beautiful at night when the surrounding buildings are lit up.  There can be art vendors at lunch and outdoor concerts in the evenings.  The best treat is during the holidays when the Tree is up and they have an Ice Staking Rink.  (You should absolutely do this when you are visiting SF)  Also, make sure to get a photo with one of the SF Heart Sculptures.

This is a great spot for visitors and locals alike.  For those of us who live here every day, it's a spot to take a moment and remember just where you are.  I still remember that first night well.
author: Adam S.

description: Very fancy and yet  you need to be careful of your belongings and self here. Busy area but beautiful stores with high end clothing brands.
author: Zoe M.

description:
You can rate a park now, haha! I love Union Square and the places around there. I always come every second Saturday of May to perform at the San Francisco Taiwanese American Cultural Festival. The place is so nostalgic for me, knowing that there is the huge Macy in front of me and a lot of designer shops behind me. Also tons of things to do around the place such as Chinatown and shopping. They always keep the place immaculate. 

Definitely a great place for holding festivals and taking pictures (hint hint Hearts haha). Great place for tourists and locals to really get to know the San Francisco vibe. Honestly, I think this place should be more iconic than the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Vivienne C.

description: Favorite Christmas tradition.. love this area.. from shopping to ice skating, carolers and people watching. The best
author: Mary Ann M.

description:
Union Square Park is a large shopping district full of diverse shops and people, all of whom share the love of exploring the wonders of each store. During the winter season, there is a large and brightly lit Christmas tree perched between Macy's, Saks Fifth Avenue, and the Apple store.

As a tourist, I was concerned that it would be dangerous to walk around in the night time, but when I saw how many people were there, it eased my conscience and allowed me to comfortably take in the lights, music, and breezy night air. If you are not a big fan of extremely crowded areas, then Union Square Park is best to visit during the early morning or late afternoons.
author: Annie C.

description:
This is the park where most popular events occur in San Francisco and it is near many high end department stores.  I love coming here during Christmas time as that is when the city gets an ice rink and you can ice skate even during the warm winter nights.  Although I never learned to ice skate, I enjoy watching and admiring the nearby Christmas displays. 

The shops are high end mostly that sell Coach, Rolex, Tiffany, Armani, and more.  It is always good to be familiar with the trends and what brands are hot at this time, that is true especially if you are like me.  I search for such brands at discount, resale and thrift stores. However, I just prefer not to actually shop at the stores that sell these brands new and at regular price.  

Nearby is the Asian Art Museum that I do enjoy walking through.  I recall once going there to see a Geisha exhibit and fully enjoyed it.  The building houses a great collection of early, Ming Dynasty, stone statues.  

Pros:
-most popular events occur here throughout the year 
-lots of shops, restaurants and hotels in the area but mostly lean toward the expensive side
-my favorite place nearby is the Asian Art Museum 
-large center park that is easy to find

Cons:
-hard to find parking in this area as it is a popular place and if you do, it can be expensive
-shops, hotels, and restaurants are in general expensive in this area
author: Irene S.

description:
I really can't recommend a good time to visit Union Square Park.  I feel as though it's ALWAYS crowded.  Tourists FLOCK to this place.  

The "left my heart in SF" hearts adorn the park and create a unique backdrop for tourist photos.  During the holidays, the city's giant Christmas tree and menorah call Union Square Park home.  

If you don't mind crowds or if you aren't claustrophobic,  Union Square is nice place to visit.  You may want to skip it if you don't enjoy mobs of tourists.
author: Andrea H.

description:
Union Square -- people know it as the place with the HUUUUGEE Macy's! It's a great place to grab some coffee, and chill on your break. I grabbed some dim sum from Chinatown, walked to Union Square, and enjoyed my lunch here with my boyfriend. It's really not too crowded during the day time, however there is a lot of noise from the cars driving around the intersections. Also, this place lacks shade! There's not enough umbrellas to cover all the tables. So prepare yourself, especually on a nice, clear sky day and make sure you find yourself a seat in the shade -- a good place is under the trees right in front of Macys. This place is also very beautiful during Christmas time when they put the tree up,  offer ice skating, and other holiday treats. There are wreaths all up on Macy's and it is definitely a beautiful sight.

Definitely a place to check out if you are new to San Francisco!
author: Mae-Elisa S.

description:
A little rich for my blood but awesome for window shopping, photo snapping, eating, sipping, streetcar riding, hotel staying, night life having, bar hopping, conversing, meeting, greeting and just plain ole fun loving San Francisco memory making.

I absolutely cannot wait to visit this beautiful place again. I left my heart...

~Christy (STL)
author: Christy A.

description:
Passed through here twice on the way to and from meeting the bus tour. A very neat park, which at this time of year is overrun by construction and an ice skating rink. This would probably be awesome if it wasn't for the cranes, the jackhammers and the immense anount of noise going on.

It's just a one-block area, but it's surrounded on all sides by high end shopping destinations, hotels and restaurants. Make it a point to stop here.

Note: As is usual in San Francisco, homeless people abound.
author: Bruce K.

description:
Wide open area in San Francisco covered with cement, chairs and tables for people to enjoy coffee. I feel like it's more like a square than it is a park, because I don't see much greenery in this area. Moreover, it is really just one big space.

Search up this place on google, you'll learn a bit about it's history of why it's a monuemental place. 

One thing that you will definitely see is the big Macy's in the back. What i loved most about this place are the little heart decorations on each side of this "park". I took pictures beside two of them - one of them was white with many collages on it and the other one was a red heart with san francisco's bay bridge graffitied over it.
author: Kristy N.

description: This is the heart of downtown San Francisco and you might meet many interesting events during holidays or weekends. Take a break sometimes and enjoy the every seasonal flower if you got tired by shopping around.
author: River W.

description:
Union Square offers cherished memories for the millions who have come to visit over the years. As old as California itself, and having survived the 1906 earthquake, this iconic park had gotten run down and shabby before being shut down in 2000 for a two year renovation.  And, for a modest $25 mil, we got our money's worth - it's an equally great spot for a quiet book read, outdoor concert, people watching, afternoon stroll or for a well-earned caffeine boost during your SF holiday shopping trip.

Speaking of which, are the cable cars nearby still filled with Christmas carolers?
author: John H.

description: The vibe and energy is alive! A great place to relax, look at some beautiful art work and watch people in action. I took many pictures at this park. Macy's and Saxs Fifth Avenue surround the park with other stores. You will definitely want to see what I'm talking about once you visit here.
author: Becky G.

description: Passed through the park numerous times and the energy is infectious. There always seemed to be something new to see and it is the perfect spot for people watching. Some panhandling,  but not overwhelming. Take a moment, sit and relax and watch the world pass by. Terrific location for shopping or finding a little history. There is a great wine bar  1/2 block away on Geary Street just past Powell.
author: Dave W.

description: Great place for a pit stop in between shopping, sightseeing or for taking a lunch break if you work downtown. Great views of San Francisco architecture from every angle! Just across the street (from any direction) one can easily find coffee, shops, restaurants or plush department stores. My only issue is that there are several homeless folks constantly milling around and often hitting up people for money. It tends to kill the scenic/chill vibe here. But, this place is still worthy of four stars for sure. Definitely worth your time to visit Union Square Park.
author: Peter C.

description:
Sort of a central meeting point/park in downtown San Francisco, which really shines in the winter holiday season.

Parking? Yeah, no. There's some not very economical parking garages scattered around, but be advised that there is some construction going on around the square, which makes an already challenging traffic situation even more complicated. The best bart station to use to get here is the powell station, which offers a fairly pleasant walk straight up to union square. Well, after you get out of the station anyway.The not so great members of the San Francisco street scene know that they can make bank panhandling tourists at this station, so there are more then the usual number of folks asking for money. Once you get past that though it's great.

The park itself is kinda on the ordinary side (Disclaimer: that statement reflects the views and opinions of Steve only and may not be universally shared. Your experiences may vary.) for San Francisco at any rate.It is smack dab in the high end shopping district if that's your thing. It is a main recruiting station for various San Francisco tour bus companies(you'll see what I mean. It's impossible to get in without them hitting you up.So to speak.)There is a magnificent victory memorial for the war of 1898 (the Spanish-American war.), a ton of places to sit and watch people,bicycle rentals, two sophisticated coffee/wine bars (they also serve food. Paninis, insalata and suchlike), a street art market on some days, some photogenic public art, decent views of the surrounding buildings, and well, that's it. I find it more magical in the winter when some of the open space is turned into a public ice skating rink. Awesome for people watching.  Also great for selfies. Pro tip-the shopping center across the street-the one with the starbucks and cheesecake factory-allows for spectacular open air views of the square, once you get to the top floor(the one that has the cheesecake factory restaurant). 

Great for a quiet afternoon of watching people, or if you need a rendezvous spot. Also a perfect jumping off place for the bus tour thingys. But hey if you miss out on this spot, don't sweat it, there's tons of other stuff in San Francisco that are truly truly spectacular.
author: Steven W.

description:
Very festive place around the Christmas Season. 

Parking: Below Union Square is a great deal for SF. I stayed at a local hotel and this parking was cheaper and really close

Grass: This is the only place in the area that has a park like environment. Due to I had a dog with me this was a highly visited spot for us. Lots of benches to enjoy the view. 

Café: There is a café on each side. Nothing fancy and a bit pricy, but they are still a great perk to your visit.

Ice Skating: Very nice rink. We didn't give it a spin, but it was still a nice thing to make the place more festive.

Location: Perfect. Right in the heart of the shopping area. This is a great meeting place and a place to cut through to get to the other side.

No complaints. I will be back to water the grass and park.
author: Melissa S.

description:
This is a chill spot, however, it is in the middle of all the hustle and bustle of union square. I've been here during multiple hours of the day; during the day time, evening, and at night. The steps provide a chill spot to sit.

They also have some of the heart sculptures which are fun to take pictures with. During Christmas time, there's a tree that is decorated very nicely. This is where everyone congregates during Santa Con. There's also an ice rink (see "Union Square ice rink") that you can go to during the holidays. 

It's generally a nice atmosphere throughout the year, but not really a "park" with greenery. It's a nice place to come, sit, and talk (or even walk around, you do you!)
author: Deepti N.

description:
Union Square is definitely a great central location to stay.  

This beautiful park is surrounded by hotels and shopping.  Local artists have paintings set up to browse.  It seems as every form of transportation around the city will stop here.  There are several cable car stops, cabs, several tour bus companies as well as the occasional limo service for $7 to the wharf.  

There is a cute little coffee and treat business by the park with tables.  This is great for many to enjoy a quick breakfast or lunch in a nice setting.  

Union Square has everything you need.  You stay at the Westin St Francis or shop at Tiffany's.  It's all great!
author: Bethany E.

description:
This park is famous for the painted hearts that everyone takes pictures with to post on Instagram and Facebook! It had some cafes and people selling art in the middle of the park.

A lot of people are just hanging out. It's pretty central and close to a lot of stores like Nike, Macy's, Express, and Uniqlo.

There's an underground paid parking lot but we ended up parking in a garage behind Macy's which was $3.50 per hour for the weekend.

We just took our quick photo as a memento of our SF trip and then moved on to the shops after walking around for a bit since there wasn't much else to do at the park.
author: Marianne E.

description:
Why are the hearts gone? :-( Wanted to take my parents to see the famous SF hearts and take our iconic and oh so touristy SF shots, but they were nowhere to be seen.

During the holidays, it is nice and festive in that there are huge Christmas trees - one in the middle of the plaza, one outside of Macy's, and at least another inside a huge department store that can be seen through the high windows. They also have a cheesy but cute outdoor skating rink for added holiday ambiance. 

However, there is also quite a bit of construction going on when we went over Thanksgiving weekend. I get that it'll make it better in the long term, but it does currently detract from the experience a little bit.
author: Phoebe C.

description: We came by to have our to-go lunch, and there are several places to sit. You just have to get a little creative and bear with the dust. There were employees sweeping/raking the area causing a stir of dust and dirt, but it was manageable.
author: Lisa D.

description:
I LOVE SF!

There's no other place like it.  I've been coming here since I was a chubby toddler.  Remember Emporium, remember Woolworth's, remember the iconic Brown twins, we can start a thread about remember when SF had...

...the list would be endless.  I know we all share some of kind of memories while strolling through the park and hangin' at Union Square, whether shopping, people watching, hoppin' on a cable car, or attending a party/function.  Don't forget to dress in layers - bring a coat, jacket or hoodie year-round :) 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tTBsZEZrcOo
author: Christine R.

description: Union square park is not beautiful like golden gate bridge or fun like fisherman's warft, but somehow it's also a landmark of san francisco. I come here once in a while just to chill, watch the busy people walking by. It's location is great as well.
author: Robert J.

description:
The heart of downtown SF. Definitely start here if you're on a tour mission. Even more so if you're going on a shopping spree. Saks n Fifth, Macy's, Neiman Marcus, and other cute little boutiques are all congregated around the union square. This is also a Great spot to get on tour buses. My favourite tour is the one that goes all the way to the Golden Gate.

Parking: there's parking underground or by the mall. Or you can just leave you car at the hotel and walk!
author: Blessing N.

description:
A city square is a fundamental part of any major city. Union Square fulfills this mantra.

Located off of Geary just across the street from the Macy's, this location was the host to a Filipino culture celebration the day I visited. These kind of town centers are a must and are perfect to hold festivals, fairs, and pop up shops of the like.
author: Rawlins R.

description:
I have stayed all around SF during my many trips here and Union Square is always my go to location for convenience.

You're in the heart of the city and centrally located for easy getting around to other areas (trolly cars and BART is easily accessible).  Not to mention, Union Square is close to amzaing shops and restaurants.

It's also just a great place to pop a squat and people watch.

Bring a jacket and comfy shoes.  :)
author: Lucky S.

description:
I'm in a different world here.  This is my third time today, and each time I come I notice more.  I feel like I am in the middle of something amazing.  

If you visit San Francisco, you need to make this your first stop.  You will feel like you're in a different place.  All the great stores are here.  I'm in heaven.

I can't wait to wake up tomorrow!
author: Claire H.

description: So nice to be able to find a good resting spot where you can find a seat without paying in downtown SF! San Francisco is always busy and crowed. You can hardly find a place to just chill a little bit if you are shopping here. Union square is one of the few exceptions. I love sitting here with my eyes closed, feel the busy lives around me, but keeping my mind in peace. I dont know how to explain it, but that feeling is incredible.
author: Hazel B.

description:
Nice area to take a break from a busy day of work, play, shopping, etc. love the green space in a sea full of buildings to hangout. I would recommend this as a place to hangout with friends, have a picnic or just read a book. 

Pros:
Very central
Well groomed green space despite the foot traffic 

Cons: non big ones except this place gets busy!!
author: Michael T.

description: Always lots of people and in a great location! I appreciate the parking garage directly underneath it. I do wish the cafes on either end sold cocktails too, rather than just beer/wine. There's currently a tractor that's been sitting out in front of it (a total eyesore) within view of the Christmas tree and Macy's beautiful holiday lights -- I feel like Ive seen that tractor there for the past year, but I could be wrong, there just always seems to be construction right in front of the park.
author: Natasha K.

description: Places Cooper convenient Airport parking. The only reason for a not five-star was it was pretty confusing knowing where and how to get out of the place on the side that I wanted to be on. Ended up on the wrong side and had to walk all the way around but no big deal... My fat ass needs exercise anyways. :-)
author: Joseph M.

description:
Union Square is hands down my favorite place to shop in the Bay Area. It has everything you could ever want! It is a shopping paradise that also has yummy food. I could easily spend an entire day here and have an absolute blast.

My favorite stores include the gigantic eight (?) story Macy's right in the middle of the square, Nordstrom in the Westfield Mall, the MAC makeup store, the Sephora store, and the three story Forever 21. I also love to browse Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue when I feel like treating myself. 

My favorite food spots to hit up are Tout Sweet in Macy's (some of my favorite macarons!), the Cheesecake Factory in Macy's (lovely restaurant for dinner and has glorious views of Union Square since it is located at the top of Macy's), Godiva in Westfield Mall (hello truffles!), ENO wine bar (it's wine -- need I say more?), and Dojima Ann (for delicious and inexpensive sushi). 

I particularly love Union Square during the holidays when they light a humongous tree in the middle of the square and build a cute little ice rink right next to the tree. There is no where else I feel more festive than when I am spending the day in Union Square for the holidays!

Union Square also has a stop where you get on the cable car to ride into other parts of the city, but the line is always incredibly long, and I don't believe it is worth it for the wait considering BART and MUNI also have stops right in Union Square that can take you anywhere in the city as well. 

Union Square is one of my favorite spots in the city, and I'll always keep coming back!
author: Pooja M.

description:
Union Square has always been a favorite part of my city to go to and to spend the days. During the spring and summer days, it's nice to sit at and have a cup of iced tea or some lunch. On fall and winter days, walking around and hanging out is just as nice. During the holiday season they have an ice skating rink, huge Christmas tree and menorah for Hanukkah and Christmas lights all around. 

There are a lot of shops around Union Square, mainly high end stores like LV, Prada, NM, VS, Tiffany & Co, Bulgari etc so if those are your stores than this is your place to be around. There are also plenty of hotels around if you are coming from out of town because everything is local. Definitely come check this out if you have never been or if you are from the area, hanging out here is cool too! Only down side is the parking is hard to find and yes it's expensive - but it's SF, so what do you expect? Lol
author: Anne R.

description:
Union Square Park is a great central location in the very compact city of San Francisco! High end shopping surrounds for several blocks out, lots of great hotels to choose from, a major trolley stop is located on one of the four framing streets, tons of eateries here and there, the iconic, Tony Bennett song inspired SF Heart art pieces are present for fun and cute photo opps, and the park maintains several beautiful palm tress (quite the feat for so often cold NCal SF). 

One of the major streets is currently under construction, so that certainly deters from the overall charm a bit. Apparently the park underwent a recent renovation, thus ridding the area of many homeless people and dissuading the once present pickpockets as well. There are occasional spottings of street performers to take pleasure in; however, for being such a "city center" park (particularly with all of the ever present tourists about 7 days a week), the lack of street food (there is one pretzel stand) is quite perplexing. Perhaps city permit issues, rules and regs, ...?   

Overall, USP is a very nice place to sit on a sunny day, enjoy a cool drink, relax for a bit and give your feet a rest...and of course, people watch. A park is not a city park unless there is good people watching to be had. :0
author: Dawn H.

description: Right in the heart of SF is this little park taking up a city block.  When I was there, an ice rink was set up.  It's a nice place to sit and observe the hustle and bustle of the Frisco activity.  A great location for shops, restaurants and hotels.  The walk is not too bad from the metro as well.  The famous cable car passes through here and get you all the way to Fisherman's Wharf.  My hotel was not too far from here.  I intentionally reserved to stay in this area due to it's close proximity to great shops and restaurants.
author: Darrell K.

description:
Heart of Downtown. Every since they remodeled Union Square things have gotten better and better. 

Great respite to take a break from shopping or to get out of the office to grab a quick drink, coffee, or lunch.

It appears the bums are allergic to the clean so that is a major bonus.

Great to see all the tourists scurrying about.

Take a few minutes in your hectic day and plop yourself down and see what happens!!!
author: David G.

description: You'll see a bunch of tourists here, like me LOL. Always crowded here. This is where you can find the big "left my heart in SF" hearts that people take pics in front of. The one in my pic is right across the Union Square Apple Store if ya don't wanna walk around looking for it!
author: Ha P.

description: Give this entire area a wide berth unless you love crowds of clueless tourists, dodging human feces, and a thick layer of filth on every surface you touch. Impossible to enjoy the nice view from the park given the overall environment and quality of the facilities.
author: Owen P.

description:
Hearts of San Francisco, luxury hotels, and shopping! Plus the famous cable cars and all the tour buses go through here.

My favorite time is definitely at night, when there's less crowds, and in the middle of this busy city you can just sit with a nice warm drink and just hang out.

Home of the Dewey Monument, where the Goddess of Victory welcomes you.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Hehe how do I not write about one of my most favorite parks?

One of the hearts of San Francisco, Union Square is the busy bustling mecca filled with people of all kinds. Workers, businessmen, businesswomen, school kids, families, friends, lovers, etc. This is the place where every tourist needs to see at least once in their lives. This is the place where a lot of the magic occurs for SF.

For one thing, this park is completely surrounded with loads of stores. Boutiques, restaurants, hotels, you name it, it's probably here (maybe lol). One of the best things to do is to choose to dine outside of cheesecake factory (inside Macy's) and you'll find yourself staring down the people all around. Make sure its a sunny day!

During Christmas, this place is the place to be. The beautiful Christmas tree is a sight that no one wants to miss. Take pictures, this tree goes down some time in the middle of January. And people can enjoy the ice skating rink after gazing upon the tall Christmas tree.

The only downside about this place is getting here if you drive. Just. Don't. LOL. Congested traffic + angry drivers + loads of pedestrians = should've used public transportation. 

There is a thing about finding all the Hearts of San Francisco. Union square has one. So definitely find it and look for more!
author: Jerianne G.

description: This was a great place to visit. I was able to take a picture with 3 different hearts. Unfortunately, the place was under construction and a portion of it was blocked off. It's in the heart of San Fran and right by the trolley!
author: Camellia P.

description: Union Square is a nice place to take someone who came from out of town. Take pictures with the hearts. Do a little shopping. Get irritated with everyone. Show how busy SF really is.
author: Roen R.

description:
This is one of the best people watching spots ever.  So many people pass through this small park.   Shoppers, skateboarders, tourists, locals, so many....

It's located in San Francisco's shopping district surrounded by stores in tall buildings.

There are lots of things that happen here depending in when you come, like art sales and ice skating.  It's a great space to visit and eat lunch or just relax.
author: Mark B.

description: The center of all the shopping that can be done at Union Square. The square itself isn't too big and there isn't much of note this last visit, but big enough for an ice skating rink and a tree for the holiday festivities. There were some booths too for some pictures and other groups promoting their cause. Some areas that were fenced off so I suppose they are performing repairs and sprucing it up. As a natural focal point of Union square it was designed well for that purpose...so naturally it'll be crowded. Meet up and go to your next destination!
author: Desmond F.

description:
Union Square is a plaza more than it is a park in a sense that there is far more concrete with tables and chairs than green and trees.  There is a cafe on the east side called Emporio Rulli but there are places to sit and just relax in this very dense and noisy part of town.  This square is surrounded by hotels and retail shopping stores such as Macy's and Neiman Marcus and the specialty stores like Tiffany, Gucci and Chanel.  This area in general down to market has much of the big shopping in the downtown area.  Big stores like the Gap and Anthropologie are down closer to Market.

The west side of the square is Hyde Street where the cable car turns around just at the bottom near Market St so it's easy access this area if you're a tourist staying near Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Lambert P.

description:
Great place to wander and watch people, shop, and stroll along the place.
Perfect spot to sit a relax with a cup of coffee or boba haha.
After walking around and all, we sat there and just stared at all these amazing architectural buildings surrounding the park.
7 For All Mankind, Aldo, H&M, Saks 5th Avenue, Tiffany & Co. 
Most are all high-end retailers.
For first-timers and tourists, great place to check it out!
Take pictures with SF hearts on the corners of the park!
There's a parking structure and fees vary with time.
author: Laramae E.

description: It's a beautiful place to walk around and get your shopping done!  Lots of hustle and bustle (obviously) so guard your belongings appropriately.
author: Veronica A.

description:
Another tourist spot of SF. It is located in the middle of a lot of tall buildings and shopping centers. On the four corners of Union Square, there are the iconic hearts of SF that you have probably seen people take pictures with. There is a red one with the golden gate bridge that is always there but the other three rotates often.

During my most recent visit, there was a lot of construction going on so one of the corners did not have a heart sculpture. The other two were pretty cool, one had "Hello" written in the various languages of the world and the other consisted of polaroid snapshots of SF. 

This is a neat place to stroll around and window shop or even bar hop!
author: Minh-An C.

description:
I work a block away so I hang out or pass through here a lot.

Positives:
- The holidays are a fun, festive time. There's a big tree and the whole square is decked out, complete with an ice skating rink.
- Always fun to people-watch.
- The heart sculptures
- Lots of restaurants around and in it.
- SHOPS EVERYWHERE
- Usually sunny by the afternoon. Protected from the wind.
- Cable cars and lots of other class SF attractions are right here.

Negatives:
- If you don't like crowds, you won't want to be here. It's hectic!!
- LOUD. Noise from people, traffic, and construction is nonstop.
- Crowded. Often no actual seats available, especially in the shade.
- Lots of homeless people, bible thumpers, and other sales people for tourist things.
- Tourist confusion to the Nth degree. Like, on the phones, taking pics, oblivious to the locals trying to come and go or just sit and relax.
- PIgeons. Everywhere. With their droppings.
author: Katherine R.

description: Love that this little park and square is just several blocks up the road from me. It's definitely well appreciated, especially since the only other green space is all the way up in Nob Hill. It's a nice pit stop for the dogs, and great to check out all the cool events going on in the city. There's something different going on in the square every time I go there, from swing dancing to salsa, even to just wine by the glass and enjoying someone's company. Nice little chill oasis in the middle of this concrete jungle called SF.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Union Square Park is smacked dabbed in the middle of SF's shopping mecca.  This is the circumference of point zero, you will find lux boutique shops, big departments stores, fine dining, hotels, and the hustle and bustle of tourist, residents, workers, food seekers and shoppers surrounding this park.  This is where you can put your feet up, drink a cup of latte, wear your sunglasses as you people watch or take cheesy peace symbol photos in front of the 'I love SF' heart statues.  

This park hosts various events throughout the year!  Here are some things to make your heart race into the square...

!) Movie in the Park - during the warm summer nights, they will play old classics on a jumbo sized screen.  Bring a blanket, a picnic basket and find a comfortable spot to snuggle with your family and loved ones.  There's romance in the air...

!) Weekend music festivals - pop in to listen to the beat and perhaps swing dance with a live band playing on the band stand.  It's lively, fresh, and festive when the music is blaring out and believe me, your toes will tap to the music!

!) Santacon!! - 1 day out of the year, all Santa Clause outfits can be dusted and worn to this function.  Sexy Santa, Drunk Santa, Bumble bee Santa, Normal Santa, Greedy Santa, Naked Santa... you name it, that santa has been here!  It's a sea of RED and it should never be missed.  Though you may feel claustrophobic at times...

!) Hermes Museum Tent - See Hermes artisans make purses right in front of your eyes.  See the leather and watch it transform into the most expensive purses in the world.  Luxury that you can appreciate as an artform.  

!) kristie Yamaguchi Ice Skating Rink - it's here every year.  Though its small and the ice is choppy from the sun beating down into the rink, it is a tradition that shouldn't be missed.  This year, they had drag queens kick-off the opening of the rink.  A site you will never see anywhere else but San Francisco!

I can go on and on about how fabulous this park is.  But you should come here for yourself and experience it.  Who knows what you'll find at this park, as I had stumbled into most of these events by accident.  But event or none, this is definitely one of the best parks you'll ever visit in San Francisco...
author: Jenny T.

description:
When you walk into Union Square Park, you feel like you're in an urban oasis of fine shops and fancy folks.  I have to admit, when I walk around this area, I feel a little out of place in my frayed jeans and modest Merona fleece.  Honestly, it is a real treat to step off of BART at the Powell station and walk on the glittering sidewalks that lead up to Union Square.  I can pretend, if only just for a few moments, that I am a high-paying executive working in one of those high rise buildings in FiDi :)  

Union Square Park itself is well-designed and gorgeous day or night.  There are large steps with grassy landings, tall palms, and beautifully painted hearts at some of the park's corners.  Planters overflow with exquisite specimens of Angel's trumpets (Brugmansia, for my fellow botany nerds :p) while nearby planters contain vividly colored annuals (petunias, if I recall correctly).  Emporio Rulli Cafe sits right on Union Square and caters to your coffee and sandwich needs.  Outdoor seating is a must for a cafe like this, and Emporio Rulli does not disappoint with its ample seating in the sun, shade, or indoors.  I really like how there are oversized steps inside Union Square Park for lounging and people-watching, too.  

At nighttime, the lights from the street and neighboring shops cast warm shadows and pools of mysterious light on the park's stones.  It is quite a different feel at nighttime, but just as beautiful as in the day.  Right now, there is a warm red glow in the Square from all the Chinese New Year lanterns!  Various events are held on Union Square, so check their website to stay up to date with them.  And if you can, stop by during the holiday season to watch the Macy's Union Square tree lighting ceremony.  It is crowded, but oh so breathtaking to see.  It definitely ignites the holiday spirit in everyone, too! :)
author: Brittany N.

description:
Good news: the new subway system is advancing nicely, with construction going at a much more rapid pace since falling behind due to the Christmas holidays.

Bad news: This park isn't as beautiful now.

I had a day off and wanted to read a book in the beautiful sunny day, so I headed here thinking I could lounge on the grassy steps and read/people watch for an hour or 2.

There is now construction going on 3 out of 4 of the streets. Stockton is (and has been) closed off completely. Geary is starting to see shifted lanes, orange cones, and disrupted sidewalks. The construction is also spilling onto Post street on the North End.

They have taken out half of the iconic "hearts" that border the park. The grassy area was closed off for "maintenance due to recent storms."

So as I sat on a ledge and read, the sounds of jack-hammering and construction machines filled the air instead. 

What a drastic change from 3 weeks ago when this park was lively and inviting.
But of course, the construction can only bring good changes and additions to this city. But in the meantime, the park will suffer a bit in the aesthetics department.
author: Lanie L.

description:
This review is all about the park. (There's a separate listing for the 'hood.) Sometimes I purposefully select my walk route to pass through this centrally located square. But occasionally I'm disappointed that my diagonal shortcut is blocked off by fences for a temporary event. (Lots of events happen here, and some like to put up huge tents in the middle, which hinders the usual for foot traffic across the park.)

There's something for everybody, which is why everyone from different walks of life congregates here. In the spring, you can admire cherry blossoms juxtaposed with the year-round palm trees. Between May and October, you can catch live performances, thanks to Union Square Live. In the winter, you'll likely see the gargantuan Macy's Christmas (fake) tree, the oversized menorah, and the ice skating rink.

The park is also friendly for tourist activities: at least two different hop on, hop off tour bus companies have stops here, and there's also a bike rental service on the west side of the park.

It also has a long history. You will can read more of these facts on the plaque located at the southwest corner of the park, but the following are my favorites:
* Union Square was originally called O'Farrell's Mountain in 1847 because it was a sand dune. The sand dune was cleared around 1860, and the park was named after the public rallies held in support of the Union during the Civil War.
* After the 1906 earthquake, temporary hotel rooms were built in the square while St. Francis Hotel was being reconstructed.
* Timothy Pflueger (architect of the Castro Theater and the San Francisco Stock Exchange) designed the parking garage under the square, which was the first underground parking facility and doubled as an air raid shelter.

The verdict: As a local, I do have a love-hate relationship with Union Square, but I think I secretly love it more than I hate having to navigate the throngs of tourists in the area.
author: Tiff T.

description:
This is a great meeting location and starting point to venture the Union Square. There's Tiffany, Macy's, LV, Chanel, Neiman, etc., at the immediate site. Walking several yards in any direction, you'll find more shops and diverse restaurants. 100 yards down on Powell St, there's the Westfield Mall, Bloomingdales, Nordstrom, and many many more.  This is also the main location for cable cars, if you planning on using this form of transportation during your trip. 

The Union Square Park is a beautiful city park unlike other parks. You'll see diverse people constantly bustling through and many will stop to take photos or selfies, locals casually strolling, workers taking a break, street musicians at every turn, and beggars.. 

The cosmopolitan city feel is extremely appealing. Come check it out for yourself.
author: Manola J.

description:
If you dislike Union Square, your soul must be made of antifreeze or something.

Beloved by both locals and tourists alike, Union Square is the urban heart of SF -- and, by some measures, the entire West Coast.  Its closest cousin would be Times Square in NYC, but Union Square is infinitely tidier, classier, and more welcoming.

Shopping?  Union Square has you covered.  All the world-class boutiques (plus Uniqlo!) are within a block.  The Westfield San Francisco Centre is right there too.

Dining?  Plenty of that too.  Sure, a handful of chain restaurants loom large over the place, but there's no shortage of interesting mom-and-pop shops and bistros.

People-watching?  Of course there's people-watching... It's SF after all.  On any given day, you'll have street performers, Japanese tourists, scavenger hunters, and other miscellaneous crazies vying for your attention.  They're never rude or pushy, though.

Relaxing?  That's the best part of all!  On a gorgeous spring day, just plop yourself on one of the many benches, and soak up the sun in the company of waterfalls of flowers.  There's really no better feeling.

I love Union Square... and, if I lived in the city, I'd drop by everyday.  =)
author: David G.

description: Union Square is in a swanky area of SF, stores such as Saks, Neiman Marcus, Tiffany's, Macy's, etc. are surrounding the big paved park. At Xmas it's beautiful with the ice skating rink and giant lit tree. Summers are nice to sit under a tree or on spark bench with a coffee and people watch. There's a lot of good restaurants nearby, nice hotels such as St Francis or Sir Francis Drake, and there within the park a couple small cafes.
author: Danielle G.

description:
There are so very many things that I love about San Francisco, and while tourismy tourism full of tourists isn't tops on that list, I still do love it. So that's the thing that I like about Union Square. You have all the consumerism that you'll ever need--Tiffany's, Macy's, and any other y's you can shake a stick (or a credit card) at.

But keep your eyes open, because this is, after all, San Francisco. So you'll still see pigeons, and political messages, and weirdos, and amazing style, and killer food nearby. You don't have to look too far beyond that family from Wisconsin to see that street musician trying to make a living. 

I took a stroll near holiday times, and they've got the massive Christmas tree up in the park. And lots of skating. And it's completely lovely. But even in the non-winter months, this is a must-see (at least once) for anyone checking the San Francisco box off of their travel list.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Best place to enjoy your morning breakfast and latte. Simply buy your take away from the Walgreen's Upmarket on Powell, find a table and enjoy people watching.  There is also an Italian cafe on the SW corner with yummy selections.

The local artist guild sets up there in the morning and there are regular music concerts in the afternoons.

Tour buses leave from the SW corner, and all the big stores surround the park. Chinatown gate is a few blocks north and over.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
This park is great to relax after  shopping, people watching, and admiring the buildings around downtown.

What I liked most during this visit was the ice rink and the tall Christmas Tree was a nice touch to bring some added cheer. 

Be advise, Union Square is full of tourists and homeless people,just like the Las Vegas Strip and the Los Angeles and Hollywood areas are full of tourists and bums.
author: Paul B.

description:
Every tourist and local ends up here whether by choice or chance.
This square is a lot of things.  It's the center of shopping, there's a garage underneath, there are painted hearts, a cafe, a ticket booth and a bus stop for tourist buses.  There is also plenty of space to enjoy a snack or people watch.  
There are a lot of events where they will tent.  During the winter they have an ice skating rink which is pretty picturesque.  It's always buzzing with activity.  Meet up here, rest here, take pictures with your favorite art heart.
author: Kristi G.

description:
You're not going to find a better place to capture the essence of downtown San Francisco than Union Square. Besides plenty of tourists, you'll see plenty of quirky locals, performances, impromptu speeches, protests, parades, tours and anything else you can think of. It's the ultimate place to people watch. All you have to do is take a seat, sit back and enjoy. 

Since I was a tiny kid, I've always loved coming here. It's a historic central hub, a bustling centerpiece to the vibrant city around it. There is always LIFE happening here. Spend a couple hours here on any given day and you'll witness so many of the people that make the city by the bay so great. 

Besides the human element, there is also plenty of architecture to admire. The Westin St. Francis, one of the most beautiful hotels on the west coast, is on the west end.
author: Alex L.

description:
Union Square Park is great to visit if you're visiting for the first time, especially around the holiday season. There's lots of space & places to sit. It's also surrounded by hearts, a few cafes & shopping outlets. It's smack dabbed in the heart of the city!

I love visiting here when it's night time because everything is lit up & the air is usually breezy! It's also less crowded at night time & all the pigeons are asleep. It's also quiet & peaceful at night. During the day, you hear the busy roads & people walking fast to get to where they need to go.

There's a parking garage right underneath the park but it's pricey per hour.

You haven't experienced San Francisco if you haven't visited Union Square!
author: Gwyne P.

description: Only walked through at night, but i'm sure there's a lot of traffic during the day.  It's beautiful at night with the lights. Got some great pictures
author: Fay A.

description:
Union Square is filled with Christmas spirit. The stores around the Macy's Christmas Tree all came together to sing you Yelpers this Christmas Carol...

***
(The Twelve Days of Christmas)

On the first day of Christmas, my Yelpers sent to me...

12 Shoppers shopping

11 Skaters skating

10 Taxis waiting   

9 Men are shaving  (TheArtOfShaving)

8 Lattes Brewing    (Starbucks)

7 Models modeling  (VictoriasSecret) 

6 Cheesecakes baking  (TheCheesecakeFactory)

5 Tifffffffffffany Rings!   (Tiffanys)

4 Afternoon Tea   (TheRotunda)

3 Handbags  (LouieV)

2 Jordan buffs  (Niketown)

Annnnd Macy's with their BIG Treeeeeeeeee  (Macy's)

***

Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays Yelpers! Come enjoy Union Square and have a December to remember! Special thanks to Macy's for putting up the tree every year :)

-----
Bonus carol from Niketown, which happens to be foodkid's fave store and Christmas song...


***NikeTown, Last Christmas***

Last Christmas, I gave you gift carddd
but you saw some hype J's, and blew it awayy.
This year, to save you some time
I'll buy you the Retro specials!   #LegendBlue #AJXI #GOODLUCK
author: Ringo M.

description:
Union Square is definitely my must go places in SF. 

Great for shopping, eating, taking a stroll and relaxing!

They have popular department stores, upscale boutiques, art galleries, restaurants, hotels, and movie theaters. My favorite stores are Zara and Uniqlo. Also, there is a Westfield San Francisco Centre nearby on Market St.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I went to Union Square Park for the NBA Nations tour. I was excited to hear it was in San Francisco during my visit. I feel lucky because the tour only go to 8 cities. The entire basketball setup in the park was cool. I was like a kid in the candy store. I love basketball and having courts in the heart of Downtown San Francisco was unreal. The park is shaded well and you can enjoy sun. If I lived in San Francisco, Union Square Park would be a regular hangout for me. I'm glad I got to experience playing basketball in Union Square Park. The different hearts throughout the park is a big tourist attraction for pictures. A lot of foot traffic comes through the park during prime hours. Union Square Park is a good place for relaxation in San Francisco.
author: Dominic B.

description:
One of my favorite places to go in SF. Pretty touristy, but I like it. 

There always seems to be an event going on, but I never have trouble finding parking. The garage conveniently is located underground. It gets expensive, but it's better than driving around for an hour to find street parking where your car can easily get dinged/scratched/stolen(?). 

There are sooo many places to shop. My boyfriend is a huge Nike fan, so we always go there. Neiman Marcus is also nice if you want something more high end.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
TOURIST TRAP.  Only reason I love coming here is because they showcase the new hearts on 3 of the 4 corners.  They aren't there now because it's closer to the end of the year and probably already sold and the new hearts come out in February.  The other corner is Tony Bennett's heart inspired by his song "I left my heart in San Francisco" called America's Greatest City by the Bay.  That one never moves.  It's great they showcase the hearts because a ton of people see it.  It brings the publicity the hearts need and it showcases local area artists.  I love art in public places plus these hearts raises money for the San Francisco General Hospital. 

It's a good place to people watch since shopping is everywhere.  It's close to the BART and the cable cars.  I love christmas time because they have ice skating and the giant christmas tree.  Sometimes they have events at Union Square.  I remember there was a Japanese Pop event or something like that.  There are always street performances around union square so that's always fun.  Lots to do and see at union square!
author: Chrissie O.

description: The parking here. Oh my god. There is a 15 minute limit from paying to getting out. On busy days it takes 20+ minutes to get out. What a stupid system that caused so many people to be stuck in the parking lot on Christmas. Don't park here.
author: Timothy D.

description: Union Square Park was a great little breath of fresh air amongst the hustle and bustle of down town. The Union Square Mall was under construction and extra stressful, which made this utopia of a park even more refreshing. I liked the fact that there was a little store in the park to buy food and beverages, including alcoholic beverages. While I went shopping my husband relaxed with a beer and people watched. It worked out perfectly.
author: Chelsea B.

description: So my fiancé and I have been coming here for the past few years during Christmas and Santa Con. We love seeing everyone here dressed in santa costumes and checking out all the holiday decorations. This year they had an area next to Macy's where kids could play and shoot their lightcopters. This is the city so there's always some weirdos here so be prepared for that lol.
author: Ramon A.

description:
Union Square is the buzzing epicenter of retail San Francisco and I find myself passing through here often either to or from various city walks. The square is especially festive during the Christmas season with the tree and ice rink, however, there are other activities throughout the year that set this area abuzz. Just this past weekend, there was a small art show of local San Francisco area artists and in the spring there was a festival dedicated to the culture of Taiawan. 

It's a great pit stop for sitting and people watching and a great meeting spot as well if you're connecting with some friends in the city. Sure, there is the usual array of the lost, homeless and slightly crazy citizens-but that's anywhere you go in this general vicinity. Use common sense, as you would anywhere else, grab a snack and have seat to admire the bustling square, the well manicured palm trees and the monuments to retail industry (Macy's, Nieman's, Tiffany, etc) nearby.

Easy walk from either Montgomery or Powell BART stations-I don't recommend driving-not by any means. Those of you from out of town, take heed on that for sure!

Not a full day destination but a nice pit stop in your San Francisco travels.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
there is only really one way into the park at the moment as construction is going on.  The steps face Macy's and there is usually a hot dog cart across the way.  Do try a hot dog they are organic and tasty.

Bad news is that with the construction there are places the homeless can hide out and avoid the folks that are hired to evict them.  I wouldn't have a  problem with it if they would sit and stay warm but when they get in your face and harass your kids that's not a good thing.
author: Megan B.

description:
I have been here multiple times and it's absolutely wonderful! It's such a cute place for pictures and absolutely beautiful during Christmas time because of that giant Christmas tree. It was actually my first time here for the Tree Lighting Event and it was crazy! 

The park itself is huge. It takes up the very center of the Downtown SF shopping area. It's literally a square right in the middle of all the shops. It's sort of a big park where you can rest and just sit and talk after a long day of shopping! It's also a nice place to take pictures, especially with the hearts they display. I do think they take it down once in a while because I only saw one this last time I went. 

But during the normal seasons, there's usually a few hearts on the corners of the park. It's only during Christmas when they put up on these decorations and the giant tree. They also have a ice skating rank right at the park, too! 

This is definitely worth a trip to at least once when you're in Downtown SF. It really is a tourist place, but it's great to be there to get that Downtown SF experience. Parking can be painful, but I suggest going a little further to those parking garages.
author: Wendy Y.

description:
HEARTS

If you don't know where Union Square is, you'll probably know it as the place where there are HEART SCULPTURES ....... because I did. =X 

And what makes it a tourist attraction? (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/union-square-park-san-francisco-2?select=bGO4dkdxxG_PxcQiFVNUfg#l6WtbmR2P4Hf6rMjs88-6A) taking a photo next to the heart sculpture like yours truly did. There is one on each corner of the park, each decorated in a different design by an artist. 

Union Square Park is located in the "heart" of Union Square - where you'll find people hustlin' and bustin' to work, several high end eateries (and cheap hot dog stands too) and designer stores. But you'll probably be seeing a bunch of tourists walking around and taking photos (*ahem* like me *ahem*) There is a tall column with a statue within the middle of the park. I'm not quite familiar with the history of the statue, but it stands out that people are taking photos of it, but not as much as the heart sculptures. 

FYI =
*The park is probably the only thing you'll find with grass when you're in the city. 
*Located above an underground public parking lot 
*WHICH is very $$$$ parking and probably the only parking nearby
*Lots of benches to hang out in the midst of the busy city
*Across the street from the largest Macy's (it's the flagship store)
*Walk down Powell St. to get to the Westfield SF Center mall (although most of the stores in that mall are also located outside near Union Square Park)
*A public restroom is located near the entrance of the parking garage
*Near the Westin Hotel and other major hotel boutiques
*Great place to people watch!

Whether you are a tourist (or not) I'm sure you'd love to take a photo (or two) next to the HEART SCULPTURES! 

Yelp 2013 100 for 100 Challenge - Review #99
author: Kristen M.

description:
Ice skating was great. It is much cheaper if you buy online ahead of time. 

I think they have a playlist of the worst Christmas music of all time. Literally the very worst. Please play better music. It's so bad.
author: Julie G.

description:
If your in for a tour to San Francisco this historical landmark is a must to add to your list.

Its located in the heart of Downtown San Francisco and this square is surrounded with restaurants,hotels and shops. The popular spots here are the painted hearts sculptures installed on the steps of the square, its a favorite of couples that takes pictures with it or just by everyone. 

There is even a statue right in the middle of the plaza called the Goddess of Victory which catches your eye. During the Christmas holidays there is huge Macy's Christmas tree displayed here as well.

As much as I visit Frisco I don't come here much but It was good memories for me on my first time. When we walk by here Its nice to see people gather and having their Kodak moments.
author: Jon B.

description:
There's always something about being in a big city and sitting in the grass having a picnic. 
Despite all the traffic, honking of cabs, and giant buildings surrounding you; there's some sense of one-ness you have with it all.

And the fact that it was a sun-shiny day......well, who could ask for anything more =)

You gotta love San Francisco for times like these!
author: Laurie V.

description:
This place is active. Often times, events are being held here. It is super busy.
Parking is right underneath and when Christmas is around, this where the Huge tree is. 

Right next to SF's shopping district!
author: Roger A.

description:
Yes I like it. I like it in the winter when Christmas decor and the skating rink is in full season. I like it during the spring when the weather is grand. I like it in the summer when tourists come to see how awesome our city is. And I like it in the fall when I can sip a pumpkin spice latte watching people go by.

I was here today and there was a huge rally concerning freeing Syria. It added to the cacophony and made for a very unpleasant lounge time. Now I am cool with certain types of protests and I love when people speak up for their beliefs but come on, is chanting "Free Syria" going to free Syria? Last I heard John Kerry isn't around here to hear the chants. Last I knew, our hands were tied with the country. How about doing it at the statehouse in Sacramento or even better, in DC?

I mean should I hold up a sign that says "Find the missing Malaysian Airlines Plane!". Will that change anything?

Speak freely, but speak effectively - sheesh.
author: Julia P.

description: Five stars! Lots to do and shop around! Many good eateries around! In holiday months they have an ice skating rink as well! Fun.    !
author: Jordan B.

description:
How can you go to San Francisco and not make a stop at Union Square Park? Similar to what others are saying, there is something for everyone here. The diversity of the people who visit this place every day is mind blowing..so many different languages being spoken at one time it's crazy to think about. My favorite thing to do here is people watch. There are people from all walks of life who pass through this place. Surrounding this park are tons of great shopping destinations like Louis Vuitton, Macy's, etc...and plenty of spaces to lounge around to people watch. 

During the winter time there is a decent skating rink and beautiful Christmas trees adorned with unique trinkets and ornaments. During the summer, there are a variety of activities that occur throughout the day and in the evening-my favorite thing I have done here is watch an outdoor movie - perfect for a chilly night so you can bring fleece blankets to stay warm. 

My only semi gripe about this place is the heavy number of pan handlers who can get a little intense...
author: Vy B.

description:
Such a great spot in the epicentre of San Francsico tourist consumerism. 

Palm trees, patio furnirture, green space, all a stones throw away from certain credit card debt and busy traffic. manifique.. LURVE!!!

Specific stand outs to me were the patio tables/chairs set out and apparently if you're in "the know" there is a free WiFi offering in the area (which I couldn't figure out how to lock into).

Echoing the sentiments of Benjamin G, this also makes a great landmark/point of reference for out of towners (such as myself). Worth a stop to rest weary shopping/tourist legs.
author: Kris U.

description: Once in a while I visit SF Union Sq for lots of events and seeing & making a wish on the big Christmas tree down there. Also Like to see people I skating down there too.
author: Mychael H.

description:
Union Square is the most popular shopping destination in San Francisco and possibly Northern California.  Technically, it's just one city block surrounded by nothing but hotels, department stores, upscale boutiques, theaters, etc.  Pretty much all the major and upscale brands are located here.  Definitely a fashionable and cosmopolitan place.  Several flagship stores are located on the square, including Macy's and Levi's.
