It's a very busy area with both locals and tourists filling up the sidewalks and streets.

Always decorated extravagantly for the holidays, Union Square, Macy's, and Neiman Marcus each have their own gigantic, multistory Christmas trees.  You can see all three at once from the square.  Macy's also has lighted Christmas wreaths in every single window.  It's certainly a sight to behold.  Also during the holidays, Union Square has an outdoor ice skating rink setup.  All in all, a beautiful square that is fun to walk around, shop, and people watch.
author: Daniel B.

description:
Great looking city park.  We came here for Christmas and really enjoyed observing the ice skating rink and huge Christmas Tree.   This park is also located near big name brand stores and restaurants therefore it is easy to spend the whole day here shopping, dining and people watching. 

The only downfall I would say is the parking.  Oh I am sure SF gets to hear about it all day long but seriously parking can take up a huge chunk of your day.  We took our chances with the parking structure located directly underneath the park even though it said "lot full"  we circled it a few times and finally found parking.  It was not too expensive and the elevator brings you directly to the park so that's a plus.   When you pay your ticket at the end you need to rush out before the 15 minutes is up otherwise you are charged for the extra minutes which can be challenging when everyone is trying to get out all at once.

Overall a great park.
author: Sylvia Q.

description:
Neat little park in the middle of downtown.

Parking here sucks like crazy.  Best to take the BART here.

The park itself is pretty neat, but admittedly most of it is covered in concrete.  You are really just sitting on top of an underground parkade after all.  With that said, there are some nice public art displays here, and there are plenty of steps for you to sit down ponder life, or which ghetto dim sum place to try next.
author: Edward L.

description: Pretty and relaxing. Kept clean. There's a nice bustle as tourists and locals mix in the shared space.
author: Irene S.

description: SF is a very unique city great shopping food and bars Union square is a landmark in the city if u haven't been get there!!!
author: Sac M.

description: People watching, lively city life, shopping, live music.. Always something going on. Love this place.  Bring a blanket & chill in the sun.
author: Mandie A.

description:
Loved union square and macys (only because the my has my purse and it would have cost a fortune to get it here in Birmingham!). 

I had food on top of Macys at the Cheesecake Factory and it was delicious. The staff were very friendly and efficient also. The cheesecake was amazing! Too much for me. I had to bring it back to my room and I still could not eat all of it! (San Francisco - I am only one person with a one person portion stomach size. Lol).
author: Charlene F.

description: Holiday time, this is the place to be, 80ft Christmas tree, a highly decorated Macy's, Saks Fifth, the heart of every single expensive place to shop in Northern California, 60k purses to million dollar jewelry. Classical views and access to everything. There is a pickup/drop-off for all transportation here. Trolley's, Cable Cars, Buses, Taxi services, Uber drivers, Lyft Drivers, Tram, BART, all within a few spaces or block walk. The Ice Skating rink in the middle for the Christmas season, Reef's and decorated, brightly lit buildings from Nordstroms at the Bottom of the Hill and Westfield Plaza on Mission. Any kind of food is here, visually pleasing at night, daytime a classical gem of the City of San Francisco. Tourists everywhere, literally, keep your valuables close, and your significant other closer, lots of flirtatious activity here. But that's San Francisco and it's lively communities. A lot of thieves, store thefts, transients, homeless, crack heads, hookers, pimps, and street entertainment to bask upon, only reason downplayed to 4 stars, you have to pay attention or lose a wallet or worst, get your credit card information stolen by scanners. Identity theft a possibility here, keep your stuff close, deep in pockets or purses, cops were tackling people left and right, sirens at multiple locations and police with people in handcuffs on quite a few corners awaiting a "pickup" from any kind of police car that could squeeze through, the cops were on Motorcycles that were arresting people, only way in. 4 stars for the only factor of questionable activity. To be expected, but well governed and policed. Enjoy your time!
author: Phil H.

description: We come here usually just for a quick break from walking from place to place, this last time was to let my little nephew get out of his stroller & run around a bit.  It's a big open space with all walks of life there, this time with lots of weed wafting thru the air.  So maybe not so great to bring the little ones.
author: Judy S.

description: it's just another tourist spot. so if you plan on being in a very busy and crowded place then this is the place for you. completely surrounded by buildings and although that may seem like a turn off, the lights at night are beautiful and something that I look forward too.
author: Xavier L.

description:
Union Square, what can I say about you? I love your stores, love your restaurants and coffee shops, and I love how easy it is to walk around.  It's so convenient and it's great for window shopping or walking with a friend and catching up.  If I lived in the city, I think I'd make frequent trips here since it has everything.  

We actually had a scavenger hunt in SF and it was super fun because we had to find methods of transportation to get around and take pictures of the most random things.  It kind of helped to learn how to find you way around the city, but gosh..it's still tough for me!  Good thing I got my handy dandy gps :P
author: Grace K.

description:
Mostly unnoticed in my regular SF shopping trips...but when she is all decked out for Christmas and Hanukkah....she is quite a sight!!

We braved the crowds so the DGD's could see the lights. I was a bit overwhelmed by how hard it was to simply walk down the street....and there was a disgusting woman smoking not 5 feet away from the skating rink while children looked on....yes I told her she was a jerk.

The girls were in thrilled...the skaters and the Zamboni were the highlights of our trip. We also saw the pets in Macy's window....a big *awwww* from DGD the elder.

Worth it all to see the looks on their faces!
author: Katherine F.

description:
I tried to stay out of the city on most recent bay Area visit but I had some stuff to do so I failed at that plan. During my errands I took a breather in Union Square and people watched. I looked at the big ass tree and all the Christmas decorations.
The little park is nice, there's a stage a couple cafes and plenty of people to eyeball. You can watch the elevators rise and fall at the St. Frances Hotel and in the winter you can ice skate too.
You can park beneath.
This is the middle of the this area of town.
author: Alexander R.

description:
Self explanatory:

It's the spot to see the Christmas tree lighting show, ice skating rink during the holidays, a spectacular view to be in the middle of the shopping area in SF and of course, free movies or shows held here during the summer time.

How can you not like it? Besides, it's my meeting spot whenever my friends and I need to meet up for dinner or lunch and head out to go shopping. Or sit around, take in the sights, and enjoy a nice cup of coffee or tea while waiting for friends or families while they meander around union square.

The only CONs I have personally, super crowded during the holidays. Especially during SantaCon. Will that keep me clear away from here? Nope. I'll be around.

Maybe I'll run into you here Yelpers! Happy shopping!
author: Fraulein C.

description:
Let me start off by saying...

I FUCKING LOVE SAN FRANCISCO!

And one of the major spots of this great city that melts my heart is Union Square.

Location:
Union Square is located near BART Stations, shops, and restaurants which makes for plenty to do. Additionally, for some reason despite it being a centerpiece of San Francisco, I never really see many tourists around so you can always have plenty of space to relax.

Events:
Union Square is home to plenty of events. Every now and again, there's a market or an art display. Other times, there are community organised flash mobs. 

This park definitely keeps the spirit of downtown San Francisco alive instead of letting it slip into shallow city-life.

5 stars for Union Square!
5 stars for San Francisco!
author: Clarissa Y.

description: Fun time and really cool plants. Not sure the name of the place but it was on the other side of the square opposite of Westin St Francis but a nice breakfast sandwich and juice to start the morning.
author: Allen O.

description:
Free seating. Looks like a lot of people just sit around and...watch other people...most of whom are watching other people as well...watching them back...

The hearts are entertaining. I wish they had more bench seating though, with shade.
author: K G.

description: Whenever I think of San Francisco, I think of Union Square. The energy of this place makes it seem like the center and hub of the entire city. Shops line the entire square, as well as restaurants, and even though you may not be able to afford Prada or Gucci or Louis Vuitton, it is still fun to walk around in the city surrounded by skyscrapers and the aura of wonder.
author: Ally M.

description: Love coming here to see the heart structures located on each corner of the park. They change every so often. Plenty of areas to sit and people watch or eat. Located across from a huge Macy's and around various dining establishments. On weekends, you may encounter cultural festivals, protests of some sort, and/or interesting people roaming the area. Good place to chill and hang out.
author: Sandy H.

description: One of the most beautiful area in San Francisco city for the visitors & local . I went there More that 4 times with my friends, it's very nice to chill-out and they have a very good café in the corner for breakfast.
author: Moaid M.

description:
Beautiful day... Time to spare.... Why not head to Union Square to take gorgeous pictures to the heart artworks, beautiful trees and flowers, and the diversity of the community?  Union Square has a quiet element in the hustle and bustle of the city.  One time when I was in Union Square, there was a respectful and peaceful protest for the Syrian issues.  I find this area to be an excellent place to relax.

And as always, Have Fun!!!
author: Christian H.

description:
Another huge shopping area in San Francisco.  There are a ton of restaurants and boutiques here - the center piece is the Macys building.  During the holiday season (my favorite time of the year to visit), they put up a huge Christmas tree right in the middle of Union Square.  There is also an ice skating rink and a ton of people gathered around to admire the spectacle.  If you want to grab a bite, I'd suggest checking out the Cheesecake Factory or the Burger Bar inside the Macys building.  The food at both these places are decent, but it's the view of Union Square that's worth the price.  Keep in mind though, the wait time for the Cheesecake Factory could run anywhere from half an hour to two hours!

Also, parking can be a pain in the butt, not to mention quite expensive too.  My suggestion is to take the Bart (Bay Area Rapid Transit) to the Powell station, which drops you off right inside the SF Westfield Shopping Center (just a few short blocks away from Union Square).  

If you're looking for a shopper's paradise, this is where you want to be.  If you're not into shopping, not a problem.. you can admire all the tourists in the area too :)

Watch out for hobos!  It is SF after all...
author: Cecilia S.

description:
As much as I hate anything tourist dominated, Union Square provides so much that I just can't give it anything less than four stars. 

Excellent shopping: check. (H&M, Zara, Apple)
People watching: check. (sit on the steps facing Macy's)
Entertainment: check. (watch all the dumb tourists and street performers)
Decent food: check. (food court at Westfield)
Accessibility: check. (Bart and Muni stops galore)
Weather: check. (gets less wind and more sun than other areas of the city)

Parking is a total bitch though. Don't even think about coming here via car unless you're prepared to pay through the nose for garage parking.
author: Henry W.

description:
Union Square Park is pretty all season long. During spring and summer it's cool to sit back and take a break from shopping and have a little picnic and people watch. What am I saying? You can pretty much do that any season as long as its not raining outside. 

During the holidays it's soooo lovely! This place is decked out in full blown decor with huge ornaments and pretty lights from head to toe.

Great place to chill and take a break, indefinitely!
author: Rhona R.

description:
Union Sq is one of my fav places in SF.

:)
author: Carol Y.

description: I live a couple blocks away & every day no matter what different crowd of people are here or different event, art show, live music, etc. it's always full of life but also a very peaceful place to come and relax. I bring my 6 month old daughter here at least once a day. It's our favorite park in the heart of the city. Very convenient location and security guards on staff at all times. Very safe & clean.
author: K P.

description: Great little park to relax, people watch, read a book, chat with friends, etc Right in the heart of Union Sq - limited grassy areas but the patches facing Macy's have outlets in the ground - great for charging up your electronics.
author: Brenda L.

description: This is just a tourist spot. When we came there was a lot of people selling art. It's a must see if your visiting SF.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Love this place! So much like New York's Central park in a lot of ways.

My husband and I sauntered through the whole area, including the shopping malls and the four-story Macy's.  We came at night on a Saturday and during lunch time the following Sunday. Both times were fun.   Love the city.

Everyone's diverse too and it's just a nice place to hang out.

I will minus one star due to the fact that parking is horrible. We had to circle the whole place over 3-4 times (took about an hour) to get to the parking lot. That was on the Saturday evening - bad idea. It was also very pricey to park. Fortunately on Sunday afternoon, we were able to find parking in Chinatown for free and walked it; albeit far, but very worth the stroll.

Can't wait to come back soon!
author: Summer S.

description: Beautiful place to take pictures at, perfect for tourist. They have four hearts at each corner! Me and my fiancé had nice walk around that park, there is a nice cafe there too and plenty of stores around.
author: Juan C.

description: Coffee in one hand, breakfast in the other, the sun shining on Union Square and me sitting on the steps. That's what I call a perfect morning.
author: Bekkah R.

description:
This is a really beautiful area of San Francisco!  I came to the city to visit friends for Thanksgiving, and Saturday evening we ended up here taking in all the holiday decorations, ice skating, and overall awesome vibe of the city. There are so many stores here, I feel like I am in a smaller version of NYC without nearly as much crowd and traffic.  Beautiful architecture, plenty to do and see.  It's a must to see when you are exploring San Francisco. 

I wouldn't recommend trying to drive in, take the BART or CalTrain into the city and use those feet to get around or take advantage of the MUNI system.  The city is only four miles wide, you can manage without a car and avoid parking nightmares.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Great place as a local and a tourist. 

The took out two of the hearts, but the other two hearts are on Geary. Currently, there's the 'blue sky' heart and the 'San Fran-Golden Gate Bridge' one that everyone takes a picture with. 

It's a great place to relax, chill, and listen to some music. The grass is a nice place to sit. There are homeless people around, but it's San Francisco so it's typical. There is a parking structure downstairs, but not worth the price. 

If you just want to stop from shopping, sit there and enjoy the view.
author: Adam J.

description: Even though I miss the old version of this park, I always do enjoy spending a bit of time here whenever I am in Union Square.  I just wish there was more of a lawn like the old days....
author: Thomas D.

description:
Union Square Park is a pretty cool place. Pretty touristy, and packed with people, but there's still space to just sit down and relax among the hustle and bustle of Downtown San Francisco.

The main stage of the park is used for various events, such as the SF Chefs Festival, the Christmas ice rink, and many others.

The one thing I love is the SF Hearts placed around the park. They change every year, so there's just one more reason to come back - to check out these delightful pieces of art!
author: Kevin J.

description: I thought it was a park but really it is a central hub in the heart of Downtown. It is surrounded by plenty of shops and restaurants, which makes the area pretty busy. In the square itself, they host a few vendors, a cafe, a restaurant, and plenty of outdoor seating to relax and people watch. The main attraction here is the big heart sculptures where many people take pictures by, where lines can get long surprisingly. My boyfriend stayed here to relax and check out the area. While cool, it's super crowded and touristy which isn't our style so we went ahead to our next destination.
author: Felicia L.

description:
Pretty awesome. Loved this downtown and the feel of an intense city in the middle of San Fran. 

People watching here is the most entertaining thing ever. Be ready to spend hours walking around :D
author: Dominique F.

description:
This is a nice little clean park and the city does a great job keeping out the pigeons and homeless. 

The Christmas ice rink is small but fun.
author: Justin S.

description:
Union Square is a mecca for people from all over the world. The day I was here a lot of Frenchies was in town for a convention.

Crossing the street countless of times that day and meeting the same Frenchies once or twice was funny. It's a place where you can mind your own business or you can be friendly and reach out. 

I'm curious by nature so I found out who and why the Frenchies were in town. They all said they love the good ol  US of A. How about that? :0 Not to mention they were throwing their euro dollar practically everywhere. They were in the same stores I was. Same breakfast place I was. 

In short Union Square is yours and what you make of it.
author: Janet D.

description: Great place during the holidays to enjoy ice skating and see beautiful Christmas decorations!
author: Michael S.

description: This is by far the best public square's in the park in the city. I absolutely love the ice skating rink in the winter time along with the huge christmas tree. So many exclusive store's like Macy's, Louise Vuitton, Gucci, Banana Republic, ect. The cable car also comes throught here pretty frequently. It's the perfect place to sit down, have a bite to eat, and just people watch. Take the escalator's in Macy's to the 7th floor. There you will find the cheesecake factory with all sort's of different cheesecakes to choose from. There's also a bar with a lookout over the square. This is truly one of San Francisco's most treasured gem's.
author: Tj J.

description: A place to relax while waiting for the sun to set. Nice place nice people from all walks of life and from around the globe. Name it and you have it Sax, Macy's, Tiffany, Neiman etc.
author: Robbleeav D.

description:
Shops, shops, shops, shops and more shops!

High end like Neiman Marcus and low end like H&M - there is something for everyone in Union Square.  The people watching is top notch if you are into that, all walks of life come through this area...tourists and locals alike can't deny that fact.  Tourists - the locals look at you and giggle.  Locals - the tourists look at you and giggle, too.

The location is wonderful and the park is a perfect getaway from the hustle and bustle of the city (although I am sure even the park can be quite busy).  I really enjoy the painted heart sculptures that are on the corners.  There were artists selling their work in the square when I was there, a beautiful place to look at beautiful things.

One of my friends participated in a Flash Mob there once, so I can imagine it happens every now and then; would've been cool to be there or participate.

If you are a tourist, I would say it is a must visit spot in San Fran, great photo opps, great shopping, lots of people (which can also be a negative), right downtown and easy to get to/from on public transportation.
author: Jasmine B.

description: Union Square is an awesome place! Located in the heart of SF, surrounded by a bunch of key shopping stores, including a gigantic Macy's! The stores are pretty much the same as stores down here in SoCal, so don't expect a lot of "unique" stores, except for UniqLo - no pun intended. Definitely a fun place to walk around and explore, although it's usually pretty crowded. Parking is ridiculously expensive, so either put on your walking shoes or be prepared to take public transportation. Luckily, the latter is a super convenient transportation mode, since it pretty much goes everywhere and is beyond reasonably priced.
author: Nancy T.

description:
One of the nicer areas of the city. Actually, second to North Beach, Union Square is my favorite. The plaza is pretty, and the shopping is good. It is a little sanctuary from the hustle and bustle of cars to see the hustle and bustle of people going about their day! 

Definitely walk the area - no car needed. Take a break on a bench in the plaza and take it all in. It has such a different vibe compared to all the other neighborhoods in this city. This is the perfect spot to start and end a day of walking around the city to sight see.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Parking is HELLA expensive.

Aside from that, this is the ultimate SF shopping experience. Don't bother going to Westfield. Union Square has all those stores 3x the size! Imagine a 3 story Zara...a 3 story Forever 21...the biggest Banana Republic ever...yup, that's all here in Union Square!
author: Esther Y.

description: Alway a pleasure, to take a walk, or sit for awhile, on a sunny day here just to enjoy the weather, and of course "people watch".  Today, there was an Art Show, I saw a really great painting, I wish now i would have got it!  Surrounding the park, is some of the best shopping in the world, hard to resist not going in all the great stores.
author: Winny S.

description:
Fantastic spot for an alfresco lunch on a sunny day! It can be crowded if you're looking for shade.

There are two little cafe's at each side of the park with designated outdoor seating. Lovely oasis in the middle of the downtown bustle!
author: Kate N.

description:
What a lovely spot in the city!

Surrounded by the shopping area, this place is a nice getaway from the stores if you want to lay in the grass, catch some sunshine, relax, or wander around looking at the art vendors in the center.

Surrounded by palm trees, there are plenty of spots to sit on stairs, grass, or walls.
author: Akvile D.

description:
and in the middle of it all... an ice rink!

if you've ever found yourself in union square as a tourist or a local you already know all about the awesome shops that can be found all around -macy's- tiffany's -nike town.... there are some very tasty places to discover and dine too! cheesecake factory- neimann marcus' - burger bar...
and there is of course the signature hearts on the different corners of the square to take a picture of :)

this review however is for the ice rink that you can find during the holidays. add one gigantic festive tree and then string lights EVERYWHERE! and it's just magical. so come on by! they will be open for a couple more weeks.

happy holidays!

until next time-

cheers!
author: Jerico P.

description:
Now THIS is a fantastic respite from the craziness of San Fran. Go ahead. Take a little breath of fresh air, roll out a blanket (whilst dodging the small colony of angry pigeons and their fecal matter), plop down with lunch, and enjoy the passersby/sunshine/San Fran beat. Multiple levels of green space and enough room to call your own for an hour or two. 

Also great to use as a landmark or judge for distance.
author: Benjamin G.

description: This is a nice spot for parents who are shopping, yet need an  "outdoor break" for their kids.  Whenever we pass by, we stop to let my son explore  in the square.  I love people watching and just resting here.  At Christmas time, my son can run around the large Christmas tree and watch the ice skaters (super small rink though) for quite a while.  If you are visiting San Francisco as a tourist, it's definitely a nice place to take a break while you shop, or before you hop on the cable car for another destination.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Union Square is a public park within a concrete jungle, where children and adults come and go. The park is a great place to sit (if you go on days without too many shoppers or tourists) and people watch while connecting to via Wi-Fi or just to sip your favorite beverage (most likely purchased from one of many coffee shops in the area).

This is a great place to enjoy a moment away from the everyday hustle, though personally I would avoid here on days when too many people simply crowd cause traffic to come to a standstill. Since the central subway is about to begin heavy construction, the relative tranquility of this park will be compromised, so come here if you wish to escape, but don't stay too long and let the noise ruin the experience.
author: Rob L.

description:
In the middle of all the places to shop downtown, a perfect spot to meet up with others or just hang out. 

I love the Hearts of Union square and I've seen one of the best ones so far, YODA!
author: Steph S.

description: Best in the winter when the big tree is up and the skaters spin to the music.  I love to stand here and look up and around at the park and the awesome city.
author: Leonard S.

description:
Consumer purgatory amidst a metropolis smothered in secondhand smoke and disposable coffee cups. I can actually feel the city grime metastasizing in my lungs when I try to navigate my way through this maze of zealous tourists. 

The only store I actually spent more than an anxiety-haunted minute in was Niketown. Angels sounded trumpets and opened the golden gates of  this multi-level clothing paradise for me and I relished every garment and shoe like the wide-eyed trophy wives next door in Saks, and that's when I felt compelled to leave. That, and thoughts of El Salvadorian factory workers being beaten for asking for fair wages. No matter, we're all going to Hell anyway. Watch my Hell end up being Neimans.
author: Julianna O.

description: A nice town square in the center of the city. There's not much on this square itself, but this is the epicenter of a lot of downtown SF.
author: Ross L.

description:
You are more to me than just a pretty landmark. More than the pinaccle of the shopping district (I never did much shopping anyway). Every time I see you, you take my breath away, just a little bit. I instantly feel thankful that I live here and that I can sit in what I feel is the heart of the city, and watch the people, cars, buses and cable cars all whiz by....

You're unlike any other.

You remind me of the days my grandma (God rest her soul) and my mom would take me here to feed the pigeons on a lazy Sunday. The plaza looks different now, but just as beautiful.

You remind me of the times I tried to ice skate in your skating rink and fell on my ass, but I laughed and kept going.

You remind me of the times I teared up during the tree-lighting ceremony during Christmas time, and how the air smells during the holidays. There's an energy in the air...

You remind me of everything I love about my city. And just like an old friend, I promise to keep finding excuses to come and visit you every chance I get, so you can take my breath away one more time :)
author: Mariela D.

description: Union Square located near the end of the Powell Street cable car, China Town and the Theater District offers the best names in fashion for shopping or dining and theater. You are a short walk to the end of the world famous cable car located at the cross streets of Powell and Market to head off to Fisherman's Wharf and  Ghiradelli Square to enjoy the natural hills of San Francisco. There is an abundance of shopping in an around the Union Square and Market street area. Numerous hotels are in the area, including the world famous historical Westin Saint Frances hotel and my more affordable Kimpton Prescott hotel.
author: Tony J.

description:
Sometimes I like to put on my blond Afro wig and tie the sleeves of my green cardigan around my shoulders. I would stand in the middle of the plaza and start singing Art Garfunkel songs like an angelic choirboy...

"Since we can no longer make it, girl,
I found a new place to live my life.
It's really no place at all,
Just a lot of concrete, you see.
It's cold and windy but I let it be,
Livin' without you there,
Right on Union Square."

OK, that was "Second Avenue", my children. But it doesn't matter 'cause I lied...I don't busk. However, I do have this fantasy of being that Irish guy in "Once" and singing the hell out of Van Morrison in the middle of Union Square. Gee, any of you remember the opening scenes of "The Conversation" in the old Union Square when Gene Hackman was spying on Cindy Williams (yes, Shirley of Laverne and...)?

OK, so do people at least remember when this place was a pit everyone avoided at night because of the lack of lighting and all the unkempt greenery? But now it's a model urban space well worth hanging out just for the flow of the United Nations delegations streaming by. On a sunny Saturday afternoon, me and Jamie W. would park ourselves on one of those silver benches and make fun of the people walking by like Woody Allen did with Diane Keaton in "Annie Hall"..."Look, there's the winner of the Truman Capote look-alike contest."

Or I'd come early in the morning and watch far healthier-looking people doing tai chi, while I gnaw on my bear claw and slurp my venti-size cappuccino much to the chagrin of the dress shirt I'm usually wearing. Or I'd watch the lovers strolling by at dusk and try to be encouraging..."Look who's gettin' lucky tonight! Wooo-hoooo!!" Anyhow, I love Union Square for its wide open space, terrace seating and the generally genial demeanor of the people who pass by because...

"When you're weary, feeling small,
When tears are in your eyes, I will dry them all;
I'm on your side ...when times get rough
And friends just can't be found,
Like a park next to troubled retailers
I will lay me down.
Like a park next to troubled retailers
I will lay me down!"

OK, that was "Bridge Over Troubled Water". Work with me, people ...work with me.
author: Ed U.

description:
LOVE hangin' out here. So much to do, see and eat!!! 

This is where I stay whenever I'm having fun in the Bay Area. 

Tons of shopping (from H&M to Burberry), you can find it all here. 

You can't leave without taking pics of each of the "hearts" that encompass the square. There's actually one with a pic of YODA! 

BART and the cable cars are nearby and within walking distance. Walking is the mode of my transportation for the most part.
author: Maria C.

description:
If you want to do shopping in SF this is the place.  There is a huge westfield mall with plenty of stores as well as several large blocks filled with everything from luxury brands to everyday brands.

I guess it would be somewhat similar to Rodeo Dr. in Beverly Hills except Union square is larger and has less emphasis on high end luxury brands
author: Ben Y.

description: yeah this is the spot to people watch & shop.
author: Tony B.

description:
Union Square is a plaza bordered by Geary, Powell, Post and Stockton Streets. Union Square also refers to the central shopping, hotel, and theater district that surrounds the plaza for several blocks. 

Union Square was built and dedicated by San Francisco's first American mayor John Geary in 1850, and is so named for the pro-Union rallies that happened there before and during the Civil War. Since then, the plaza has undergone some changes including the 1903 dedication of a monument to Admiral George Dewey's victory at the Battle of Manila Bay during the Spanish American War. It also commemorates President William McKinley, who had been recently assassinated. The figurine at the top of the monument, "Victory", was modeled from the likeness of a local heiress. Around 1940, a large underground parking garage was built under the square that relocated the plaza's lawns, shrubs and the Dewey monument to the garage "roof." 

During the late 1970s, and into the 1990s, the area became a bit derelict, as the homeless began to camp in the space. San Francisco's rowdy New Year's parties used to happen yearly at the plaza with some sort of civil disruption happening. In early 1998, city planners began plans to renovate the plaza to create more paved surfaces for easier maintenance, with outdoor cafes, and more levels to the underground garage. In late 2000, the park was partially closed down to complete these renovations.  Then in July of 2002, the park was reopened. Then Mayor Willie Brown was quoted as saying - "Use it; it is your square" 

Gayle and I particularly enjoy Union Square during the Holiday Season at night. We come here to look through the Macy's windows (especially the cats and dogs), admire the lights, and walk hand-in-hand through the Plaza. The only things missing are snow and a one horse open sleigh.
author: Eric B.

description:
Regular Tuesday. Not even a holiday, this place is PACKED. Parking garages were full too! Took 3-4 garage drivebys before a "FULL" sign was not seen at the entrance. 

Also Stockton & Grant (I think) right at the corner of the nike store, construction. You can't go straight. Right turn only! Learned that the hard way. 

If driving, watch out for pedestrians of all sizes. My only city complaint is, the light for cars and pedestrians are the same length, 20 people can cross the street but only 2-3 cars can make it through. Let's work on that please?
author: Dany B.

description: I will go sit there sometimes with a coffee and people watch. Other than a place to sit for a minute for me its okay. I don't enjoy getting frumped at when I don't give homeless people money every 5-10 minutes. I wish there were some better street foods than the pretzel stand outside of Macy's. It is a good place to meet up with people.
author: Amy W.

description:
Great spot for people watching! Winter time it was so pretty with decorations, huge Macy's Christmas tree and ice skating rink. Only downside was no bathrooms, none that I found at least. 

But it's a worthy stop when exploring the city, views of historic buildings.
author: Kayla L.

description:
Union Square is a hub of San Francisco.  It's very touristy.  I think that the majority of people we saw were tourists.  I would venture to say that SF has more tourists than LA.

I left my car at the hotel.  I've concluded that although SF's public transportation isn't the greatest, it's better than trying to squeeze about in the thick traffic and pay through the nose for parking if you're able to fine one.

Union Square is an exciting place to be.  It's flavorful and eclectic with big box retailers, restaurants and opportunities to people watch.
author: Keila N.

description:
It's a very touristy area. The view isn't the best, but if you come during the daytime, it'll give you a first hand view of the hustle and bustle of union square. I think the view of it (cheesecake factory, best during Christmas time at night) is better than the view from it. There's cafes on both ends of the park where there are plenty of seating to soak up the rare beautiful day and people watch. For some reason, people just love to sit on the stairs across from Macy's and stare at everyone. The main type of people you will see here are: 1. Business types 2. Tourists 3. Freaks and Misfits 4. The homeless

If you want to take a load off from all of the shopping and walking, you can do so here. But be warned, the amount of traffic and people traffic doesn't allow for a full relaxation.
author: Phan H.

description:
Union Square is a destination i haven't been to for a while. i've always seen more birds here than people, especially that flying rat kind. the blackbirds and swaallows i don't mind. Union Square is probably known for it's parking garage. i may have gone in once or twice but haven't gone since. maybe it's expensive.

highlights at union square:
-holiday ice rink : a decade or so ago, my kids really liked it here. maybe it was a lot cheaper and less crowded then.  street parking was also possible at that time.
-festivals of all kinds: korean, filipino celebrations of culture and/or independence: nice display of diversity.
-the open space in the mass of concrete is welcome. just watch out for dem birds!
-protest rallites : can't remember if i actually attended one though i probably witness one here but can't remember what i saw, who i saw and what they did or didn't do.

@union square is bartable-exit powell station.
author: Victor G.

description:
This is the place where I fell in love with SF! Not the wharf or the GG bridge, its Union Square! The hustle and bustle of the square is enough to fill you with excitement and make you feel alive. You don't need to go here for shopping, just enjoying the atmosphere is enough to have a great experience! 

Oh, before you sit down on one of the benches, grab a hotdog or pretzel (or both) from the street vendors around the square, it makes the experience so much better!
author: Gordon O.

description:
The first time I ever came to San Francisco it was raining so I never got to get out of the car and see all of the goodness that is Union Square.  I did some research on this place and found out that the name "Union Square" comes from the area being used during the Civil War for rallies and support for the Union Army back when California was a frontier state full of gold diggers (the frontiersmen are gone but I'm not so sure about the gold diggers.)

This place is basically Times Square of the West Coast.  I'm probably speaking from a tourist's point of view, but this place was really fun just to walk around for the first time on a summer afternoon.  Everywhere you look you see department stores, restaurants, tourists/college students/very well dressed people walking around, the amazing San Francisco architecture, street performers, and so much more.  This place is also super accessible through the Muni/BART (which you should take because I can't even imagine what parking would be like here - and I'm from LA).

If you're visiting San Francisco and you have a couple of hours to kill, take a stroll around here!
author: Josh C.

description:
Such a pretty sight during the Holidays! Macy*s is decorated ground up, and coming from HI, it definitely feels like Christmas! They also have an ice skating rink, but we didn't get a chance to go since I was more excited for the shopping nearby!

We grabbed some slices of pizza and just sat here to enjoy the City. 

We scored parking on the street the first night we stopped by for a quick look. There's also parking located in the garage which is quite expensive (we spent $30 for a couple of hours or so).
author: Sammie T.

description:
busy. loud. smells like piss. you WILL be constantly haggled by bums and pushed around by tourists.BUT this is a good spot if you wanna blow some cash and shop (at stores that are EVERYWHERE else in the country as well)

good central location to stay in so you can take the muni, cable cars, or buses to BETTER areas of SF but other than that it blows.

okay okay so its not that bad...i just wouldnt want to spend more than an hour here at a time.
author: Kiana C.

description:
Living in Berkeley makes me grateful for anything that resembles civilization/city-life.  I love the hustle and bustle of this area and there's always something interesting to see.  

It's a great place to come and snap pictures (if you're into that).
author: Christine B.

description: More often than not this place is full of beggars and homeless people, and the grass stinks of urine from people and dogs pissing everywhere. One time I saw 2 homeless people under a blanket and their legs were uncovered and they were having sex as the man on top was humping away this was broad daylight in the afternoon. There has to be police and park presence to make this place safe and clean.
author: N A.

description: I love all the festivals and events here. Even went on a first date here. During the winter they put up a huge tree and ice ring. Really a great place to ppl watch.
author: nancy w.

description:
We went to the 18th annual Tree Lighting Ceremony in Union Square.  It was crowded at 4pm even though the event was for 6-7pm.  The Jersey Boys were doing a practice run so we were lucky to see them at 4pm.  

They were selling commemorative tree lighting pin for $10 to help the UCSF Children's Hospital for children w/ life-threatening illnesses & their families.

PG&E gave out FREE Greenlite LED 35 indoor-outdoor Xmas lights -Cool.

FREE Luna sample tea cakes were given out at the end: Vanilla Macadamia & Berry Pomegranate.

Starbucks were giving out FREE drinks - didn't get any.

At 6pm the crowds were huge..couldn't get close to the stage & we were crammed in like sardines standing & waiting for the show.  We couldn't see much.

The Trickster from KOOZA was there.  Jersey Boys performed, the SF Boys' Chorus performed, Santa gave a brief appearance.  Lights came on for the tree..then it was Crazy trying to get out.
author: Ann L.

description: I love Union Square!  It is my favorite place to catch some sun or take a break from shopping and doing errands, catch some entertainment on the stage, check out cultural festivals or art shows on weekends, grab something quick to drink or snack on at one of the corner cafes, get some half-price tickets for shows/theatre nearby, walk through on my way to the gym, a great place to people watch - and it's the best place to meet your friends because everyone knows where it is as it is so central!
author: Maile N.

description:
Nice park and wonderful atmosphere! 

Love the live music and art we saw today while on vacation. This city is amazing!!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Love the hustle and bustle of Union Square, reminds me of New York and Taiwan, minus a few street vendors.

This place is shopping central for all price ranges. Girls, I am excited to say they have the hugest Forever 21 here, 3 stories! Guys, sadly your section was not expanded, sorry.

I think its amazing that even when you're sitting and resting in the square, there's so much activity going on that you feel like you're not wasting your time sitting, but taking the time to enjoy every minute the city has to offer.
author: Hanna L.

description: Good place to chill and hang out with my newspaper and coffee, I need to fit in with the sophisticated people.
author: Jerry G.

description:
I feel very European when I am sitting here because there's almost no squares like these in the U.S.
Nice area and especially when there's a shade. 
Nice stores around and food. 
It's beautiful during christmas.
I usually sit here before I go to eat to my favourite Italian restaurant, 
«È Tutto Qua»! 
:D
author: Nadav M.

description:
It's a tourist trap for sure, but sometimes it's nice to pretend to be a tourist for a day and experience the hustle and bustle of this beautiful city.
I love the free shows that take there during the summer months.
author: Séamus C.

description: Lots of places to find cheaper drinks (water, soda and wine). Walgreens on every corner. Great location to stay since so close to cable cars and muni.  Get a day pass or 2-3 day pass for public transportation. Can use for muni and cable car. Easy to use. Might have to ask for directions. Most people friendly. There are even Union square tourist employees there to help. Great shopping. Close to great restaurants also within walking distance. A muni ride away from giant baseball stadium. Lots of homeless people though.
author: Janice K.

description:
Cool hangout spot.  During our visits to downtown San Francisco, we'll come here once in awhile.  It's nice to take a break here and just people watch.  It is in the "heart" of San Francisco.  Maybe that's why there are some Heart sculptures displayed.

Union Square is surrounded by everything!  There are plenty of restaurants, shops, hotels, etc. all around the area.  

To take a break from the hustle and bustle of the big city, Union Square is the perfect place to go to.
author: PatrickJ T.

description: USP is an open and compact park with more tile and concrete than grass, trees, and shrubs. It's a decent spot to soak up some rays, people-watch, or nosh on your take-out. Just be careful of the hovering pigeons, which will eat any crumb that falls from your sammie.
author: Derek N.

description: I believe that save the chronic panhandling, this is one California's finest and prettiest urban concrete parks. The term park can be innocently misleading. Union Square once a grassy knoll. The photos here on this site will show the transformation that is both liked and hated by locals and tourists alike. Seasonal ice skating and beautiful Christmas tree make this a fun place for kids and adults alike. On sunny days, this is a great place to relax for a tea or coffee during your visit to this city favorite.
author: Michael G.

description:
Union Square is sooo dope!  After going to a wedding near there we got to walk around the next morning and find places to eat.  There are definitely plenty of places that are cracking. 

The stores around here are HUGE.  From the huge Nike Town, Neiman Marcus, Macy's Saks Fifth, Tiffany's, Victoria's Secret, etc. 

I was so fascinated with the sculptured hearts that were displayed on each corner of Union Square.  They are so cool!  So I did some research and this is what it is:
Hearts in San Francisco began in 2004 as a fund raiser for the San Francisco General Hospital Foundation. Like the famous painted cows, the painted hearts -- created from uniform molds and painted by individual artists -- decorate the city in areas like Union Square, until they are auctioned off at a benefit for the charity. New hearts are unveiled each year.

This is such a cool idea!   I think Union Square was kept up really nice with the fresh grass and people just laying out basking in the sun.  One of the rare days when SF actually gets sunny and hot. 

The tour buses start here and looks like you can buy some passes.  They have a parking garage right here too.  Not sure how much it is. 

Also this year I will be running in my first Nike Women's half marathon and it starts at Union Square!  I will see you again oh beautiful one! Oh and during xmas time and the tree!?!? yes def gonna try to make it out.
author: Anya R.

description: Located in the heart of San Francisco, Union Square Park is very touristy but wasn't too ridiculously packed on a Saturday night. I do recall USP being a lot prettier five years ago during the holidays. Without the giant Christmas tree, ice skating rink, light strung buildings, and holiday cheer, USP is actually kind of boring to look at.
author: Ivy W.

description:
I love the park itself, though I'm a bigger fan of it when it isn't dumping busloads of tourists into it. I'm a tourist in San Francisco myself, but the sort of people that take the bus tours are the most nightmarish, self-indulgent people that I encountered in San Francisco. 

 That being said, I love sitting down to people watch in this park. Today I met an older italian gentleman who told me his story about being growing up in Italy and spending the last 50 years in San Francisco.  He told me that he went back to his small town in Italy recently after his wife passed away and couldn't wait to come back to San Francisco. He said that it wasn't because it had changed, but because he had changed.  We discussed the people that were in the park and I was sort of sad to have to leave to catch my flight.

 You can come to this park any day of the week and meet someone interesting. You may have to wade through groups of tour-lemmings in order to find someone like the gentleman I found today, but it's worth it.
author: Jeremy S.

description: One of the best parks in SF. It's located right next to Bart (Powell). It has the famous rotating hearts sculpture that is a must photo op. Malls, shopping and nice hotels surround it. The park is clean and has ample room to hangout. Events go on weekly here too. Great meeting point.
author: Chuck N.

description: A true site to see and spend time in.  Aside from the amount of tourists and homeless beggars it is still a wonderful place to sit and enjoy a good day.  Beautiful sights, great people watching, and in an amazing location.  Always events going on too, can be a lot of fun!
author: Lyndsey C.

description:
WARNING TO TOURISTS

There are people who are in "police type" uniforms, who will tell you you are getting a ticket for jaywalking, and then ask you to instead donate money to a charity. This is a scam. Do NOT give these people money. They have somehow gotten a license to "solicit", but there is nothing legal about the enterprise.

Also, if kids ask to support the Boys and Girls club, the Boys and Girls club NEVER do on street solicitations.

Union square is beautiful otherwise.
author: Tim N.

description:
Walk to the center of the square and just take a 360 view of what surrounds you.  AMAZING!

I walk by here daily and there's always something new to look at.  Big city feel, cool air blowing through, tons of people walking in every which direction, and it's actually a parking lot.  LOL...  For a long time, I didn't even know that.  HAaahahha...
author: Limzer L.

description: I cant believe some people rate here 5 stars...  here is why ,  there is not even one bathroom for people in that huge park, there is no water no where altho over 70 percent of earth is water....  plus Rats are everywhere jumping around so many of them.. and it is day and night.. really hard to believe...
author: Wolfy E.

description: This is a wonderful park area.  They have a little cafe where you can get some coffee and pastries.  There is also a great little bike rental place, if you wish to explore the city via bike.  The mornings are best - air is fresh and brisk.  Evenings are ok, but the homeless start coming out more at night.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
THE BAD: I must say, the only time I would ever be in this part of S.F. is if I am desperate or if I am dead. The amounts of people, are insane. You can barely move. The tourists are even more annoying than they are in Fisherman's Wharf. The Westfield Mall, Don't even get me started on that. (If you want a mall go out to Stone's Town). oh god "Stop the Insanity" Brings back some memories of Susan Powter. Oh how I miss her.  Run run run...unless you live to shop. Then again, maybe since I hate shopping.. Which brings me to the one good thing about this annoying part of SF

THE GOOD:
The union Square park: Yes! this is the only thing and I mean ONLY thing that saves this lousy area. The park is a great place to sit and people watch while connecting to Yelp Via Wifi so that I don't have to connect to my smart phone's network. The view of Macy's makes me want to throw up, but other than that, this is Union Square's only salvation in my book.
author: Damien K.

description: While a partisan of the South like me doesn't like anything named "Union Square" I have to admit that I do love this part of San Francisco.  While it's hemmed in by the signs of luxury department stores and hotels, the people and artists who often exhibit here are very real.  It's a great place to browse and explore, and as a tribute to effective public places - places that can uplift and relax in the midst of towering buildings - it's a great success.  Check it out.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Union Square has changed a lot over the years, but I think it's better now than it was when I was a kid.  It's cleaner and there are more trees and plants, for starters.

This is a great place for an outdoor lunch on nice days, though it can get crowded.

The best time to visit Union Square is December, when there are lovely decorations, an enormous Christmas Tree, a giant Menorah, and an ice stating rink.

There is a parking lot underneath the square, but it fills up quickly.  Best to take BART whenever possible!  Driving and parking in SF are notoriously difficult.
author: Raina S.

description:
What happened to the grassy knoll, eh?  Why did SF make Union Square into a concrete jungle?  Where will the Christmas Tree be installed this Christmas, eh?  The hearts on the entrance steps are cool, but kitchy . . . it's like LA sporting their angels, while SF has hearts, I guess.

Sure, it is nice to have that humungous statue commemorating WWII Filipinos in the middle of Union Square, but the ambiance was ruined.  My childhood memories of running on the grass are gone.  What's with that coffee & tea cafe at Union Square?

Commercialism has consumed Union Square!  I'm gonna cry now . . . 

O=:-(
author: Shirley M. J.

description: Central location for shopping and eats but the "local color" seem to all have the same speech, hoping to score a dollar or two....keep your bags zipped and close to you as they stand VERY close,  trying to get into your bag!
author: Gina B.

description:
I find myself gravitating towards, or possibly more accurately, orbiting around, Union Square most every time I trek across the bridge, despite the fact that it's not my favorite place to be when I'm making the effort. There are more serene, picturesque and generally more pleasant places to be in San Francisco; there's more variety of cultural cuisines elsewhere, for much less money. Still, I end up here more often than not.

Sometimes it's because a friend has visited SF, as has happened several times in the last couple years, and they wind up getting a room in a Union Square hotel. Other times it's for the nightlife and all that entails - Ruby Skye, e.g., with it's occasional headliners of house, electronica, etc etc.

Lately I've driven there on almost auto-pilot mode, favoring the stout parking garage very near the Powell Street cable car origin. I've found several places that have very decent food and beer specials; Foley's Irish Pub on the southwest corner comes to mind (though fear for your appetite if it's a busy Friday evening, and more so for your ears as it's thunderously loud when full). Across from Infusion Lounge, to its west, is a little yakitori place that has a nice selection of sake and a very trendy, quiet atmosphere with huge windows from which you can people-watch during conversational lulls, assuming you're not alone.

To the East End of the Square: fancy pants stores galore, including my personal favorite, a GUESS flagship store (the basement being entirely devoted to Men's Wear! Yes I do get excited enough to use an exclamation point.). For some reason the streets on this side seem almost entirely devoid of homeless. There's a cool little street that's blocked off to all traffic except that on foot which has another favorite store of mine, the ridiculously over-priced Sur la Table gourmet cooking store (rumor is, I see, that this location is closed? Anyway.), as well as a cute cafe that spills itself onto the vehicle-less street.

North by northeast from the Square you'll find yourself soon enough at the grand entrance to Chinatown, a place that I have yet to brave alone. Go two steps further west of Foley's and you'll be in the mix, as it were: the Tenderloin (q.v., on your own dime, if you don't know; there are some ultra cool spots to visit though so don't let the smell, sights and sounds scare you off too quickly . . . .). South from the Square gets you directly into a huge indoor mall with several repeats of the big retailers (another GUESS store? Why thank you!).

Many people mention the people-watching. It is all that and more. Especially in the summer, and you're one (like moi) that likes to see painfully beautiful women walking in every direction at once, literally so many that one can't remember from one corner to the next which was most lovely. A few streets of this and I'm ready to drown my sorrows; hello Foley's, missed you . . . .
author: Todd C.

description: Union Square is the epicenter of shopping & culture in San Francisco.  It's a few blocks from the Apple store, Burberry, Prada, and Sephora.  It's right next to Macys, Victoria's Secret, Tiffany & Co. and Niketown.  It's also surrounded by art galleries, fabulous restaurants, and theaters.  There are steps to sit on, people to see, places to rest your soul.  Crowds congregate, gawk, and disperse.  People come and go.  It's easily accessible by public transportation.  It's literally a hubbub, day and night.  There are street performers throughout the day.  There are events that take place at the Square.  I've stayed nearby Union Square twice now and it's such a cool place to be at in San Francisco.  It's all a girl could ask for and more!
author: Trina D.

description:
So pretty! I love that sometimes (during holidays) Union Square gets decorated & has tables/open seating for people to sit and enjoy the view/weather. Beautiful!

Also...anyone notice that the designs on the hearts change?
author: Jennifer J.

description:
"I left my heart...in San Francisco...high on the hill, it calls to me...." -Tony Bennet.  Love this place, such a center of tourist and shopping.  A sea of people and cars, it is chaos with delight. I was here with the gf and we love the decorated heart statue, so cheesy, so romantic.  Perfect in the midst of busy Union Square.

The only sad note, when I was younger, FAO Schwarz used to be around the corner, I think.  Times have change, but Union Square still radiates her charm and continues to be a goodwill ambassador to the city by the bay.

Kiss Kiss..
author: Kevin B.

description:
I love Union Sq, there is always something going on! In my time here I have 

- Gazing at the beautiful Christmas tree
- Watched a small children ice dancing competition
- Witnessed a middle aged Rollerblade meet up group show off its skills
- Stumbled across an MJ flash mob performance
- Took part in a secret street game at Easter time
- and so much more

Union Sq never fails to entertain me
author: Chris M.

description:
What a nice little divergence from skyscrapers.  Yes, while hiking around downtown, I cut through this square and found many others with the same idea....well, they weren't short cutting, I found people chatting, suntanning, strutting around in costumes (it was Halloween), and dining outside.  I also found lots of red tape....well, maybe it was yellow tape....whatever tape it was, there was construction going on.  

But yeah, if you plan it just right (when the sun towers over you, between sky scrapers, and showers you with light), then you can enjoy a nice vacation from the gloom of gray, cold, metallic city life at this nice Square.
author: Corey G.

description:
It was ok.  Maybe because it was rainy and there was a group of noisy picketers in front of the Westin that there weren't that many people hanging out there.

I can imagine that it would be better without said issues.

But... until I experience it, this is my review.  I'll update later if I ever go back. :)
author: Jessica P.

description:
Loved the atmosphere and all the spring blooms!  Artists set up and show there work, and a tasty little Italian bistro makes it easy to sip your favorite vino and browse local art. 
Great place to relax, people-watch, rent a bike, or simply breathe in the fresh air in the heart of downtown.
author: Prebble R.

description:
Its that time of year again!!  Ice skating in the park!  people gathered around the huge Christmas tree in the square and hoards of people getter their last minute shopping done.

If you missed the Santa Con kick off in Union Square last Saturday because of the rain and the holiday spirit has not taken hold of you yet a nice stroll through Union Square at dusk might do the trick!  Its beautiful this time of year and the usual city noise is almost drowned out by the sounds of the holidays...
author: Antoine V.

description:
Shopping shopping shopping - all around a piece of green on top of a parking lot.
Throw in a statue in the center on top and you got yourself a union square!
author: Nick L.

description: Love this place! Beside it being busy it was nice seeing people from all around the world. Today was a beautiful day.
author: Tim V.

description:
I like coming here to visit the hustle and bustle of San Francisco.

There's always something going on at Union Square so a visit is a must.
author: Vira P.

description: A beautiful outdoor park/space in downtown SF.  Although there was a cold wind, the sun was out and the park was full of people on the Saturday morning we walked by.  All in all, a beautiful spot in a great city.  I also thought the underground parking here was a great idea.
author: Andreas H.

description:
A great place to do some PREMIUM people watching!!! 
This is a tourist must stop, so there is always a bunch of people in the square, walking, sitting, lounging... to my surprise it is rarely has a crowded feel... even though there are hundreds of people around. 

This square hosts some random events, music, and art showcases, which is cool if you come by on those days. At Christmas time they display an AWESOME tree!!! And they have ice skating! 

Overall its a nice place to sit back with some take out or a coffee, get a bit of sunshine and enjoy the beauty of SF!
author: Jennifer D.

description: I think it's a typical tourist spot, but it's a great place to meet up with your friends and family, they also have a cafe on Stockton side and Powell side so you can people watch. Occasionally they have events in the center, sometimes it would be Hermes demonstrating their artisanal crafts, Nike exhibit for their Nike Women's Marathon, Currently Marc Jacobs has some installation going on there.
author: Yuki A.

description: Haven't been to Union Square in quite some time. I can tell they did some remodeling. We were there this past weekend for the ice skating rink opening. It was a lot of fun. We sat at the cafe there as well. Only negative is there are a lot of homeless people in the area, but poor people are everywhere in the City.
author: Danny N.

description: One of the nicest places in San Francisco, assuming you can afford to stay in the better hotels around the square.  There's lots of restaurants of just about all cuisines and prices.  The shopping is on the higher end, though lots of chains.  The area is sort of touristy but never seems to be too crowded.
author: Jason G.

description:
San Francisco got it right and as for Pershing Square in Los Angeles... well... I'll leave a review about Pershing Square later ...

Union Square gives you a real big city feel like Chicago or New York.  The square is inviting, clean will full of art and incredible shopping and dining options.  

I visit Union Square every time I visit the city.  It definitely gets 5 stars from me.
author: George B.

description: Surrounded by tons of high-end luxury shops and often hosting a cultural event, this very very conveniently located square just 1 block from Market Street truly is 1 of the centres of the city.
author: Richard C.

description: An oasis within an oasis.  A location to absorb SF's rare sunny rays.  Lovely.
author: Mel G.

description: A quick BART (Bay Area Rapid Transit) ride away, Union Square is a cultural hub of northern California. Eclectic street performers, talented musicians diverse crowd--it is definitely a spot you don't want to miss out on. It's great for shopping, people watching, or a nice morning, mid-day, and/or evening walk.
author: Ryan A.

description: I LOVE Union Square! On sunny days it's nice to just sit there and observe busy downtown. When you're done observing you can just walk across the street for a bite and then shop! =)
author: Teresa C.

description:
Great place to sit and people watch while taking in the sun (on those days its there). 
Gotta love the Christmas tree & ice skate rank during the Holiday seasons.
author: Helen D.

description: Always love coming here at the holidays. It is so festive with the tree and the Ice Skaing Rink. Usually crowded, but that adds to the fun and feeling of the holidays.
author: Travis H.

description:
Had a wonderful view of this beautiful square during our stay in SF.

They had great etchings in the granite surrounding the Square that really told you the history of the city and Union Square which was great. 

Friday nights is rollerblader night, cool cause they all had on flashing lights and it was like a mini light show while they were there!

Also had a pretty neat art show which showed sculptures. paintings and photographs from various artists. I great place to check out when you are in that part of SF!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I enjoy Union Square for the hustle and bustle of it all. There are a million people walking around coming and going from restaurants and shops. All trying to catch the next crosswalk.

I enjoy taking a seat on the steps amongst the tall buildings and just people watch . It is great to see the unique people of SF enter your life one moment and be gone the next..

Once wrapping up lunch and there are a few minutes left, then there are the dozens upon dozens shops in the area to take a breather and peruse around killing the last few minutes of a lunch break
author: Richard K.

description:
One of the top places in San Francisco. 

Ice skating happens here, there are iconic hotels and stores surrounding this place and it was featured in Monk! Plus some other movies.

Its always nice to walk around this place and they have a parking garage underneath so utilize that when you go shopping.
author: Tim M.

description:
Although Union Square is especially sparkly and pretty around the holidays, I love it year-round.  Whenever I really want to feel like I'm a part of the magic that is San Francisco (and don't have my car), I come here.  Just walking around, smirking at the tourists wearing their shorts and recently purchased "SF" fleece sweatshirts, deciding which store I want to throw my money at, hearing the cable car go by...that's San Francisco.

Union Square in San Francisco is what Newbury Street is in Boston or Michigan Ave is in Chicago to me.  Except with less people trying to cross the street (that's an entirely different review).

Although I didn't manage to go ice skating this year (stupid foot), I can't think of a better place to try to push over those who REALLY can't skate.  

Although there is a undercurrent of insanity within the hustle and bustle, I feel at peace here.  Or maybe it's because it was the 2nd day of my 2 week vacation...
author: Pam S.

description:
Everybody's waiting for the man with the bag...

No, I'm not talking about the "man bag" of Friends fame.  I'm talking about Santa.  Only 9 more days until Santa does his thing!

Whenever I see decorated Christmas trees I feel all warm and happy inside.  I wish I was a little girl again.  I loved that feeling of excitement and anticipation.  A time when I could not wait to open my gifts from my family and Santa.  

My family has spent one weekend every holiday season in SF, ever since I can remember.  I always loved to see the ginormous Christmas tree in Union Square.  I still do.  All of the sparkling lights and ornaments.  Breathtaking...especially at night.

Christmas is here again!
author: Karen G.

description:
Pretty clean and great area for events.
I'm glad they have this area for things like  that.

When they have the Xmas tree up, it's really a symbol of the Price and Joy of all SFers and Americans.... its a great feeling during the holidays.
author: Calvin C.

description:
Union Square is just what it sounds like. It's literally a 'square' in the middle of a very busy shopping area in San Francisco. At each corner, there is a huge sculptured heart that is auctioned off annually for a charity. It is a must see for tourists. 

I came here for part of my Valentine's date and it was so much fun. Not only were the shopping stores in the area humongous, but they had a very large selection of high-end stores to choose from too. I enjoyed walking around and looking at what San Francisco had to offer, aside from the Golden Gate Bridge. People watching is always fun too! I could probably walk around this area for a week and still not be able to cover everything!
author: Lien T.

description: The park has gotten much cleaner than before. You see staff and security all over the place. No more homelessness. Most importantly, the holiday season there gets a lot of attention when the weather is right and the Ice rink is operating. Good Job city of SF
author: Shadi K.

description: great place to people watch! whenever we get a chance to drive into the city, i love coming to union square... not just for the shopping or restaurants, but for the people.... pop a squat and just observe... take in the city... take in the life... christmas time is absolutely beautiful! and the addition of the ice skating rink makes me even more enjoyable to people watch!
author: Gina M.

description: Ground zero for luxury retail in SF.
author: Patrick H.

description: One of my favorite spots in the city to linger and just people watch.  Seems like it's always sunny there, so pull up a chair or sit on a step and just relax.  Always a mix of locals and tourist mulling around.  Great spot in SF.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Something's always happening in the square, whether it's a concert, promotion, demonstration, or festival, I can assure you that you won't be bored. Perfect place for people watching, as being in the center of the shopping area seems to advocate for diversity like no other. Grab a cup of coffee, a book, magazine, or a friend, and enjoy all that there is to enjoy in clean public space.

Christmas time is one of the best times to stop by, with an ice skating rink, giant Christmas tree... It's one of the things I miss the most about San Francisco.

San Francisco is home to some very unique and outrageous people, and you really can't help but fall in love with it. Thousands of people walk through Union Square a day, and who knows? Maybe you'll bump into someone you know. Or someone you don't know... But would like to get to know. ;)

If the stage isn't being occupied, GO FOR IT. There's never a better place or time for an impromptu Union Square performance.
author: Colleen M.

description: A beautiful park in the middle of sprawling downtown San Francisco. Conveniently located a few blocked from the Bart and the turn around point for the cable cars, it is a must see attraction in the area. It's fun to take a blow off and just relax and listen to the sounds of the city.
author: Joey B.

description:
Is it just me or does anyone miss the old design? Yet as each year passes I become more accustomed and happy with this one. A bit more cement than I like, less place to chill out in. Jamiroquai could never have given a free concert in the new layout. Which was AMAZING!
I LOVE the 1/2 price ticket booth by See's Candy. A great to know for tickets that day at a discount. I am not impressed with Rully's. The stores nearby are quite great and the SFC is just a few blocks away. Why do they try to cram an ice skating rink in during the winter I do not know. It makes it way too crowded and their has always been a rink in Embarcadero. 
Yet they Jazz it up with shows of art and small music. They built a mini stage/platform. Keep it well maintained, almost a prissy feel... kinda perfect for tourist. You will feel quite posh hanging out here.
author: Natasha M.

description:
If you go some creepy guy will probably give you a sticker and assume you're a tourist. 

At least that's what always seems to happen to me.
author: Murphy O.

description:
What can be said about Union Square that has not already been said?

Except how incredibly amazing it is!  

You can sit, shop, eat, people watch, and more.
author: Kevin W.

description:
This is a great people watching spot.  You only need to sit and watch for 15-30 minutes and I swear you will see the greatest variety of people.

My hubby and I saw people of different ages, races, heights, weights, dress styles, walking styles, moods,etc. 

  There was one elderly Chinese man wearing a Superman tee shirt.  There were women who looked like they stepped out of a time machine from the 50's---dressed up with gloves!  There were babies less than a month old.  There were grandparents with grand kids.  Huge groups of friends.  Lots of tweens and teens checking each other out.

My personal favorite was watching and listening to the families who were speaking foreign languages.  Although I couldn't even figure out what language they were speaking, I could easily translate what they were "probably" saying by their body language and tones of voice.

Scenario #1:
Husband to wife: Did you have to buy so much stuff?
Wife:  Hey, I'm on vacation. I had to get gifts for everyone.
Husband:  Then why am I carrying all YOUR bags?

Scenario # 2:
Kid:  I am really hungry, I want to eat now!
Mom: No way!  I asked you at least 10 times and you said, "No."
Kid:  Nooooooooooooooo, I want food now!


Scenario # 3:

Woman:  There sure are a lot of strange people in this town. They are pretty scary looking!
Friend:  Don't be so paranoid!  

Scenario #4:

Woman (pointing to me):  Do you think she speaks XXXXX ?
I'm not sure she even speaks English!

Other Woman:  I don't know what she is.  Let's ask someone else.






And so forth......


Anyway,  Union Square is a lively place where people and pigeons are having fun or at least trying to have fun.

Plus they have a Sees Candy store there--only preboxed items , but you can still get their candy bars.
author: Rinky N.

description:
I think this is San Francisco's equivalant of a giant outdoor mall. Shops Everywhere. the main square has so many performers and artists its pretty cool. 
We visited during Christmas so they had a giant tree lit up as well as an Ice skating rink out. 

the Bad
Parking in a city is horrible. We ended up paying about 14 bucks for 2 hours parking. We come from L.A though so paying for parking is ridiculous or too expensive. 
- Not alot of bathrooms. At least non that I saw. Ended up pretending to shop at Nike store to use their restroom which was on the top floor. 5 floors. 

The Good
Very Nice looking and touristy area. Lots of activity and you actually feel like you are in a city. We saw people playing bagpipes. We saw Carol Singers. We saw a small Orchestra. We saw people playing the blues on the street.
author: Zan O.

description: Near lots of shopping, lots of restaurants, and there's almost always something going on at Union Square on the weekends! Bonus points for being so close to BART!
author: Leana L.

description: A GREAT PLACE TO PEOPLE WATCH! There is always a variety of people taking advantage of the beautiful space. Needing time to kill, a friend and I found some seats here at Union Square. Since the Christmas tree and the ice skating rink was no longer there from winter, there was a ton of open space. In just the hour I was at Union Square today I saw two elderly women doing laps around the square, a couple exchanging Valentine's gifts, and three dancers filming a dance video. But the cutest thing I witnessed was a man controlling a remote control car and chasing any little child in the vicinity with it. All the kids loved being chased, and over time there were about twelve different kids all playing together with this remote controlled car. Little tubby toddlers chasing a car is the cutest thing everrr!
author: Kevin Joseph A.

description: I love San Francisco so much. I call it the Emerald City and have been coming here since 2012. I have a few old friends that live here, and my aunt and uncle live in Oakland. I think it's a magical city - it's big, sexy and very 'cosmo' with a small-town feel.
author: Khoa K T.

description:
Complete chaos..but I love it nonetheless.

Once you actually make it to union square and bypass all of the traffic and parking issues (note: you can park in the structure directly in front of Macy's), it just makes you smile! This is especially true for us from the suburbs that get so thrilled by coming to Union Square and finally feeling the excitement of city life. I really love Union Square during the holidays with the tree, skating rink, a sense of excitement/happiness in the air..what more do you need..other than, money, of course to spend at the stores nearby ;)

There is a nice litte cafe area up at the top of the square. Stores surround it, and a huge Westfield shopping mall is a block away. 

If you come prepared for the huge mobs of people (mostly tourists), long lines, and homeless people that lurk on many city streets.. you will probably have a good day at Union Square.
author: A L.

description:
Since being remodeled a few years back, Union Square has become a much more inviting place.  With nicer seats, grassy areas, and free performances, what's not to love/  

During the day, the sun shine so brightly over the square and tourists sit side by side with business people enjoying a break from their busy day.  

On any given day, you might find a Ben and Jerry's booth giving out scoops of free ice cream, a visiting band performing their favorite numbers, or a runway showing off anything from art, to the latest fashions, to the exotic erotic.

On my most recent visit there, I came across a bunch of teenagers in the midst of a scavenger hunt.  They needed someone to ride piggyback across the street.  I couldn't help but volunteer.  Oh how I love scavenger hunts!
author: Teri C.

description:
This is a great place to come hang out if you live in the city--or if you're just visiting and you want to tell your friends back in Wisconsin that you ate lunch in Union Square!

BUT we have one issue.. I'm part of the Bay Area Flash Mob group (Find us on facebook!) and the other day was the second time I've performed here. Both times we've have troubles with security.
Really?? Do you REALLY not want awesome stuff like flash mobs to happen here? Random exciting unexpected moments like these are what make the city such an incredible place to live/visit! The people who got to see our MJ dance medley were positively thrilled (no pun intended)! Why deprive people of excitement, Union Square security? Freedom of speech, man! Freedom of DANCE!!
author: Ashley W.
