description: Too many people. The first five minutes i was here, there was boat tour bus that crashed into a car. Pedestrians walk whenever they want, same with the drivers.
author: Heidi F.

description:
This is such a great use of land in the Downtown area. During my short vacation I noticed that its used as a public art exhibit, resting spot for tired shoppers and lunch spot for Downtown workers. 

They've designed the layout in a way which allows for large standing crowds and exhibits but they've also designed built-in steps and chairs into the Square to allow people the ability to relax in the sun.
author: Garran C.

description:
When my folks lived here in the 1970's Union Square was the meeting point for friends and family before going off on City adventures.  

On May 12, 2010 I proposed in front of the Dewey Monument.

Needless to say, Union Square is a special place.
author: Jordan P.

description: Located in the heart of downtown SF.  A great place to chill and people watch when weather permits.  My favorite time to go here with my family is during the holidays when the Christmas tree is up, watching people ice skating and sipping on Starbucks.  It has become a family tradition. :)
author: Sheila M.

description:
Union square has almost any type of store you can image.  Shoes, clothes, food, China Town.

The cheapest parking garage I found so far is the Ellis and O'farell parking garage but if anyone knows of a cheaper one, please hit me up and let me know.

The only thing I hate about Union Square is some parts smell like pee and once I got tricked by a homeless woman into buying her some burger king.  I didn't mind buying her some burger king but when we got inside she tried to throw on extra pickles, meat, a bun, and a side of onion rings or curly fries (whichever one they serve).  I was like, "nu-uh, I ain't got enough extra cash for all that, we agreed to just a meal."
author: James N.

description:
Complete chaos..but I love it nonetheless.

Once you actually make it to union square and bypass all of the traffic and parking issues (note: you can park in the structure directly in front of Macy's), it just makes you smile! This is especially true for us from the suburbs that get so thrilled by coming to Union Square and finally feeling the excitement of city life. I really love Union Square during the holidays with the tree, skating rink, a sense of excitement/happiness in the air..what more do you need..other than, money, of course to spend at the stores nearby ;)

There is a nice litte cafe area up at the top of the square. Stores surround it, and a huge Westfield shopping mall is a block away. 

If you come prepared for the huge mobs of people (mostly tourists), long lines, and homeless people that lurk on many city streets.. you will probably have a good day at Union Square.
author: Lena A.

description: Loved this park! It is perfect for enjoying a glass of wine and people watching at the little cafe. I can spend hours here.
author: Jeralyn M.

description:
It's a good spot for locals to meet downtown, and really the only place to sit with a cup of coffee or a sandwich in the whole downtown area. 

It seems to be a good spot for tourists to take a pit stop and relax, but beware of the bums. DON'T give them anything, they are like stray cats because of the tourists giving them money there.
author: Mafia M.

description: Great for people watching, taking a break from shopping.  Grab a coffee at peet's on Geary or at nordstrom and just kick back and enjoy the free wifi, wave at the duck boats and sightseeing buses, and soak up the sun.  Yeah, there are panhandlers and guys drinking 40's but if you say no they go away with no fuss.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Shopping + People Watching + Music + Human Billboards = FUN.

Street parking is near impossible, so we usually end up in the parking garage. It's $3.50 for less than an hour, $7.00 for 1-2 hours, $10.50 for 2-3 hours.. if you're planning on parking for longer, the rates are found here: http://www.unionsquareshop.com/parking.html
author: Asha S.

description: I'm not the trendy type. I'm not the high-end fashion type. I'm not impressed with the posh. Union Square is surrounded by The Posh...but I still love it. This is the heart of San Francisco's Shopping District: Macy's, Saks Fifth Avenue, Tiffany & Co., Neiman Marcus, you name it! Not enough greenery for me to call it an oasis though. I think that may have been the original intent for the space over a century ago, but they've refinished it now to cater more to events and such. The space is utilized well. On any given day, there are art vendors setting up shop, free musical performances, dancing lessons, theater, and promotion crews giving out freebies and samples. Even though we don't have noticeable seasons, during the "winter" time, the space hosts a small ice skating rink. The space is sometimes rented out for private parties. All good! Spend money in my city!!!
author: Helen L.

description: Cool park.  Nice place to congregate when in Nob Hill.  The Dewey Monument plus palm trees is a combo that really works.
author: Alf O.

description:
If you were to ask me to rate this place 15 years ago I would've given it zero stars.  But its 2010 and within the past 10 years the city and county of SF finally decided to spend some serious moolah to beautify this place.

More security, artwork, benches to sit, some greenery, heck it actually feels like a safe place to hang out by yourself and enjoy some people watching.  I just wish I had the time to actually take on this activity =P

Well I was suppose to meet my friend Jenny here for the tree lighting ceremony on Nov 26th but my co-worker wouldnt switch shift with me so I had to cancel on her.  It wasnt cool of me but I made sure I would make it up to her the following week.

Well I made it to union square AFTER the tree was lit.  I was overwhelmed by the amount people who showed up for the tree lighting.  They basically managed to shut down Stockton street for 30 minutes.  

This place is cool because there's also a stage where you'll sometimes see free performances or events.  A great place to chill out after a long day of shopping.  If the Christmas tree doesnt put you in the holiday spirit then I think there's something wrong with you.  You can definitely feel the energy more so during the holiday season.
author: Sun T.

description: During the Holiday season,Union Square is a nice park/place to have a cup of cocoa with your love one's on a cold night.
author: Matt G.

description: Ice skating at its best. Only fell two dozen times...... The surrounding buildings and the whole Christmas theme is bad ass! If you get a chance hit this place up. Mike out!
author: Michael T.

description: I love coming here anytime of year, but especially during Christmas time when the giant tree is all lit up and Macy's has all their pretty reefs on the windows. No matter when you come here there is always something to do or something to see. There is an endless array of shops everywhere you look, and so many places to eat. I have been coming here for a few years now and it is one of my favorite places to visit when I am in San Francisco!
author: Diana L.

description:
I'm always in the area shopping. For shopping it's alright. Surrounded by the boutiques for ballers. That I am not (yet)! 

During Christmas time, tree lighting ceremony and an ice skating rink. Tree lighting was interesting, one of those go to once and never again type of deals. The skating rink, I'd never go to just because the ice looks like crap and I'm picky about my ice. 

Normally you can always find the hearts of SF at the corners. I think they change from time to time? 

What bugs me about the park is the hobos sitting around, but it is SF after all. Somehow still surprises me that they'd all be huddling up in such a touristy area. But I'm sure that's what they're after. The tourists' change. 

For me, the park itself is more of a place I pass through rather than linger.
author: Constance C.

description: Its a cool little park whole area is neat. walked in to the little cafe, did not get anything but staff was pretty cool about looking around and was very polite.
author: Shane A.

description:
Great place to go when you have that hankering to be a tourist again. And hey, it's where the mother of all Macy's exists!

I require that you also visit LUSH on Powell just off Geary at Union Square.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
I love San Fran and I love Union Square. 

But,be weary of the bums, I'll tell you a quick story.

My fiance an I were eating breakfast and drinking coffee at the cafe and a sad little old homeless lady came up to him and in a soft voice asked for some change. This lady was like 2 inches away from his face and continued to beg, my fiance kept politely rejecting. Well, she got pissed, she screamed FU in his face and then walked away and began to throw chairs. Needles to say the bums are a little unstable...
author: Ashley M.

description:
This square is located right in the heart of downtown! Union square has come a long way from what I remember back in the early 90s. I grew up living in the tenderloin neighborhood and walk by union square almost daily after school. From my childhood memories, this use to be a place full of homeless sleeping on the benches and pigeons every where and their poop all over the places. 

They had under gone major constructions and had gave this neighborhood gem a new look. I work right around the corner from union square and I come here to get some quick sun fix on a nice warm San Francisco day! 

If anyone is visiting San Francisco, you  must stop by union square and have a cup of coffee at their mini cafe. 

It's a great place to people watch also because it's full of different types on people. :)
author: Jenny G.

description: Union Square Park is awesome!  It's great any time of day.  I suppose that's why it is so busy all the time.
author: Michael L.

description:
I didn't get a chance to explore every shop, boutique, or sights of Union Square.  It was a bit overwhelming for my first time but I'll surely be back to experience it again.  

Be prepared to do a lot of walking!!!
author: Celin S.

description:
After visiting the Union Square park in NY one can only try to compare the two and despite having the same name, both are unique and special to the locals. I remember enjoying union square more back when there was more grass and less concrete. Although it underwent new renovations for several years and has a nicer appearance with a stage and all, I can't help but miss the old and the familiar.

Union Square SF like it's NY cousin is a great tourist trap, next to plenty of shopping, high end designer stores and fine dining. It's where all the action lies, all the traffic and parking tickets happen, not to mention where most of the cities revenue comes from and all the yuppies work. Still, it's close to several bus lines, provides easy access to all the essentials and a place for young and old alike to shop, drink and be merry till they drop. 

And since the city is my home, it will always hold a special place in my heart not to mention a very big hole in my wallet.
author: Petra S.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF!! Everyone should come here - both locals and tourists alike. In the winter they have an ice skating rink. The rest of the year they have occasional events in the square. There are tables to take food and eat at. Great place to come sit down and chat after grabbing coffee. Good meeting place too.

Favorite thing about the park? The artist hearts on the corners that they periodically change out! Always fun to see which new ones they'll put up.
author: Brad Y.

description:
Great spot to come and people watch. Yesterday was the Indonesian Independence Day celebration so there was a parade and show. Very nice. We received some gifts from one of the vendors and my daughter loved that. 

Can't wait to see what is going on there today.
author: Lee R.

description: People watch. Best place. Love it. They even have events right smack in the middle. Art or music. It's amazing, just to see young and old and all kinds of different people dancing and enjoying the music and all the surroundings. I must say, it was a lovely day!
author: Sherryl Z.

description: Pretty park in SF.  I love all the shopping around it too :) I love it here during the holidays.  I think it is Robert Aitken who did the Goddess of victory but I love that statue!  Great photo spot for friends and family when they come to visit.
author: Evan G.

description: San Francisco would be SO much better if there were no homeless people. I walked by here the other day and there was a homeless lady shooting up in the doorway of one of the shops, facing the sidewalk/street, kitty corner to the park. This was at 7pm with hundreds of people walking by right by her and there she was with a hypodermic needle hanging out of her arm and half asleep. It was crazy and weird. There are no bathrooms for these people to use so they urinate (and defacate) right on the street or in the doorways to most of these businesses. The smell is absolutely horrible and gross. They will also constantly ask you for money. Some of them are aggressive and will get in your face. On a couple separate occasions, I gave a couple people a dollar and they all said ok, but do you have 4 more or can I have more. One big black homeless guy asked me if I had any money to give him and when I said no, sorry I don't, he walked right next to me for a while and had his face almost up against my ear and said, I really need some money man. That time I honestly thought I was going to get beat up and hurt by this homeless guy. Something needs to be done about these people. San Francisco is a beautiful and very expensive city to live in and it is not ok for them to be here anymore. San Francisco city councel, FIND A WAY TO GET RID OF THESE PEOPLE NOW!!
author: Rick M.

description: You can say you've been to SF without a visit to Union Square. In the Heart of SF, lots of Shopping, Restaurants, Bars... You cant miss the Cable Cars, MUNI Street Cars and the famous GANG "Pigeons"... they are all over the place so take cover... Lots of things going on. A place that you will never get bored. You just cant simply dislike Union Square.
author: Diego V.

description: So much to do and so much to see! The shopping is perfection, the streets are adorable, and the restaurants are memorable! Wander the streets for a cute date, come here on vacation with your family, stop by for some solo shopping- anything goes in the center of SF!
author: Camellia S.

description:
It's always nice to just sit and people watch here. Boredom is definitely not something that is found in this area, where occasional art displays and jazz bands can be seen and heard.
http://images18.fotki.com/v345/photos/3/32745/657170/CIMG0768-vi.jpg
I spent the afternoon of my day off here and was curious to see if there was any free WiFi around. Lo and behold, there was. The signal even reaches up to the 3rd floor of Macy's cafe. Check out the photos I submitted in the photos section.
author: Michelle G.

description: Always love shopping here. Love the crowds, the atmosphere, the restaurants, the energy. And of course, the cable cars. Love sipping a cappuccino on the corner and people-watching. And I love the weather. I love SAN FRANCISCO!!!
author: Sharon H.

description: First time here was around x'mas time.  It was so pretty and x'masy!!!  Definitely come here and check it out!!!
author: Tiffany H.

description: Beautiful central location in San Francisco. The heart of the city.
author: Wendy P.

description:
How can you not love Union Square.

I live in the TenderNob and work in the Fidi.  So I am constantly walking by/through Union Square.  I love to go on walks and have this be a meeting point a stopping point to sit and people watch.

Love to come and watch people EAT SHIT on the ice skating rink during the winter.  Yes it might make me a bad person, but at least I'm enjoying myself.

Althgouh it does REALLY bother me when hold grips of tourist just stand in th emiddle of the sidewalk.  GET OUT OF THE WAY YOU ROAD BLOCKS!  

Can't you see I'm walking here?!?!
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Such a great place to take a break in the city. The park is in the heart of the city where all the action happens.  Close to the major shopping areas, clean, good vibes.  

There is a little cafe where you can grab something for convenience. A good hang out spot to meet up with friends and enjoy and day.
author: Shad B.

description:
Come here for the sightseeing, people watching, and of course - shopping. 

its a clean and safe place with plenty of shopping to fulfill the capitalist or shopaholic in all of us. In the middle when i went there was a huge open air artist market with original artwork and sculptures. 

Lots of restaurants and a HUGE MACY's store. It was packed with tourists.
author: Amit K.

description:
I remember when Union Square was part of the skateboarding Mecca that SF became in the 90s. Now, not so much. A few million dollars and some palm trees later and badda bing! A *new* Union Square.

I like this incarnation of Union Square. The aforementioned palm trees are a nice "California" touch, albeit a little more SoCal than Nor ... The plaza area is nice and open, and the stepped design is a good use of the space and grade.

The little coffee joints that you can sit on the square and enjoy your coffee at are a great addition. Nothing beats a nice warm morning cup of coffee here on a Sunday in the spring.
author: Wes T.

description:
Mobs of shoppers + salsa\latin band + lots of places to shop = I'll take wifey here again

Nice clean place, I felt safe, can be romantic at night.

That's it.
author: Christopher P.

description: If you're even in San Francisco, this is definitely a sight to see!!! It's beautiful here.  I stayed at a hotel in Union Square and just had a blast in the area.  If you're looking for shopping options, this is also a wonderful place to visit.
author: Nora F.

description: Union Square - after my experience on Friday - I dislike you even more than ever.  In the last year, all the street parking has been turned to white, yellow or red zones for like a 3 block radius and there's basically NO motorcycle parking.  So on the unfortunate day that I decide to go into SF on my motorcycle to do some errands before my dentist appointment - the weather is nice and I cannot find a place to park for half an hour - then I have to park SIX blocks away and walk in all my freaking gear meant to keep me warm while going over the bridge - and I get all hot and sweaty and aggravated - the garages that do take motorcycles seem to only offer a flat day rate for motorcycles (instead of hourly).  I hate the stupid shops all around Union Square - Macy's is a nightmare (except for the kittens and puppies at the holidays) and there are so many awful tourists that I just cannot believe I got sucked into this again.  I love my dentist but I'm switching to someone in the East Bay.  Screw you, Union Square.
author: Jenn C.

description:
The details of the Square are what I like most.  From the finish and curves of the hand rails to the differences and lines of the paving.  I prefer public spaces for relaxation- St. Marys Square or South Park are more my speed.  Especially now that I find myself in SF as a tourist.  Union Square is more for a quick break and walking through.  

There are trees though the square isn't too shady.  There's seating - retaining walls and benches, but not too much free most times of the day.  

For me the prettiest views in the Square are out towards the surrounding old buildings.
author: Darren S.

description: A must-see in San Fran! The square is beautiful, the St. Francis is gloriously historic, and China town is a meer 3 blocks away. Make sure to stop by the cafe Empiro Rulli and enjoy the evening sounds of Steven the jazz musician who spent almost every evening sending beautiful brass playing up to our 10th floor hotel room.
author: Alissa R.

description: Make sure to take a stroll to the trolley turnaround to meet n greet all the aggressive panhandlers.
author: Vlad A.

description:
I love this place.  In the summer its a great place to sit and read something, in the winter its a great place to go ice skating.  

There is a cafe nearby, and a ticket booth, not to mention a flower place as well.  You can find anything to entertain you within walking distance from here.
author: Stacy S.

description:
Union Square is one of those excellent jumping off points to exploring San Francisco. It's close enough to the main shopping area down there and also a short walk to Chinatown. You can catch a bus to anywhere in the city as well as one of the famous Cable Cars at the turnaround. Oh yeah, it's also a nice park to sit at. It can become pretty frantic around this area with the tourists, locals, business people and homeless. People watching can become very interesting.

Anyway, it's probably one of those things you'd pass or wander through and think, "This is cool." Most likely though one wouldn't make it a point to visit purposefully. If you happenstance to be in the area, it's a nice little park.

I think that there is parking right under the square.
author: Brian A.

description:
There is nothing I could say that has not been said about Union Square.  I will say that as a San Franciscan, it is the heart of the city to me. 

THere are many shops for all tastes and desires.  You have your high end boutiques like my favorite: Diptique where you can get the finest candles money can buy all the way from France.  You can sit and have your hair cut by a master stylist at my favorite salon Zindigi on Grant St. If you fancy a hot Cocoa you can find at least 2-3 varieties at Emporio Rulli - Caffe, Pasticceria, Wine Bar... a date once laughed at me when I asked "what kind of hot chocolate do you have?"  Hey... there are plenty of varieties out there!  If you need some gear to work out... Nike Town, Addidas, Puma, and other retail stores are around that can help you with that. Do you have a race car fanatic?  You can get a nice Ferrari gift for them at the Ferrari store.  Did you leave you iPhone/iPod charger in your last hotel? Just stroll down Stockton and Market and you will find the Apple Store.  Need something altered?  No problem, there is Cable Car Tailors on O'Farrell to the rescue. Coffee?  Starbucks on almost every corner... you desire something a little more sophisticated? There is the fabulous Clock Bar at the St. Francis... they have a great burger.  Of course, my favorite Macy's in the US (Yes, I prefer it over the one in NYC) is also there with everything your heart desires. On some days you can even find a band playing on the square.  It is a magical place to me....  filled with history and many delights
author: Amelia M.

description: This square is in the heart of all the shopping!  Lots of beautiful sculptures around the entire park, as well as a nice deli/coffee shop on the east end of the square.  Nice place to grab a patio table and review your day or watch all the tourists stroll by.  Usually there's a street musician blowing a horn so grab a cup of coffee and get to people watchin'
author: H H.

description:
After a super long construction period, San Francisco gives us this?  Just what is this place supposed to be?  A walk-through spot?  Empty space for the area to breathe?  A giant chess board?  Or a spot to relax?

Whatever it is, it's no more than a wasted opportunity.  I mean come on, this is San Francisco!  There should be some designer willing to give us some oohs and aahhs.  I'm not asking for any abstract architecture or random design ideas, just something that sets us apart from everyone else.  Big slabs of marble and concrete surely will not accomplish that.
author: Michael H.

description: When I was visiting my hotel was just around the area. This place was pretty neat during the day and at night. It's relatively pretty clean...cleaner than NYC's Union Square. But then again anywhere outside of NYC is already cleaner. I think the park is a nice place to have lunch outside near the palm trees. And there truly is a lot of homeless people, but I've gotten used to this in NYC so it's no biggie. But I did get yelled at by one of them when I was visiting San Fran because I took a picture of one of them and he yelled at me for not giving him a $1. It was a funny experience.
author: Sandy C.

description:
Tourist trap, but nevertheless, one of my favorite parts of the city!

Sometimes I cable car down to Union Square on a lazy Saturday to check out the scene and get lost in the mix. Whether it's a beat-boxing group of kids in front of Forever 21, Europeans taking pictures of the infamous "hearts" in the square, or that bum begging for change- Union Square is always entertaining. The shops, scene, local art, and street vendors make for a 100% satisfying experience for an attention deficit individual like me. But hey, that's San Francisco for you!
author: Kristin F.

description: Hmmmm....Union Square.  It's basically a parking garage hidden by a civic plaza on top.  The luxury stores which line its perimeter set an upscale tone for the Square, which is then immediately dashed by the plethora of typical, drugged-out, smelly, literally-crazy street people which always seem close at hand.  There often seems to be some sort of event taking place on the square, so I guess that could be an attraction.  The Powell Street cable cars and termination of tour bus routes also mean that tourists are everywhere.  Union Square could be the Times Square of the West Coast, if the City government actually felt like cleaning up the street life and making people feel safe here.  Oh well.
author: Ryan W.

description:
he scent of fresh vanilla
And the cream of morning's fog
Are the sacrifices you make
When you live downtown.

Dirty hands reaching in your pocket for cash
And a man lying dead on the street for three weeks
Are the things you gain
When you live downtown.

The vast ocean glistening with surfers and sailors
And the radiance of the setting sun
Are the sacrifices you make
When you live downtown.

The scent of waste rising out the factory's stack
And the stars erased through the city lights
Are the things you gain
When you live downtown.

The hours to travel to your destination
And days spent without seeing a fellow friend
Are the sacrifices you make
When you live downtown.

All the colors and eyes by your side
And the many stories you get to hear
Are the things you gain
When you live downtown.

The empty mind divulging into the television
And the hours spent into the internet void
Are the sacrifices you make
When you live downtown.

The coffee houses and beautiful parks
And the many flavors you get to taste
Are the things you gain
When you live downtown.
author: Jon-o G.

description: Nice place to visit, especially around holidays. In the winter, there is a skating rink here. There is a coffee shop. Nearby are lots of stores. Many of the SF tours leave from here.
author: Mihir M.

description:
The hustle and bustle of downtown SF at it's finest. I like sitting out here on those rare sunny days and having a picnic, it's crowded but I can always find a little corner. I hate quiet, so this is also a great reading spot.

Fun story of the day:I saw someone get proposed to here during Christmastime! Okay well it was a few days after Christmas, but the tree was still up, so the guy had the ambiance down. He also had champagne and paper cups, it was cute. 

I now need to trick someone into doing the same for me.
author: Pearl R.

description: Tourist central.  Busy as hell.  Parking in the garage is expensive.
author: Trynh K.

description: Very touristy. There are a lot of luxury shops...Gucci, Tiffany & Co., Neiman Marcus, Macy's, Saks. Or you can just sit around the park and watch the tourists go by. There are a lot of restaurants in the area if you get hungry while shopping. We went early when a lot if the little cafes were still closed.
author: Rosie P.

description: Love this square, the history and monuments. Added bonus of world class shopping all around. Use the square to plan your shopping adventure.
author: Steve S.

description: Very cute park in the middle of San Francisco. Bring a picnic blanket and have a picnic. Had a relaxing time here with the hubby!
author: Mary I.

description: Great on the holidays. Macy's women's shoes and men's shoes nearby us a must stop. Good restaurants, shop all nearby. Powell Bart is closest off Market St.
author: Tony O.

description: I live really close to Union Square. I have spent a lot of time here and have many fond memories that I will never forget that occurred at this square. I love how during the holidays theres a big tree and an ice skating rink. On a nice day people just bask in the sun or enjoy lunch here. Also sometimes theres events that occur here.
author: Sarah C.

description: A park area in the middle of major, famous, and pricey stores. thin outside mall courtyard where something is always going and its the touristy place to go.
author: Anabel V.

description: One thing to do here: SHOP. All brands lives here in Union City. I am blessed a couple times a year to go to this magical place where I can grace myself at Chanel, Neiman Marcus, Saks Fifth, and seriously die over all my favorite brands. Union Square is the most unique place ever. From the people that walk around, to the food, to the shops. I love the eclectic feel of SF, and this is seriously where I leave my heart at every time I get to come  here. LOVE LOVE!!
author: Uyen T.

description:
It has been a while since I have spent time at Union Square and on Monday I walked around and then sat at the steps of the square for about an hour. On a warm day like it was on Monday, Union Square is the place to be, to watch all the people from all part of the world walk back and forth. There is a certain type of energy that is at Union Square and it is fascinating to watch it move about. 

I noticed that more trees have been planted at Union Square, I think that is good idea. I was disappointed to see that Sees Candy is no longer at Union Square, I wonder what happened? Perhaps the economic recession? Don't know, will have to find out. That little shop space is a perfect retail space. 

Will have to go back soon to find out if a new retailer or tenant has taken that spot.
author: Jonathan F.

description:
I don't know why, but I get the feeling every crazy bitch in the People's Republic of San Francisco wants a piece of yours truly. I'm starting to wonder if I have a blinking "The Doctor Is In" neon sign above my head visible to the terminally deranged, to which you say "well Darin, birds of a feather!" To which I say "You online stalkers don't know I'm actually very even-keeled and almost shy in person, do you REALLY think I'm like those anti-gay demagogues at the Cable Car turnaround who chastise cocksuckers using the rack and wheel of holy judgement? FUCK YOUUU!" I. Just. Don't. Know. I was talking about this with a friend who also bears this cross and she seemed to think it was a racial thing, it's like of course people scream and harass us, they don't think we'll respond 'cause we're Asian, OH MASSSAAA, I SORRY FOR TALKIN BACK, 'TWONT HAPPEN AGAYUNN!!!
 
Or maybe it's just the holiday season taking its toll on everyone.
 
Anyway, if you throw a bunch of SAD afflicted individuals on the narrow sidewalks and close quarters of Union Square in the rain two Sundays before the Christmas Day, well, a little crazy is bound to erupt.
 
We were all there, shopping for presents at the stores grouped in the four-block radius demarcating the Union Square shopping district. The rain fell steadily -- it soaked the blouse picked up at the Nordie's 'fire sale', the books bought at Borders, the gifts meticulously wrapped at Macy's, and made us wonder if maybe, just MAYBE, this whole season is more trouble than it's worth.
 
I worked my way up Powell Street, dodged folks as they shuffled towards the Powell Street station, and tried not to spear them with my golf umbrella though of course it was inevitable. We're all avoiding the rain: they accidentally hit my umbrella at times, I accidentally hit theirs. The cost of doing business, no?

Then the bitch in front of me turned on a dime, gave me a wizened, wrinkled glare, and started I KID YOU NOT screaming at me in front of EVERYONE on Powell/O'Farrell.

Bitch: HEY!
Me: [confused look]
Bitch: YOU GOTTA WATCH OUT, YOU'RE HITTING MY UMBRELLA!!!!!!
Me: Sorry lady, but you know...it's raining.
Bitch: YOU GOTTA PAY ATTENTION, YOU STUPID ASS! DID YOU HEAR ME? PAY ATT-TEN-SHUNN!!!!!
Me: OH SHUT THE FUCK UP!!!

She kept screaming at me, but by that point I stopped listening and crossed the street.

And now you know why I hate holiday shopping in Union Square with every fiber of my bei -- oh wow, they have an ice rink in the square now! Whee!
author: d s.

description: There's a lot of great stores to explore in this area and a few great restaurants on Maiden Lane. Try to explore some of the side streets - there's a lot of stores that I overlooked here. Plus, people watching is always fun (tourists and non-tourists alike) when you get tired and want a place to plop.
author: Denise N.

description: Union square is a fun place to hang out for shopping, dining, or just people watching! Im staying in one of the hotels and its a great central location.
author: Danielle M.

description: Nice park. Lots of places to sit down. Had a painted heart for a photo opt. All the tours leave from this area. Nice people watching. Lots of shops by this area.
author: Samantha N.

description: This definitely reminds me of New York, but with a lot less cars around. There are plenty of stores to shop at and the park in the center is clean! I love how their major stores were located in the outside of the park like Nike Town, Levi's, Tiffany & Co, and more. It's definitely a touristy place to visit, but a great place to burn a hole in your wallet if you have the financial capabilities to do so.
author: Michelle H.

description: So much fun, beautiful, great exercise, great shopping and beautiful hotels.  plus got to enjoy a little dixie jazz at the wharf
author: Becky R.

description:
As I exclaimed to my sister as she toured me around her home away from home, all throughout several places in the Bay. 

"The mall is my home [sigh of relief]"

Don't judge me, there's just something about being at the mall in some place unfamiliar that just makes everything better. Kinda like running into Target when you have an emergency buy and you're outta town. 

Awesome selection of every store imaginable from High end to good ole bargain busters like Ross and F21. 

If you like to shop, come here and do your worship.
author: Stephie D.

description:
I don't like the Christmas Tree at Union Square. 

The 85-foot tree adorned with thousands of twinkling lights and 1,500 red and gold ornaments...that's the specific tree in Christmas 2007 I didn't like. In fact, the more I looked at the tree the more disturbing it became in my eyes. 

Last winter when I made my yearly pilgrimage to Union Square, my keen eye noticed "there's something wrong with the tree".  The familiar glow of chestnuts roasting over an open file was missing. The same warm glow that adorned George Bailey's house in It's A Wonderful Life was missing (never mind it was a b/w film).  

Instead, Macy's "supposedly" gift to the city was LITTERED with thousands of twinkling, energy-efficient LED LIGHTS!!  Stark white lights that poke at your brain when viewed.  The green tree had gone green!  The culprit to blame was PG&E for providing the light-emitting diodes. 

In a Macy's press release regarding LEDs, "They generally use one-tenth the energy of an incandescent bulb and can last a decade or longer. They also produce almost no heat, thereby reducing fire potential." 

To which I say: "TTTHHHRRRPPPPPP!!!"

Hey Macy's, bring back the incandescent bulbs! They look much better, richer, natural and more spirited. 

* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 
MACY'S 19TH ANNUAL TREE LIGHTING 
BENEFITING UCSF CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL
Nov. 28, 2008, 6:00 p.m.
Union Square Park
author: Teddy B.

description:
So Our hotel was located in Union Square and we walked past stuff everyday but I didn't plan on actually exploring it officially until the last day.

Union square is a good place to stay if you are out of town.  It's a good center of operations.  Many of the clubs are within walking distance, there are many MUNI stations within a couple of blocks.  This is near most of the shopping.  

It would be a 5 star rating except there are way too many crazy bums in this area.
author: David N.

description:
Outside of the fact that you can rest your overshopped weary feet here after a long day of shopping, eat here, get discount theater tickets, listen to live performances on occasion, watch a movie when movie night in the parks is happening, do some crazy people watching..........

you can yelp here, because, yes, they have free wifi.
author: Drue C.

description:
Union Square, as in the square itself, certainly deserves a review - and a 5-star one at that.

I think the 2002 renovation improved it quite a bit. It was ugly before then, with too much ragged-looking greenery. The redo made it more open and more modern-looking.

It's a great spot for people-watching. European tourists in particular seem to be in evidence here. And why wouldn't they, as Union Square represents something familiar to them - shopping in a lively and attractive downtown neighborhood, as opposed to in some suburban mall.

And my favorite Union Square story of all - the Saturday before Christmas 2008, there was a rally against recently-approved Prop 8, and lots of shoppers and skating-rink-goers actually stopped to watch (and support) the proceedings. It was one of those incredibly cool, heart-warming only-in-SF kind of scenes.
author: S R.

description:
Statements that will make my friends offer contrary opinions: 

I love Union Square at CHRISTMAStime.  
I love it when Macy's puts LIVE ANIMALS in their windows.
I enjoy TAPPING on windows of the above store.

That is all.
author: Janney B.

description: People watching at it's prime. On any given day, it's a great place to take a break and just chill. I like to walk over on my break, pick a spot and just check out. In between playing with my phone (damn Words with Friends) and watching the parade of people from beneath a cute little tree, it couldn't be better. Okay, it could be better without the crazies but then it wouldn't be SF.
author: cyndi L.

description: Don't you just love the sweet smelling air of vehicle congested cities? I know I do! I love walking around Union Square enjoying the different aspects this downtown area has to offer. I love walking around the blocks, getting some exercise and shopping around. When I went here, there were a lot of people, which is good, because company is good. Cool place, I'll visit when I'm in the area again! next time, I'll try to eat at the Cheesecake Factory upon Macy's! Too bad we couldn't last time, due to the 3 hour wait.
author: Lorraine S.

description:
I really like this area of SF- if you wanna shop- it is where to go.

Always tons of people and tourists, but normally everyone is in an upbeat mood. Has plenty of eateries around as well.

Parking can be a hassle-I normally just valet at Nordstroms- quick and easy, but a bit pricey.
author: Noelle M.

description: Right in the heart of San Fransisco and just blocks away from everything.  I even walked the entire "Up Hill" trip from Fishermen Wharf and loved it.  Along the way we stopped to visit several of the other square areas but none had the charm and feel as Union Square.  I cant wait to return.
author: Kevin M.

description: What is there NOT to like about Union square? The heart of my shopping days. The area where my dog loves to run around and play with other dogs. The place where I enjoy salsa on Wednesdays during the summer, and fun movies in the warm summer nights. Fun little art vendors in the middle of the week. A block away from my classes so I can enjoy my hot apple cider during breaks. Amazing place to people watch. LOVES IT!
author: Amanda S.

description: My wife and I love this neighborhood of San Fran.  Great ambience, plenty of stores and variety.  A must area for visitors to browse, shopping and people watch.
author: Jason L.

description: This place is awesome for meeting up with a friend and starting your day!  So many shops, cafes, and restaurants.  Don't forget your camera, you'll need it!  This place does get busy if you're looking for a quiet and slow paced environment, this is NOT for you!  Go to the Hyatt and make your way to the 36th floor, it's the best place for checking out the city from a bird's eye view!  They have a full bar up there and have a good menu for snacks.  Union Square houses shops for all budget levels, everything from Prada, Gucci, to Levi's and Old Navy.  Also, catch the F train cable car in Union Square and take it to Pier 39, Fisherman's Wharf or the opposite, the Castro District.  All in all, I've definitely making my way back to Union Square soon.
author: Frank M.

description: Must go toSanFrancisco and see the down town. It's beautiful . I can't compare this place to another one! Then you can stay for awhile in union square. Relax in very nice place,see the people......
author: Mali R.

description: The renovated Union Square was meant to resemble a European plaza, but the designers' visions of grandeur fell short of the mark when the actual execution of their plans was unveiled. The wide expanse of concrete and very limited landscaping have left it looking barren and lifeless, despite the steady stream of foot traffic. How many millions were squandered to create this unattractive space? I don't recall the former incarnation being so desperate for a facelift that it warranted this disappointing do-over.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
At the beginning of every Christmas season, until I was about 12, my typically serious and sometimes grumpy full-blooded, German Grandma would dress me to the 10's in a new, beautiful, fluffy dress, fur hat and matching coat and white cloves.  She'd load me in the car and we'd trek all the way down from Sebastopol to Union Square, where she'd walk me through each and every store on the Square from where she'd buy each and every person in my family a little gift for me to give on Christmas Day.

She schooled me that a lady knows that gift giving is only complete when the very nicest wrap is used, so we always ordered extra fancy ribbons and paper, a lot of times with the funny plastic fruit or flowers on top.

I miss you, Grandma.
author: Michael O.

description: It's good to be reminded one lives in a city beautiful enough to attract tourists.
author: Inigo M.

description:
It's a pretty decent spot to eat lunch and I like to walk around after work to people watch.  As Christine S. says, there are too many annoying tourists, but I try to remember that they are a large part of the economic engine that drives San Francisco.  And they can be fun to watch.  Nothing says tourist like white sneakers, shorts and a fanny pack.  

I like the lobby of the St. Francis hotel and they also have decent bathrooms (to the right).  

I also like to try to spot the Brown twins.  I've managed a few times.  They are so cute - they don't seem real!
author: Jeremy S.

description: Beautiful space with shopping areas all around.  Pretty clean.  It's a good meeting place.  When the tree is here during Christmas, it feels like home---they even have an ice rink during winter!
author: Bryant C.

description:
Union Square, I wish I knew how to quit you.  Every time I come down there, its the same damned thing: 15,000 assholes, wandering around aimlessly, bumping into each other and coming to a sudden stop in the middle of the sidewalk.  It's enough to make me wish for my own personal cowcatcher (you know, the thing on the front of old-timey trains).

Sadly, too many merchants that I need to regularly visit are located solely at UniSqu.  And so, like an irked swallow to San Juan Capistrano, I must return, over and over again, whether I like it or not.
author: Ben P.

description: Love this place. Plenty of shops, large variety of restaurants.  Parking is little issue but if you are ready to pay, they have paid parking. Square park has changing theme. It is very good place after your city tour or after shopping. Relax with cup of coffee
author: Prasad D.

description: I love to come here and people watch.  I usually grab a coffee or lunch and find a chair or a step to sit on when the weather is nice.  Weekends are busy and full of excitement.  Sometimes there are events going on in the square, like music or shows.  Definitely a place to check out and there are lots of eateries nearby.
author: Edward S.

description:
I love Union Square in SF! I love that there's so many people shopping at at the stores along the streets of Post, Geary, Powell, etc. and not empty because of the malls.

The decorations in the winter make it that much more fun and is absolutely picture perfect for those who want to spend Christmas in the city. 

However, despite how much I love to visit this place about once every one or two years, I'm gonna have to stay loyal to Fashion Valley in San Diego where everything is in one mall and not spread all over the place on multiple streets. I like the worry-free about getting hit by cars and pounced on by bums.

Another thing I didn't like about Union Sqauare is that the only way to get parking is to use the garages and they are ridiculously expensive. I want to shop without having to pay for my car's spot too! And even in a garage, it's confusing and generally full.
author: Jenni Y.

description:
Beautiful Union Square basked in the sunshine today as I walked through.  Concrete plaza echoing with the sound of electric blues, about 20 people in the audience.  Solar summer is still here, but it's fall on the academic calendar and all the pretty tourists have gone home.  So, more Union Square for me!  

Right in the center stands a statue of Victory on a 90-foot pedestal.  On the side, a copy of a memo:  

April 24, 1898
To: Commodore George Dewey
War has commenced between the United States and Spain.  Proceed at once to the Phillipine Islands and capture or destroy the Spanish fleet.  
/s/ John D. Long 
Secretary of the Navy 

The more things change, the more they stay the same.
author: David D.

description:
I'm really pissed that they fucked up Union Square as much as they have.  The center plaza area is closed off as much as it is open, and really rude security staff hassle you even if you want to take a stroll through the square past certain times at night.  WTF is that about?

Say what you will about the previous Square, but at least it brought people together in a way that not many downtown city parks can do.

This square allows everyone to face in the direction of Macy's and is a monument to shallow consumerism.  No, I don't want to stare at David Beckham's crotch when the huge underwear banner is draped down the north side of Macy's.

Fuck that.

Union square also used to be a fun place where skateboarders and soccer kids could come in and play a little.  The fun is now gone unless it's  planned and approved and organized into events.

Fuck that too.

Union Square has changed.  Yuppie scum and recent SF transplants love the new design.  It's "cleaner" and "safer".

If you want clean and safe, get the fuck out of SF and move to fucking Vacaville.
author: Justin C.

description:
I liked the old Union Square with the grass slopes and was sad when they changed it, but the new look has grown on me over the years. I like that there's a lot of seating and and the city does a good job with the Christmas tree every year. It has tons of great stores nearby and is just walking distance from yummy Chinatown food.

What bums me out about Union Square is that there seems to be a lot more homeless there than there used to be even 2-3 years ago. You can't go 10 feet without being asked for money and/or stared at crazily. I can deal with it, but it makes SF look bad to out-of-towners.
author: Kristina A.

description: Love hanging out here on a Sunday afternoon or those hot heat wave, late-nights.  It's a beautiful place-like-park when it's not drizzling or foggy.  All walks of life hang out here.  It's a great place to eat lunch or enjoy your favorite ice cream while people watching.  There's lots of events that happen here; art displays (my favorite to check out!), free dance lessons like tango, salsa and fun stuff that the whole family or a group of friends or people on dates and couples can enjoy....film nights.  There's performances too music, choir, dance.
author: Lyn D.

description:
I use to come here and study when all the outdoor seats were taken at Starbucks or they were playing incredibly suicidal music on their XM there. I never thought I was approachable until like, one clear sunny Sunday a whole slew of men started coming up to me making horrible jokes about my studying materials. "You like CPUs? Yeah, I'm totally into CPUs!" "Do you even know what a CPU is?" "No, not really." "Please, leave me alone."

Union Square's events are mediocre and almost ruin my plans if I've come to sit here to eat or study or talk with friends. They have like, crazy loud Vietnamese events which is probably the worst idea ever, putting a Vietnamese on a loud speaker that only amplifies the sound as it hits the windows of Macy's. They also have horrible 60's rock cover bands, where they'll cover "Don't Fear the Reaper" sans the cowbell. I know, should be illegal huh.

Then you get to watch the conspirators (9-11 didn't happen!) tout their beliefs as the anti-fur people protest in front of Neiman Marcus. Oh, and the Scientologists usually set up shop in front of Macy's, giving strangers the "Oxford Capacity Test" which is specially designed so that you fail (and need their "spiritual" services) no matter what answer you give.

Three-ring circus of tourists, lousy hipster art students from Academy of Art, more lousy hipsters who work at the surrounding businesses, and tons of rude old Asian ladies (who WILL shove you out of the way) coming from Chinatown. God bless America.
author: Grace-Monday B.

description: i'm a native san franciscan, how can i not love union square?!!
author: Jas W.

description:
Union Square is about as iconic SF as you can get.  When I lived over on Mason and Bush I would come here often and order some sparkling wine from the cafe and just sit and read and/or people watch.  On a sunny day it can't be beat.  It's a great spot for a midday nap away from the office on a warm sunny day as well.

If the wife must go downtown shopping there is a great little oasis real close to the square by the name of the Gold Dust Lounge, some of you may have heard of it.
author: Anthony Y.

description:
Good for people watching on a hot day. 

Steps where you can eat during lunch.

The only thing I hate about this spot is bums will hassle you for change.
author: Keit K.

description:
I flew to San Francisco just for a Day to check out the Ferry Plaza Farmers Market, before the end of my trip I checked out Union Square just only 2 hours... before my Flight @ SFO back home to SEA. =/

This Place seemed like The Hustle and Bustle of San Francisco. I liked it Alot.  =D It was a bit Overwhelming though.... It's a great place to meet, enjoy coffee, or just let the world go by. This Shopping District is something not to miss!!

I am booking another flight as I end this Yelp Review. ;)
author: Alvin N.

description:
its union square! its awesome. it has changed a lot in past but its still the heart of the city. surrounded by great hotels and expensive tourist traps, its one of the best places just to sit chill and people watch. its still pretty interstestin to me that you have this extremely populated tourist attraction and then two blocks away....the loin. just saying...go the wrong direction and its all bad. my favorite places in/ near the square are as follows: westin st. francis, azul, macy's, H&M, and blondies. 

if you go during the right time you can see different flash mobs. i think on easter you can see a bunch of people dressed as pink bunnies, you can aslo see random flash mob dances, and santas.
author: Ashley H.

description: Totally love Union Square!  I love the big heart and the lion statues and everything.
author: Salonje R.

description:
This Union Square is a joke. When I hear "I'm going to Union Square", I will always think about the REAL Union Square - http://www.unionsquarenyc.org/

But I will say, when I sit in this union square, I feel like I'm back in NYC for a brief moment once again.
author: Jen D.

description:
I think the renovation was a success. The Memorial statue is also quite remarkable. Union Square provides a nice vantage point for Macy's ever-changing displays, as well as a break from the bump and grind action that is walking in SF.

They have art displays here. Finally, a place to pretend to have an opinion on something... besides Yelp.
author: Keane L.

description:
Union Square used to be so much nicer before the big remodel. Now there isn't enough grass and too much concrete. Easier to maintain but less friendly and beautiful on the eyes.

Yes there are homeless bum-looking types here and around the various stores that surround the plaza but just ignore them unless they look like they really need help, and not drug help.

However, Union Square is a great place to people-watch, shop, rest those tired feet, sunbathe, take pictures, eat food that you have bought in a nearby restaurant or wait for the cable cars.

Lots of scenery. And just think about how much this property would be worth if they developed it. Man, would that be a chunk of change.
author: Terry H.

description:
Tres chique! It's a very European piece of SF. Cafe, espresso, monuments, sun, stoops, then there's the injection of SF. Trannies, crackheads. This is a sweet place to check out a Saturday movie in the park. ( www.sfneighborhoodtheater.org ) Shoppers, tourists, cable cars, utlimate capitalism, and the best thing is that's it's a hot shortcut.

I live on one side and work on the other, so I get to see the "Square Action" every day of the week, pretty much. My favorite day included a marching band with a crackhead bringing up the rear, marching across Powell & Geary up the steps into the square. The crackhead sits in the middle of the intersection and flips off the cars while they lay on the horns. Anti-war protestors, tourists asking for directions, a trannie or two, and a partridge in a Union Square.
author: Braden B.

description:
I can't believe all the moaning here.
Union square was created to be a public forum, and that is exactly what it continues to be to this day.
And despite whatever personal distaste you have for the events, where else any where inthis city, or all of california for that matter, can you see free live performances by circus groups from all over the bay all summer long?

That alone would give it super stars ofr me, but combined withthe specific historic and political signifigance of the space, it seems offensively wasteful to whinge on abou the wonderful public resource San Francisco's forefathers opted to have built for their city.

And Free Circus Shows!
Come on people!
author: soggy b.

description: Its a great area to hang out and grab a bite. Its especially nice during the holidays. If you ever visit SF, this is a good place to visit. The BART runs through here so it is also convenient. I don't recommend driving here though cause traffic is horrible.
author: Alfred K.

description:
Good for cutting through when need to go diagonal from Sak's to Neiman's.

Not really somewhere I want to hang out, though it's a handy meeting landmark for friends and the city does put on outdoor movies in the summer.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Did you know that the statue commemorates the occasion of California joining the Union ...of the the State of the Americas? Go Bears Go Bare..At least the bear on the California flag is bare.

It has become more of a marble, concrete square, but that was to reduce the number of homeless harrassing and scaring the touristas.

Nicer location for STUBS/half price tickets--people not as likely to get swiped by cars trying to get into Union Square parking lot entrance on Geary Blvd.
author: miriam b.

description:
I love walking Union Square, especially at night during Christmas. 

Great people-watching. 

It's a tourist trap for sure, but sometimes it's nice to pretend to be a tourist for a day and experience the hustle and bustle of this beautiful city.
author: K P.

description: My most favorite place to dine, lodge, and shop when I'm in the City!  Union Square offers so much, mostly a tourist district bordered by the Financial District, Theater/Tenderloin, SoMa, and Nob Hill.  I love the romance of the City from the view, cable cars, and the cafes.  Mocca on Maiden is a favorite stop.  There is so much history here.  Parking is an issue - busy, traffic, and pricey.  Most shops, eateries, and galleries are within close proximity so I walked.  If I wanted to go farther, I took the cable car.  This is a great place for people watching too.  Summer months, I found are the best time to be here.  You catch some great sales at a lot of stores the first or second week of June, make that semi-annual sales at Victoria's Secret!  Union Square offers a lot and I spend a lot there too!
author: Val B.

description:
There is a creepy guy working the square the two times I spent time there.  The first time he came up to me with the opening line "I am gay and have AIDS, don't worry if I come close to you, you won't get it".  Flashback to 1983.  I think most of us realize that AIDS isn't that transferable.   He will go on to tell you a story about how he was stabbed and wants some money for the BART to get him back home. Fortunately I didn't believe a word and didn't give him any money. I was especially glad of this two days later when I saw him pulling the same show on someone else.  Seriously dude--not every tourist is ignorant.  

Other than that Union Square is a really nice place to sit down, people watch, and read a book.  The terraced lawn is quite nice, giving you a good view of the shopping district around you.
author: Katie F.

description:
OK, I'll admit that I do like walking up Powell Street from Market.  It's kind of neat to be among all these tourists spending all this money and creating all these shallow, materialistic memories of San Francisco when they haven't even seen anything interesting.  It's really neat when I'm doing all this just to get to a dermatologist's appointment.

All in all, though, Union Square sucks.  It's not really a park.  There's the things commemorating the town meeting at which San Francisco residents chose to side with the North in the Civil War.  But does this place feel historical to you?  It's just kind of fancy and boring and gross.  I do like catching the cable car here to avoid the turnaround line.  I also like jumping on the 38-Geary here.  But if Union Square disappeared tomorrow, it wouldn't bother me.  At all.
author: John S.

description: I think Union Square is interesting.  Such a mix of tourists and bums!  I like to go down during lunch, sit out side and people watch.  Yeah, you have to put up with getting asked for change and directions all the time, or to take a picture of a couple.  But if you're OK with that, it's not that bad.
author: Levi B.

description:
i love this place.. this is where my now boyfriend asked me out.
we came here yesterday for our one year, but last year the x-mas tree was up, they were barely setting it up when we were there.. they had a lot of the place blocked off for safety reasons.. they just opened the ice-skating rink which was nice since we were watching kids eat it.
we were smoking and got kicked out a certain area.. so of course we moved to where he said we could.. later.. anohter guy came and kicked us out again.. so we moved again.. so, if you're a smoker.. expect to get kicked out a lot.. i don't remember that last year or the time before when i went with my sister. who knows?!
author: Stephanie B.

description: My favorite place in SF! It's at the heart of the shopping district, so I like to sit and relax here after a big shopping spree, with some Peet's coffee or cheesecake from the Cheesecake Factory while watching tourists go by. I love the hearts here, and how their pattern keeps changing. It's a great place to just chill and to attend some events that are hosted on various occasions.
author: Meghana S.

description:
When the new design was first unvieled, I was quite unhappy about it. Now that I have spent time there, sat and drank wine, watched the tourists, made friends, seen shows, magicians, and an odd assortment of what makes San Francisco the city it is, I really enjoy it. Spending an afternoon sipping wine and watching the world go by makes me fall in love with this city again and again.
Living a few blocks away and being able to see the square from my living room, it really feels like an extension of my house..a very welcome one!
author: Jason D.

description: Such a pretty place. We came to see Drag queens on ice, I kinda wish there were more drag Queens.
author: Jessica T.

description: um, it's not a park, it's a meeting place.    stop selling your bad art!
author: Dean P.

description: Neat spot in the middle of the city. Nice to wander through on a stroll for dinner in the evening.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Best place to sit and eat lunch.  There's always sun in some part of the square, so it's nice even on chilly days (except you gotta fight off other people for premium spots).  Great for people watching and lazing about deciding what to do or where to go next.

Except when the transsexual black lady who still has a penis runs naked through the square.
author: diana s.

description:
I love this place because honestly, it's pretty much my backyard. I live a few blocks from Union Square, and while sometimes the entire idea of tourists makes my skin crawl (SERIOUSLY! Do they not have sidewalks where they are from? Do they not understand that you don't just suddenly stop walking in the middle of the sidewalk, or to block the flow of other pedestrians?!?!) Ok, so I was sidetracked. Sorry. Where was I again?

Oh yes! Union Square is an excellent place because it's outdoors, it's got tons of excellent energy and vibe going for it. Most of the time it's nothing special. Just an open area where people walk around, relax, do their own thing. But it's just nice to surrounded by so many people, and not be a part of their group.

A most excellent place to just sit out on a sunny afternoon with a book and a bottle of water. Very enjoyable indeed!
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Union Square...  what can you really say about this place (in terms of being in competition with every other large city in the world).  for me, the thing that separates this identifying center piece to our city is the fact that I can walk through its center of the Union and find a family posing in front of a decorated Christmas tree - just on Holiday from Lithuania or I can stroll past that man having a conversation with the fichus plant...  for me, I tend to walk on past instead of saying, "hey man.  whatcha 2 talking about??".  I'm the one pretending to be proud and needed (for that 8 o'clock discussion that just wouldn't be the same without you).  

what is it to you?  is it just a square that happens to be completely surrounded by name brand shops (Louie, Salvador, etc)??  is it someplace you'd take your mother to that is visiting from Vermont who you haven't seen in a year?  is it a good meal at the Cheesecake Factory?  is it just another part of the city that you walk past, not really noticing on a day to day routine but you end up recognizing in a movie preview when you're visiting Portland and say, "HEY!!  that's my PLACE!!!"?  

whatever it is to, it is a part of you.  to me, it is the heart of what I know of a city that I'm proud to tell people (brag to people) that I'm from.  it is an art gallery every few days and it is, by far, a place I'd recommend to anybody...

enjoy.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
In the mecca that is Union Square, these inviting steps to the square are paradise.

I love sit around anywhere in this square to check out the occassional exihibits and the hustle and bustle going on in the city.

The best spot for people watching.....people from all walks of life congregate in this area, this diverse city.
author: Wel C.

description:
As much as the tourists can annoy me, I love Union Square. 

Tourist trap? I suppose so, but as your token shopaholic, Union Square is great. I come around to do my shopping and to people watch. The tourists may be annoying at times, but they can also sure as hell be rather entertaining (if not painfully dumb.) 

"Where is Union Square?" one asked me as we were walking past the tradition that is the giant Christmas tree. At first I wasn't sure the person was serious but then sheepishly pointed and said, "Right there." How can you not get a kick out of stuff like that? 

All in all, I think Union Square is wonderful. It is probably one of the best people watching spots in SF as locals, tourists and the homeless alike are all here. As much as I love some of the local boutiques, some things are only available near Union Square.
author: Anita B.

description: Cool place to hang out and people watch, especially if there's live music on a warm sunny afternoon.  Unfortunately, there are ladies out there who think a warm sunny afternoon also means they get to wear their too-short skirts that share wayyy too much...um....stuff.
author: Cindy W.

description:
It was fine.  It shouldn't have been renovated but now it has and it is hard and ugly.

It gets four stars because it is a square, nothing more.
author: Patrick A.

description: Nice little plaza area that is beautiful during Christmas time because they put up a giant Christmas tree and an ice skating rink. Plenty of places to sit and kept really clean. There are many places to shop and eat in the area as well.
author: Melissa W.

description: I go through Union Square pretty much everyday, but the best way to really enjoy it is during movie in the park night! the square was packed with people all gathered together to watch Dirty Dancing. Guys with Hot chocolate backpacks roamed the crowd to keep us warm. But I was content with my whisky and Snuggie. The movie was great, and we all clapped and cheered every time Patrick Swayze showed off his amazing body. The screen had a beautiful backdrop with the lit buildings. Just the perfect night!
author: Casi C.

description:
I have to walk through Union Square to get to work now, fighting the throng of fanny-packing, lumbering tourists.  They don't jaywalk so you can spot 'em immediately, but more importantly, they don't move out of your way.  I've missed my bus because of these fatsos before and I'm sure I will again.

If you say to them, "Scuze me tourist," they get mad but they move out of the way.

Other than that, I love coming here on a lazy weekend afternoon, getting some ice cream from the only Ben and Jerry's left in the area and chillin' with my peeps and my main man, Da Monarch.
author: Frankie D.

description:
So... first of all there are in fact changes on Union Square this year. 
1. The Ice Skating Rink (I encourage everyone to try it out as it benefits a great cause)
2. 
Okay, so not many changes as the tree is the same as it was last year.... I did not see the tree lighting ceremony last year but I did see it this year. It was literally three seconds long- what a ceremony! We attempted to walk up Powell St. from Geary and almost witnessed two fights, many unhappy people, the smell (eww ask me later), and of course the tourists that just won't get out of the way. 
I will not be going to the ceremony next year, or the year after.
author: Janell D.

description: Scenic, touristy and a great place to take photos or just sit and people watch.  It's located right in the heart of a shopping mecca, and below it is an overpriced but very convent parking garage.  There always seems to be something going on here, some sort of festival, salsa dancing class, ice skating, spy games with nerf guns etc... its a really awesome sight to behold and worth a look if your visiting San Francisco
author: Aaron R.

description: ice skating rinks, expos, christmas tree lighting, a menorah lighting, and lots of tourists throughout the year but it still remains a great place to rest in between shopping
author: Vanessa L.

description:
egads.... 

The one star is strictly for public performance art like zombie mobs.  Otherwise, AVOID like the PLAGUE.  What is worse than tourists shopping?

Locals shopping.

AVOID AVOID AVOID

(I cannot understand why this would be well reviewed, unless the reviews are all by tv brainmushed ambulatory vacuum tubes that are consuming worthless fashion like mindless zombies)
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: Great location to hangout, People watch and More! I don't always get a chance to hangout at the Square but it is great to just walk by and see everything that is happening!
author: Rix G.

description:
Union Square is a great place to check out during the holidays. Its decked out with lots of festive Garland, lights and of course the giant Christmas Tree. This year they even had a ice skating rink! Its on the small side but its pretty cool to be able to ice skate in the City. With Macy's, Neiman Marcus, Nike Town and Saks 5th Ave on each corner of Union Square you have ample options to shop. You'll also find street performers around to entertain you. 

Union Square is a great place to give you that "Christmas in the City" feeling.
author: Henry S.

description: Hella SF. They often have random art shows here. Or is it every weekend? Well, whenever I drive by the parking lots downtown, I seem to catch them all the time.
author: Andrew W.

description:
"Hey, where do you want to meet up?" "Union Square!"

As the usual meeting place, it is a great start off point to get your San Francisco on. Free WiFi if you brought your laptop; Apple Store is close if you didn't. Aerial view of the city is in the Western St. Francis, which is right next to the square. Art galleries on Geary will make you seem fancy. Go north to Chinatown, east for Financial District, and northeast for North Beach.

They also have really cool sellers sometimes. The pieces are pretty good. In the winter, they have an amazing tree there, too.

Dope.
author: Haz O.

description: I don't fall for tourist traps, but this area is awesome. Tons of high end shopping, entertaining street performers and special events in the park area. Easy to find and very close to the Powell St. BART station.
author: Ryan M.

description:
That tree is decorated like a scandalous whore. Teasing and cooing her sales pitch for all the neighboring businesses " Buy, Buy, Buy- my little ones." 
The menorah, thankfully, is much more tasteful.

ice rink has way too may people slipping around in sluggy ice. Hello? Zamboni time!

Oh Ba Humbug!
author: linda l.

description:
The New Union Square, ah what fond memories. On a beautiful clear night when all the traffic has finally cleared up a bit, it's a pretty good place for people staying at the nearby hotels. 

But in the day time, it is the concrete jungle for urban skateboarders; though I'm quite sure it's illegal to skateboard there. It's a skateboarder's dream park, filled with rails, "ramps" and pavement!
author: Michael C.

description:
All I have to say is that I HATE the tourists. The ones who walk at a snail's pace down the CENTER OR LEFT side of the sidewalk. In America, you walk on the right side. And don't stop in the middle of the sidewalk because something in a window display caught your eye. Move to the side and look.

I used to work in Union Square, and I love Union Square for the convenience. But the tourists piss me off.
author: Ashley D.

description:
Union Square is my "I-need-to-sit-down" destination when all of the hustle and bustle and chaos of downtown San Francisco starts to become too much.

I certainly spend a lot of time here and the surrounding area for shopping. And Union Square is always there--a symbol of comfort when my legs need a rest and I need to refuel on some takeout I picked up along the way.

The people watching is pretty prime. Tourists, locals, bums ... they all hang out here. It's one of those central locations you can't miss.
author: Sophie D.

description: Suggested as a downtown destination for me by local friends durning my solo visit I walked on over to the Square.  It's large, clean broad paved/stone surfaces were nice.  During the summer months, june-october, there is apparently daily entertainment in the square mid-day.   Didn't make it into the array of stores surrounding this urban hub.  Did get coffee and a great shoe shine up the street.   Beautiful statues atop pillars highlight (literally) this park.    Come here to eat your lunch.   I came on a rainy day, very few people not much going on.  Chill.
author: Brent F.

description: Can't say anything bad about Union Sq. How can anyone, really? Of course there are crowds. Of course parking is an issue. Of course getting around is not fun... especially for those coming into the city by car. Once there, its all good.
author: Rob G.

description:
As a 'park' in itself, Union Square isn't much..
Just a little bit of green and a whole lotta concrete slabs plopped into the city..
And faar too noisy for me to actually sit down and unwind..

For a good park experience, I'd take my Yerba Buena Gardens anyday..

But when there's events that go on in the Square, it makes it much, much better..
Like the jazz preformances that were held kinda recently..
It's always nice to have events and such here with the city as it's backdrop..
The jazz especially fitted nicely into the atmosphere and gave that sort of 'feel-good' feeling..


Union Square as a district, it's just standard shopping and touristy things..
The shops and such around are fine, but mostly clothing shops I can care less about..


But all-in-all, Union Square is a place I go to just because it's there.. And that it's a part of our usual 'script' whenever we tour visitors coming over..
author: Nicolo T.

description:
I try to avoid this area at all costs, especially if I'm driving.

1) Why would you pay $450 for that Neiman Marcus shirt?
2) Nike Town isn't even a town... there's no mayor!
3) Foot traffic here makes driving impossible, because for some reason 2-3 lanes turn into 1 jammed line + 1-2 lanes of "should we drop off you guys here? or maybe here? or here?
author: Andy A.

description:
Union Square...everytime I visit SF the first thing I do when I step off that plane is take a deep breath and inhale that great cold crisp air. I love it...After I take in the air I head out to do a little shopping in Union Square. This place is great and has lot's of stores for you to choose from to shop and I love visiting SF for Union Square. On top of that, if you want to take in some sites, you can jump on the BART system to visit the other neighboring cities. Very convenient and easy maps to follow. 

Downtown Berkeley is nice to visit with friends because of the many small shops and restaurants that you can jump in and out of to kill time. 

I love how convenient and easy everything is in SF and love visiting everytime I get the chance to.
author: Vin P.

description:
thank you union square for being there so i can avoid shopping at macy's with my fiancee.. 

nice place to hang out.. grab a cup of coffee.. and sit and relax and get some sun.. 

there's usually something going on every time i go.. whether it's a little concert or demonstration.. it just adds to the ambience.. like i said.. it's a hell of lot better than shopping
author: Stan L.

description: Right smack in the middle of SF. I've been here at all times of the day, it doesn't seem to not be busy! Great location of shops and great place for a photo opp!!
author: Noel A.

description: I don't know why, but I can't bring myself to really like this park.  Just too many people and too much going on.  You can't just sit and enjoy.  I think the only real amusing time I've had there is when some little black birds were stalking me for my lunch.
author: Robin L.

description: Love this place. I've been coming here since high school and some things never change. The atmosphere is real nice, the crowds usually always has new faces excluding the regulars like myself and occasional people taking their breaks/lunch from work enjoying the weather. I personally love this place because its suited for all ages and its always live over there. With stores surrounding union square ranging from Macy's, niketown, Levis, cheesecake factory, and even the famous cable cars, the list goes on and on. There is never a dull moment here since it's located in downtown. During the holidays there is a huge Xmas tree and ice skating rink. Summertime they have musicians performing and occasionally play movies year round. There's always events around the square and its just a relaxing place to chill and sort your mind out. Hope everybody has a chance to experience this place whether your 'cupcaking' with your significant other or spending quality family time this is always a cool little spot to checkout in the downtown area.
author: Marvin C.

description: Ok, so it's just a square in SFO.  The restaurant there kind of looks pretentious and mediocre, yet packed at all times.  What I truly love about this square comes from the film The Conversation with Gene Hackman and John Cazale, directed by Francis Ford Coppola in between Godfather films.  I feel a magic every time I walk through this tiny square.  It is ringed by cheese, I know it, Armani and Cheesecake Factory at the ends of the cheese spectrum.
author: Christopher T.

description:
There are a lot of bums harassing locals and tourists around the Union Square area. Other than the fancy department stores like Barneys New York, Neiman Marcus, Saks, Macys, Bloomingdales, and the Old Navy Boutique, there's no real reason to hang out.

Mostly the graphic designers out of work, and foreign expatriate-like students loiter around the Borders Bookstore Cafe, and neighboring Starbucks establishments.

Union Square is relatively safe during the day. Don't come here. You probably won't fit in with the bums.
author: Michael K.

description:
Before I had begun working in Union Square, I didn't really think much of it; it was just another part of San Francisco to me. However, since I spent the past nine months working in Union Square, I have come to think of the place very differently.

There's a bit of a love/hate feeling going on inside of me whenever I'm in the area, or even when I just simply think of it. The "hate" comes from the sheer mass of (often rude) tourists coming by, always expecting everyone else who walks around the square to know simply *everything* about the whole of the city.
