No, I am sorry, I do not know everything about the city, and you shouldn't scoff at me if I reply "I don't know" to your enquiry about "where is so-and-so and how do I get to so-and-so?". 

Also, not only can the tourists be rude, but the homeless around the square are particularly demanding. There's the guy with the cat who is sneaky with how he goes about with his peddling; he puts his cat in front of Macy's somewhere and then stands away from his cat, so he can get money from passerbys who don't know the guy's old tricks and gives the cat money. I used to feel some sort of pity for him, but after he cussed me out one day for not helping him change his coins into dollars, I didn't feel pity for him anymore. Plus, there's that other bum that goes right up to customers at the hot dog stands and begs so pitifully for someone to buy him food. One, this method is just too close to comfort for many people; they don't want someone to be so close and begging for food. Two, the guy isn't even thankful after someone does give in to buying him a hot dog. Hm, perhaps people need to wise up and not give the guy what he wants.

Okay, but I digress. The "love" (maybe like?) that I feel for Union Square stems from just the convenience of the square to all of the shopping in the area. It's a good, free place to sit and people-watch (you can then watch the aforementioned groups in all their glory and just be an innocent bystander to the ruckus). On days when the weather is nice, the square is a great place to relax in and catch up with some friends. Also, the square never fails to attract free samples being doled out, and also celebrity sightings (David Beckham was in the square over the summer for his Giorgio Armani campaign for Macy's, and recently, K-pop/J-pop star BoA* was interviewed by Union Square). 

Also, it's great that the ice skating rink is open this year, which brings a very festive atmosphere to the square for the holidays. Too bad I don't really skate though, so I can only enjoy watching the people skate around the rink.

Overall, what can I say? Although Union Square evokes mixed feelings within me, it's a decent place in the end. Yes, if you're a tourist, please come here to see the sights and sounds of downtown San Francisco (but please, if you are going to ask questions, at least be courteous about it).
author: Helene K.

description: I love Union Square of San Francisco. Great shopping and it makes you appreciate the beauty of the city. I love being around a lot of people and Union Square is definitely a great place to be both for tourists and locals. There is great shopping, restaurants, hotels, and people. The only thing to beware of is the usual crowd at the cable car stop/BART station area.
author: Rylan C.

description: A great spot to sip a glass of vino and/or bubbly at the cafe on a sunny winter day and take in all the local and wanna-be local flavor.  Of course, all those wanna-be's are the tourist types with their fanny-packs, maps, and bags from nearby couture entrapments.  They can be hilarious.  But the REALLY funny part is when a naked dude with a boob job struts his stuff right there in the middle of the Square and the jaws drop!!  Just when the tourists think they are fitting right in, BAM!  Full frontal in the last place they'd expect!  That will make 'em think twice about pretending to be locals : )  God, I love San Francisco!
author: Tara G.

description: There should be more open spaces like this in SF.  A great place to take a break from your errands or shopping.  Grab a take-out lunch from one of the many great nearby eateries, and have lunch/dinner at one of the tables, check out the skyline, birds, the scene, and even some people.
author: Jack H.

description: Ever sat and read in Union square? There's an old man there, Asian I think - dirt brown skin and white, sexed hair. He jumps up from his seat every few minutes to chop the air with some martial art motion; karate kids everywhere look on in awe. I like him. There's a girl to the middle, standing errect beside some curiously stiff memorial. She likes him too, spinning off a grin as she pirouettes into a daze. I think she called out to me. "It's just exercise baby, it's just..." only to lose her diatribe whilst leaping out, step two three, pirouette.
author: Marc M.

description: Also one of my favorite places to walk around SF.  I always come here when I'm on break from school.  I generally visit the shops and just take pictures everywhere I go.  I'm really sad that they closed down the Disney store.  I went to go look at the adoption pets at the Macy's windows and never failed to marvel at how adorable these creatures were and how many people came to donate to the foundation and admire the little darlings.  I went to see the Christmas tree and was surprised that they had an ice rink up this year.  It's always a treat to come and visit here.  So many places to go to, and I love the hustle and bustle.
author: Anne N.

description: How could you not love Union Square? Having a coffee at Rulli and being entertained by the crowd is one of the least expensive shows in town. I also love that the Parks Dept. and others attempt to put on events quite frequently. My first inclination upon remodel was that it was a bit Third Reichish, but I've gotten over that and realize the cement and symmetry are merely functional.
author: Robert M.

description: I live so close by it that it's still beautiful wandering by it every time....people watching, enjoying a warm latte in the nearby cafe or overlooking down onto the Square from the Cheesecake Factory rooftop patio or from the windows of Kamalaspa. From any angle atop at taller bldgs, the view is just spectacular.  It's nice to see the Holiday Tree being brought up every December or the different art display/shows that take place on most weekends.
author: Yan M.

description: Sadly, I love this place way more at night than during the day. The square certainly has a life of its own. It pulsates with people rhythmically winding in and out to get to opposite sides of the square to go shop hopping and/or purchase tickets to a show or a cable car ride. Yet, for some reason, this place is so much more enjoyable at night when nobody is around. Well, you see people sluggishly coming out of the Cheesecake factory from a hefty meal. You will also see young couples out on a romantic stroll. I highly recommend going to the St. Francis, taking the elevator and checking out the gorgeous view. I might have romanticized it a bit but I can't help it. It's Union Square. Being a native San Franciscan, it's one of the only re-vamped places in San Francisco I actually enjoy.
author: Dorothy S.

description: I like people watchin....especially with a nice cup of coffee and new pair of shoes on my feets.
author: John-Michael C.

description: I'm really glad they cleaned up Union Square a couple of years ago.  Not it seems like a decent place to chill out.  But the truth is, I really wouldn't chill out here anyway.  I'm too busy shopping, eating, watching movies, having drinks, etc.  Union Suare is one of the most colorful commercial spots in the nation and I'm glad it's part of San Francisco.
author: Tony L.

description: The xmas tree for '08 seems just as garish and tasteless as ever but its cool that they have ice skating on the other side of the square where the giant manorrah used to be - guess the Jews will have to settle for the corner with the Kwaanza crud in it...
author: Quartknee K.

description: I love Union Square - the people watching alone is worth it. Add to that the clang of cablecar bells, the killer shopping, the fog rolling in . . . it is quintessential San Francisco. I'm down this way at least 1-2 times a week and it never gets old. I'm always finding something new or being surprised by who just walked by me. ;-)
author: Sarcastic T.

description: For the ultimate shopping experience in SF, you must go to Union Square. Many upscale stores which I love, along with the usual more affordable stores, are located around the Square. It can be quite entertaining to sit in the Square to people watch or soak in music or participate in an event--stuff that goes on there on most weekends.
author: Fern D.

description: This is just so great to have only a block away from my office... able to just sit out there in the sun, sipping on a Jamba Juice with friends... better yet having a coffee and discussing world politics.
author: Jordan Y.

description: Why? Why? WHY!?! Oh how could they tear down a park and put up that concrete monstrosity. I understand what they were going for. I've been to squares in France that were almost certainly what they were going after, but they failed, miserably. Personally I think they really did it so they could put a parking garage in. I suppose the little art show on the weekend is nice and the fashion show that blows into town is neat to watch, but really the place bums me out. That said, I will go up and sit on the grass near the little italian cafe and read a book because of the occassional cute girl that strolls by. It almost deserves another star for that. Almost.
author: Jordan M.

description: This is a great place to go spend some time in the summer or during Christmas and New Years.  If you want to go shopping that's fine too but I'd recommend going to the mall so you don't have to deal with the crowds of tourists unless of course you're going somewhere specific.  There's all kinds of places to eat and grab a drink or two and if you're bored you can check out some street show, but don't get your hopes up, I have yet to see anything worth watching like some old guy banging two spoons together.  You can definitely make a day of it at Union Square.
author: Lester A.

description: I don't care what anyone says.  Union Square is SO much better than it used to be. You couldn't have a civilized drink and catch up with friends in the same spot five years ago.  You would have been accosted by crackheads or overwhelmed by people in metallic paint.  Now you just have to deal with the pigeons.  It's nice to be able to just sit and enjoy the weather, people-watching, and company.
author: Lisa M.

description: I hate going to Union Square. First, you have to pay for parking. Second, it is crowded with tourists. Third, Macys is awful. Fourth, there are not enough interesting shops around there unless you can afford Chanel/Dior.
author: Marina N.

description: CHRISTMAS IN SAN FRANCISCO--LOVES IT. Simply breathtaking. I love Union Square, especially during the holidays!
author: Audrey T.

description: In Union Square, I have seen: the camera crew for "Monk," people get arrested, a Christmas tree, a Star of David, a man who lit an entire box of matches one by one, Gavin award the cable car bell ringer award, a free screening of "North by Northwest," and girls from (insert any foreign country) get macked on.   You gotta love this place.
author: M A N I K.

description: I noticed a lot of haters doing their thing on this wonderful place. What the heck? If you don't want anything in this immediate area then you are obviously, i don't even know. Union Square is like a world marketplace with china town and north beach not too far off... the heart and soul of san francisco... well, maybe not the soul... although consumerism is close to it... ne how, i love union square and every capitalistic inch off merchandise in it.
author: Andrew W.

description: They just had a zen garden and I missed it! It was there for a total of 1 day. And I missed it. My life will never be complete! Unless you wanna go make out there with me one stary night! I heart this place. Nuff said.
author: monika l.

description: Clean yourself up, San Francisco!  What is with all of the crack heads in this part of town?
author: Tamar N.

description: It feels like they were going for the minimalist approach but if they wanted a European piazza why denude it of a cafe life or some such thing?  Still one of the best potential public plazas in the Bay Area if not Northern CA.
author: Rob M.

description:
Ok, so I wasn't sure if I could actually write a review for Union Square. It turns out I can and here it is! I live just a few short blocks from Union Square and I have enjoyed every passing moment until last night. (I will get to that in a minute)
I enjoy Union Square because that is where all the fun is happening. Shops, Dining, Galleries, Museums, Pubs, and night clubs. Nike Town, Levi, Macy's, Michael Mina, and these are just naming a few. 
Walking to work in the morning you pass all the professionals, kids going to school, and the occasional homeless person asking for money. 
In the wintertime there is the Christmas Tree, the Ice Skating Rink, The big ass Menora haha... 
On the weekends you have the art shows! Tons of great paintings by several talented artist. 
Sometimes it can be a little over whelming on the weekends with all the lost tourist and their luggage, strollers, and big Maps of the city but that is also why I love it so much. I live in a city where people are excited to come visit. and I live in a neighborhood that people can't wait to come see!
Ok, back to last night! This review does not take away from Union Square but it happened there so here it is. 1:30am some friends and I were leaving Vessel heading to Ruby Skye and 8 Drunk ass guys come up to us (4 guys). They are drunk talking sh*t. The next thing i know a fight breaks out. It was really more of us trying to get away and avoid the fight and defend ourselves.  Nobody was really hurt, I left unscathed, but when it ended they "thugs" ran downstairs to the parking garage. We call the police (along with the security gueard). The police are there in 3 minutes flat... Thanks guys... 
The police close off the exits, the first car to come out is yes THOSE FOOLS!  
Ok so long story short... Thank you security Guard for getting on the horn to the police, and Thank you SFPD for catching those fools and arresting them. I just wish I could have been home before 4 am!
author: Miguel V.

description: I love coming here just to observe, rest after a long day, or just hangout.  I love it when they have those vendors who showcase their art.  Those are always fun.  I like watching the tourists as they look at amazement at how great a city San Francisco is.  With their camera, entourage and all! I love sitting while sipping on a vanilla bean frappaucino, kick back, and relax.  I remember coming here when they had those free shoe giveaways! Those were crazy but what an experience.
author: Mel P.

description: The perfect shopping district for a princess (me haha)
author: Candice L.

description: Union Square is awesome. I was sitting around there one morning because I was too hungover to function properly, watching yuppies buy artwork when a homeless woman named Debbie sat down next to me. We talked about things a lot, and I mean a lot because Debbie had severe short term memory loss. SF is a good place to meet homeless people, if you're into that sort of thing. I'm not, but Debbie was cool. If you meet her, tell her I say hey. She won't remember me, and she won't remember you either.
author: Bee O O.

description: renovated under mayor willie brown, it's looking modern, clean and incredibly world class these days and especially during the Holidays when the huge Christmas tree is lit.  this area is classic SF.
author: Jeff W.

description: Union Square gains a few stars due to the influx of interesting people, and then looses a few due to the influx of boring, mundane people, gains a few because of all the funny tourists and looses a few for all the funny tourists.  It's not the park for enjoying the wonderful sights and sounds of nature, nor for getting breathtaking views of the city.  It is however an ideal place for people watching.
author: Herbert S.

description: So, Union Square makes me really content. I always go there to study, which seems like a horrible idea to most of you I'm sure, but it works for me. Perhaps aesthetically it falls short. But regardless of whether  it was better before or after the makeover, I love the contrast between huge, expensive stores and then, right in the middle, a park. Flat. With grass. In the middle of downtown. I mean, even if it doesn't look like a REALY European plaza, that alone satisfies me. It's pretty awesome taking off my sandals and lying down, smelling the grass under the shade of a little tree while all the tourists and business men and vehicles whiz by. Ya feel?
author: Emily H.

description: Lord.. looking for a great shopping day? You'll find everything you need, and a lot of stuff you dont need but cant resist, all here. And be forewarned: it isn't at discount. For poor 20-somethings like me, its all about the window shopping. But don't worry, if I had a sugar daddy...
author: Erin M.

description: Tourist trap Union Square may be, but as a local, I still love this place. The major department stores, the haute couture boutiques, the streamlined Apple Store and Virgin flagship down the street. H&M, Tiffany's, 2 story Victoria's Secret and the Starlite Room. Even sitting in the middle of the square, sitting on a bench or chair that has been sponsored by one of the said illustrious establishments overlooking the square, people watching and enjoying a cup of coffee with friends is a cheap pleasure to have (unless you run over a slow-moving tourist pedestrian on your way into one of the local garages).
author: Christy M.

description:
it's so lovely, and yet so wack. it's inviting, with its tables and chairs and lawns, and then i get all seduced by it and i go and sit down and listen to my ipod and try to do some crossword puzzles and then the panhandling starts. like pigeons, except smellier. oh, and sometimes some people seem to think that the appropriate time to approach a girl is when she is relaxing by herself with headphones on and deep in thought, well it's not. crosswords=leave me alone. 

i still get tempted though... and sometimes fall for it. so if you see a girl doing crossword puzzles by herself in union square, leave her alone.
author: Jeannine S.

description: Don't jaywalk here.  I avoid staying at the hotels nearby.  I don't think its the best part of SF but this was my favorite part of the city in high school because of the shopping.  I like the World War II statue.  I wouldn't compare with the area with New York.
author: Ai M.

description: This place bleeds tourists out of every crack and crevice in the concrete. In fact, I felt so touristy that I had to whip out my digital camera and take a picture. -1 star for this utterly uncontrollable moment of American tourism.
author: Eston B.

description:
Just for the Union Square Christmas Tree Lighting:
I usually like going downtown for the tree lighting. but this year was just overwhelming. you couldn't really enjoy the "start of the holiday season" because everyone around you was pushing and yelling to try to get a glimpse of the tree. if someone else bumps me with a stroller in a crowd of 1000 people again, i'm probably going to flip out. 

i guess i should've known better that if you've seen it once (or twice), that's probably good enough.
author: L B.

description: This place is nice if you are looking for a place to hangout, have some lunch outside and take a break from shopping.  I prefer the plaza by Embarcadero over this one.
author: Jenna M.

description: Beautiful outdoor dining options for those San Francisco blue sky summer days...Sure the panhandlers get annyoing but it's better than it is in my neighberhood...plus the gold dust lounge is here so how can you go wrong !?!?
author: Francis K.

description: It's alot nicer than it used to look. Lots of tourists here, and it's a great place to just sit, relax, and chill under the sun.
author: Katherine C.

description: I love union square, I walk through it everyday to get to work and it's always lively and full of people. It is also surrounded by some of the most amazing stores like macy's, neimans, tiffiny's, gucci, nike, and Saks 5th avenue. Where can you go wrong with that. It's an amazing place to have lunch or just sit and rest and watch people go about thier lives. It's just a nice place in the middle of a bustling city!
author: Preston B.

description: There are very few places in the world that are both cool and fun. At the same time. The Eiffel Tower, yah know, that wire-y thing in the middle of Paris? When you stand under it, and look up. Definitely cool. When you stand on top of it and look down, very cool. The student section of any given big time College Football game, oh so very much fun. Union Square, however, is one of those singular points where cool and fun come together and leave you a mismashing of a nice setting, good shopping for the ladies, nearby booze for their men, a pretty scene by which to take a girl and thusly give yourself an air of respectability (or at least class).  It's also one of the only places you can run upto to a random woman, touch her on the arm and say "tag, your it" and get not maced (or hit, arrested, screamed at or otherwise in trouble) but tagged back. Yay San Fransisco.
author: Eric P.

description: I do like to hang out at Union Square.  I like the park better which is why it only got 4 stars, but it does the Job.  If i want to hang out and people watch or read the paper/a book, its pretty perfect.  People watching is always fun there becuase you will see all sorts of people walk by since its a pretty big shopping center (Little expensive for most of my taste's).  I usually grab a slice of pizza and a coke and have a seat on the ledge at the Stockton and Geary corner.  They also have some nice exhibits there ranging from some nice Art shows to an Asian drum festival.
author: Jonathan F.

description: right there in the center of the god damn center of San Francisco. who doesn't love it? union square is the landmark for cheesecake factory (which reminds me, i have to review that place). you look to the center of union square, we got decorations, bums, coffee shops, fairs, robotic human shows. everything you can think off. OH and CABLE CARS. haha. also al the good top line brand names are located in this area of the city. Louis Vuitton and that Gucci store. Also some men just love to walk by that 40 ft front entrance of Victoria Secret.. one word up is that the traffic is getting worse here.
author: Eric Y.

description: I'm a big fan of Union Square for the holidays.  The tree lighting can get a bit crazy but once it is lit, the tree together with the holiday windows at Macy's and other department stores are worth the trip. If you want to escape the crowds, stroll down Maiden Lane and have a snack at Mocca. You can have tea at the Westin St. Francis or at the Rotunda at Neiman Marcus.  If you want tips on other good holiday tree lighting ceremonies check out www.99places.com.
author: Julie H.

description: i love this whole area....especially on a nice warm, breezy day. i was reminded yesterday while in the city how much i missed working in sf where i was only a few blocks away from all the wonderful shops and restaurants! it's just nicer to be around here on a weekday than the crazy hustle and bustle of weekends.
author: Jane Y.

description: nice area to sit out on the rare nice days in san francisco.  people watching is fun, but watch out for creepy men who just sit and stare at girls... it's pretty nasty...  i would give union square 5 stars but because of those creepy pervs i can't...
author: charlotte s.

description: I LOVE UNION SQUARE. The location is nice. I love the See's candies and the little cafe thats there. I really like the pigeons that are around and also the large buildings. The huge Neiman Marcus makes it look spectacular. Do you like peace and quiet? this is the place to go.
author: William E.

description: I live in the city and I always go to Union Square to do my shopping and I always spend over my budget. I love the location and all the designer shops nearby. I used to come here to study and just hang out with friends. It's great accept for the dumbasses that walk so fucken slow and walk aimlessly. It's annoying, well ok I understand it's a tourist spot. But really? the crowd on weekends and nice days are just too much and annoying. If you plan on shopping go on a weekday but not Fridays. It's always crowded and the parking garage is always dayum full. But I still love Union Square it's the place to shop for all your designer goods and such.
author: chelle b.
